questions.text: Which is the initial fluid of choice for diarrhoea in an infant?
questions.solution:
The cornerstone of acute diarrhoea management is rehydration. The initial fluid of choice for diarrhea in an infant is Oral Rehydration Solution. It is specifically formulated to treat dehydration by replacing lost fluids and electrolytes. ORS contains the optimal ratio of sodium and glucose to facilitate sodium–glucose co-transport in the intestinal mucosa, which enhances water absorption.



Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics 21 St Page No 2028

choices.text: Administer the first dose of IV antibiotic and immediately refer to higher center
Give Oral fluids and ask the mother to continue the same and visit again the next day
Consider severe dehydration, start IV fluids, and IV antibiotics, and refer to higher center
Give Zinc supplementation and Oral rehydration solution and ask the mother to come back if some danger signs develop

questions.text: A 5-year-old who had previously experienced loose stools but no fever or blood in the feces was brought to the hospital. His mother claims that he is agitated and gulps down water quickly when given. When examined, the eyes are sunk in, and when the skin is pinched, it retracts but not instantly. What is the child's course of treatment?
questions.solution:
The given child has features suggestive of SOME dehydration. (Irritability/agitation/increased thirst/sunken eyes and delayed skin pinch).



In some dehydration - we use PLAN B - give 75ml/kg of ORS over 4 hours - which can be given orally/NG along with zinc to reduce the duration of diarrhoea. 



Hence, the best answer is option 4- Give Zinc supplementation and Oral rehydration solution and ask the mother to come back if some danger signs develop

Other Options

Option 1 - IV antibiotics and referral to higher centre according to IMNCI is done if child has severe pneumonia or very severe disease(presence of danger signs), not for some dehydration

Option 2 - Since child has some dehydration - we need to give ORS, not just oral fluids. Zn supplementation is also necessary in view of diarrhoea. 

Option 3 - IV Fluids are given in severe dehydration - however, the clinical signs in question stem are suggestive of some dehydration , not severe. 


You can also listen to the below audio to understand the management of diarrhoea in children.
 



Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 9 th Page No 430,494,498

questions.text: What is the first sign of puberty seen in girls?
questions.solution:
• The first physical sign of puberty in girls is typically a firm, tender lump under the center of one or both breasts, which appears on average at around 10.5 years. This is referred to as thelarche.
The sequence of puberty in males and females is given below

Girls: TPM
1. Thelarche
2. Pubarche
3. Menarche

Boys: TPAM
1. Testicular enlargement
2. Pubarche
3. Adrenarche
4. Moustache and Beard


Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 9 th Page No 284,285,286

questions.text: Which of the following is not a criteria for severe acute malnutrition in a 7-month-old child?
questions.solution:
World Health Organization (WHO) and UNICEF define severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in children 6 to 59 months of age as one or more of the following:

1. A weight-to-height ratio that is less than three standard deviations (SD/Z scores) from the average WHO growth reference. (W/L <-3SD)
2. Bipedal nutritional edema is present, or
3. Mid upper arm circumference is less than 11.5 cm.

Height for age is used as an indicator for chronic malnutrition, not SAM. If H/A <-2SD - child is said to have stunting or chronic malnutrition. 




Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 336

questions.text: How is the term "wasting" defined?
questions.solution:
The term malnutrition addresses 3 broad groups of conditions:

1. Wasting (low weight- for-height/length) aka Acute Malnutrition
2. Stunting (low height-for-age) aka Chronic Malnutrition
3. Underweight (low weight-for-age)

The term "wasting" is another term for Acute Malnutrition which is defined as weight for height being less than -2SD. 






Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 St Page No 333,334, table 57.2

questions.text: What is a reliable indicator for both acute and chronic malnutrition?
questions.solution:
Weight for age (option 1) is a reliable indicator for both acute and chronic malnutrition. It is low in both. If W/A is less than -2SD - child is said to be underweight.  

For Acute malnutrition: Weight for height is more reliable. Weight for height is low only in acute malnutrition, not in chronic. 

For Chronic malnutrition: Height for age is more reliable. Height for age is low only in chronic malnutrition, not in acute malnutrition





Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 333,334

questions.text: A three-year-old child is considered to have a delayed milestone if he does not:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is option (1) Use spoon 
By 18months -2 years a child can feed self with spoon. At 3 years, it’s an expected milestones and hence, inability to use a spoon by 3 years of age would be considered as delayed milestone.

Other options
 
  • Option 2 - Draw square - child learns to draw a square at 4.5 years of age. Hence, not able to draw square at 3 years is not developmental delay. 
  • Option 3 - Skip - Child learns to skip at 5 years of age. Hence, not able to skip at 3 years is not developmental delay. 
  • Option 4 - Climb alternate stair downstairs - Child learns to climb alternate stair downstairs at 4 years of age. Hence, not able to Climb alternate stair downstairs at 3 years is not developmental delay. 













Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 142,158

questions.text: The birth defect exhibited in the infant below was likely caused due to the use of which of the following medications during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The cleft lip given in the image above is typical of Isotretinoin's teratogenic effects.This medication should never be taken in a female of reproductive age without first ruling out pregnancy as it is often used to treat acne. Isotretinoin should be stopped atleast/minimum 1 month before pregnancy.


Retinoid Syndrome in Foetuses

Retinoids, which are synthetic vitamin A derivatives, if used by pregnant women and cause a distinctive pattern of birth abnormalities.

  • Craniofacial abnormalities: These may include small or malformed ears, cleft palate(as given , or facial asymmetry.
  • Central nervous system defects: Hydrocephalus or microcephaly
  • Cardiac abnormalities:  Ventricular septal defects/transposition of the great arteries 
  • Visual system abnormalities:  small or absent eyes (microphthalmia), cataracts, or optic nerve abnormalities.

Other options
Ferrous Sulphate(iron) and Folate are not teratogenic, infact given in pregnancy as supplements to reduce anemia/neural tube defect risk. Metaclopramide is non-teratogenic and a safe anti-emetic in pregnancy. 


Reference- Katzung Basic and Clinical Pharmacology 14th Edition Page no 527

choices.text: A baby born to a mother treated with beta-blockers

questions.text: Which of the following infants has the lowest risk of getting hypoglycemia?
questions.solution:
Appropriate for gestational age babies are not at risk for hypoglycemia(lowest risk amongst the given options). A baby born to a mother treated with beta-blockers/Infants of diabetic mothers and IUGR babies - all are at risk of getting hypoglycemia.

Neonates at risk of hypoglycemia include :
1. Birth weight <2000g
2. Gestational age <35 weeks
3. Small for gestational age infants (SGA): birth weight<10th percentile
4. Infants of diabetic mothers (IDM)
5. Large for gestational age (LGA) infants: birth weight>90th percentile
6. Neonates with Rh-hemolytic disease
7. Neonates born to mothers receiving therapy with Propranolol/Labetolol/oral hypoglycemic agents
8. Neonates with morphological features of growth restriction like three or more loose folds of skin around buttocks and thighs, loss of subcutaneous fat, difference of HC and CC>3cm
9. Any sick neonate e.g, those with perinatal asphyxia, polycythemia, sepsis, shock, etc
10. Family history of a genetic form of hypoglycemia
11. Congenital syndromes (e.g. Beckwith-Wiedermann), abnormal physical features (e.g., midline facial malformations, microphallus)
12. Neonates on parenteral nutrition. 



Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 339,984,985

questions.text: What is the most prevalent cause of bilateral proptosis in kids?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate answer would be Neuroblastoma as it is the most common cause of bilateral proptosis in children (more common than RB/RMS)

Metastatic neuroblastoma(<5 years) and/or acute myeloid leukemia (chloroma)(>5 years) should be considered in any child presenting with bilateral proptosis.

The Most common cause of unilateral proptosis in children is orbital cellulitis.


Reference- Parson's diseases of the eye 23rd edition Page no 345

choices.text: Result in gaseous exchange and are involved in oxygenation in the fetus
Important role in lung growth and in the development of respiratory muscles.
Helps in the conditioning of respiratory muscles.

questions.text: With respect to fetal breathing movements , Which of the following is an incorrect statement?
questions.solution:
Option 1 - is an incorrect statement.

Fetal breathing movements refer to the chest movements seen on an Antenatal USG and is a component of Biophysical Profile .

Fetal breathing movements are not involved in fetal oxygenation and the fetus instead relies on the placenta for gaseous exchange/oxygenation rather than the lungs(lungs are collapsed in a fetus) -hence, option 1 is an incorrect statement.

Importance of foetal breathing movement is that it helps in development of respiratory system(option 2)/conditioning of respiratory muscles (option 4) and nervous system to prepare the foetus for breathing after birth. They tend to increase as gestational age increases and child approaches term gestation(option 3).

Reference: Williams Obstetrics 24th edition Page no 339-342

questions.text: According to Wechsler intelligence scale scoring, average IQ of a normal child is:
questions.solution:
According to Wechsler intelligence scale scoring, average IQ of a normal child is 100 with a standard deviation of 15, thus best answer being 90.
  • The Wechsler Intelligence Scales are a series of assessments designed to measure an individual’s cognitive abilities.
  • These assessments help clinicians assess an individual’s cognitive functioning and provide an understanding of an individual’s intellectual strengths and weaknesses. The tests are composed of both verbal and performance tasks, which are all scored separately.
  • The scores are calculated using individual scores, developmental scores, and composite scores, enabling clinicians to assess an individual’s abilities within a range of categories.
  • These categories include verbal comprehension, perceptual reasoning, working memory, and processing speed.
  • The scores are used to compare the individual’s cognitive abilities in comparison to other individuals of similar ages and genders.
  • The Wechsler Intelligence Scales are a standardized measure of intelligence, providing a reliable and valid assessment, which helps clinicians determine cognitive strengths and weaknesses and devise effective treatment plans for individuals with learning or intellectual disabilities.


Reference- https://geniustests.com/about-wechsler/wechsler-intelligence-scale

questions.text: In Piaget's theory of cognitive development 'out of sight' out of mind' and 'here and now' is seen in the stage of:
questions.solution:
In Piaget's theory of cognitive development, the “out of sight, out of mind” and “here and now” concepts are seen in the Sensory-motor stage. In this stage, which occurs from birth to around two years of age, infants focus primarily on what they can see and feel right now in their surroundings.

They develop a preference for familiar objects and people, and do not make associations between objects that are not present. For example, an infant may be comforted by its mother’s touch and get upset when she is not around, instead of forming an understanding that its mother is coming back soon.

This reflects the 'here and now' concept, where objects and people that cannot be seen or touched have little relevance or understanding. It also reflects the 'out of sight, out of mind' concept, where any objects that are not in an infant's immediate environment are forgotten or ignored.

Other options
 

  • Preoperational stage (2–7 years): Egocentric thinking, symbolic play, but still no logical reasoning.

  • Concrete operational stage (7–11 years): Begins logical thought about concrete things, understands conservation.

  • Formal operational stage (11+ years): Abstract thinking, hypothesis testing, future planning.




Reference- https://www.webmd.com/children/piaget-stages-of-development

questions.text:
A mother who has a baby who is three months old asks the doctor if she can give her infant food(cereal).
What issues/future problems might this result in her child if she feeds cereal instead of breast milk?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is (1) Allergy due to the food content.

UNICEF, the World Health Organisation, and the Indian Academy of Pediatrics recommend that babies receive only breast milk for the first 6 months of life.

The most important basis/reason for this recommendation is allergy due to the proteins in animal milk and infant formula milk. Exclusive breastfeeding is associated with a lower risk of asthma, eczema, other allergic disorders, Crohn's and ulcerative colitis, obesity, leukaemia, diarrhoea, etc.

Moreover sweet supplements may cause the baby to be more inclined to drink supplements rather than breast milk which is more nutritious and essential for the baby. 

Reference-  Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics 21st edition Page no 321

questions.text: Newly erupted teeth are covered by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is (2) Nasmyth's membrane

Nasmyth's membrane (also called enamel cuticle) is a thin, delicate tissue covering the enamel of newly erupted teeth. It is derived from the reduced enamel epithelium. It protects the tooth temporarily after eruption and is eventually worn away by mastication and cleaning. It is produced by the ameloblast cells.

Other options

Option 1 - Perikymata -  They refer to the wave like transverse ridges or grooves on the enamel surface caused by rhythmic enamel deposition. They are part of enamel surface topography, not a covering

Option 3 -Fibrous tissue - refers to the gingivial connective tissue - not a covering for enamel on teeth. 

Reference- https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1048636430100170

questions.text: Which fontanelle is the last to close?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Anterior

Fontanelle is a space between the bones of the skull in an infant or fetus, where ossification is not complete and the sutures not fully developed.
Anterior fontanelle is the last to close at 18-24 months of life.

Approximate timeline for closure of fontanelle are as follows:




Reference- https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK542197/

questions.text: One and a half year old child with history of diet including only rice & milk, had a protruding abdomen, and a low albumin level, but no proteinuria. What is the most likely cause for the above?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Kwashiorkor

The child has protruding abdomen which is likely due to ascites secondary due to albumin loss and a poor diet history. These findings are suggestive of child having Kwashiorkar characterised by visceral protein loss (albumin loss) resulting in ascites, oedema, poor appetite and high mortality. 

  


Other options
  • Option 2 - Marasmus will have muscle protein loss with baggy pant appearance/simian facies and occurs usually in infants (<1y) unlike 1.5 y old child given in question stem. 
  • Option 3 – Nephrotic syndrome will present with massive proteinuria (>40mg/m2/hr), not nil proteinuria as given in question stem. 
  • Option 4 – Poor diet history of rice and milk points more towards protein deficiency leading to kwashiorkor than due to liver failure.

Reference- Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics 21st edition Page no 337, 1310, 2105

questions.text: Which of the following parameters, if found within the normal range for age, most reliably rules out malnutrition?
questions.solution:
• BMI and Skin fold thickness can erroneously be normal in patients having oedema (For eg. Patients with Kwashiorkor may have a normal weight due to water retention and oedema).
  • Hence in such scenarios, only a normal lean body mass which indicates normal body stores of protein and specifically rules out malnutrition.

Reference- https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/nursing-and-health-professions/lean-body-weight

questions.solution:
• A hand-to-hand shift of objects in a 6-month-old indicates/implies Comparison between objects.
  • Reaching out for objects implies visual motor coordination(option 1), while palmar grasp gone implies voluntary release (option 2), and sitting without support/walking implies exploring the world(option 4)
Following are the developmental milestones against the developmental implications due to these milestones:

questions.text: Identify the incorrect criteria for defining a case of Severe Acute Malnutrition(SAM):
questions.solution:
Weight for age less than 2SD (option 1) is not used to define Severe Acute Malnutrition(SAM). 

World Health Organization (WHO) and UNICEF define severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in children 6 to 59 months of age as any one or more  of the following:

1. A weight-to-height ratio that is under three standard deviations (SD or Z scores) from the average WHO growth reference.
2. Bipedal edema is present, or
3. The upper-middle arm circumference is less than 11.5 cm(or 115 mm).


Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 336

questions.text:
Match the following with correct response:
(a) Social smile (i) 1-2 months
(b) Pincer grasp (ii) 5-6 months
(c) Walks 1-2 steps (iii) 9-11 months
(d) Transfer objects (iv) 12-13 months
questions.solution:
Milestone matched with age

1. Social smile (smile after being talked to)— 2 months.

2. Pincer grasp (mature)— 11-12 months ; Immature pincer grasp - 9 months

3. Creeps well; walks but falls; stands without support—12-13 months

4. Unidextrous reach (reaching out for objects with one hand); transfers objects— 6-7 months.










Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 182

questions.text: When does a newborn reach half the height of an adult?
questions.solution:
1. A normal child at birth is 50 cm long. Its height increases by 25 cm by 1 year of life (75 cm at the end of 1 year) and by 12-13 cm in the next year (87-88cm at the end of 2 years). Thereafter, it steadily increases by 6 cm per year.
  2. A baby reaches half of their adult height by 18-24 months (2 years) of age. (Adult height is 160-170 cm, height at 2 years is 87 cm)
  3. Height doubles by 4 years (birth length is 50cm, height is 100 cm at 4 years)
  4. It triples by 12 years of age (150cm).


Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 142

questions.text: What is the important fatty acid that is present in breast milk and is important for the baby's growth?
questions.solution:
• The important fatty acid present in breast milk, which is important for baby growth is Docosahexanoic acid.
  • Up to 5-10% of fatty acids in human milk are poly-unsaturated. Most of these are Linoleic acid with smaller amounts of Linolenic acid. Linoleic acid gives rise to arachidonic acid.
  • Linolenic acid gives rise to Docosahexanoic acid. Docosahexanoic acid is found in human milk and brain lipids and is required for the development of othe nervous system and visual abilities during the first six months of life.


Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 307

choices.text: Anaerobic metabolism in the fetus can cause acidemia
Low APGAR score at 1 minute indicates the need for immediate PPV
Low APGAR score at 7 minutes indicates neonatal death/mortality.

questions.text: Which of the following regarding oxygenation of the fetus or neonate is not true?
questions.solution:
Option (4) statement is not true.
APGAR score at 7-10 minutes, if low, may indicate cerebral palsy/morbidity but not death/mortality (option 4).
According to NRP, neonatal resuscitation is continued for 20 minutes and if there is no heart rate/breathing at 20 minutes - only then is neonatal resuscitation stopped and child is declared to have died. 

Other options

  • Option 1 - True: Anaerobic metabolism due to inadequate oxygenation leads to lactic acid buildup and acidemia, which is a known fetal response to hypoxia.

  • Option 2 -True: The foetus relies on the placenta for gas exchange, and CO is washed out via placental circulation to the mother’s lungs for excretion.

  • Option 3 - True: If the child is gasping or apneic/bradycardic (HR<100) at 1 minute after initial steps of resuscitation which in turn would lead to low APGAR- child requires positive pressure ventilation and immediate resuscitation. 




Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 872

questions.text: A 7-year-old child who has ingested a button battery is immediately taken to the emergency room; an X-ray revealed that the battery was in the child's duodenum. The child is asymptomatic. What should be done next?
questions.solution:
As per the latest ESPGHAN Guidelines - if the button battery is beyond the esophagus with no magnet co-ingestion and the child is asymptomatic - the recommended management is repeat X-ray after 7 days.  Endoscopic removal is done if the battery has not been passed in 14 days or if the battery is in oesophagus/child is symtomatic. 

#controversial 
This is a highly controversial question. Answer has been confirmed with Professors at AIIMS,Delhi. Answer has been given wrong in multiple Qbanks.





Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 1942

questions.text: Which of the following milestones is missing in a 3-year-old child considered to have delayed development:
questions.solution:
By 18 months - 24months, a child should be capable of feeding themselves with a spoon. If a 3 year old child is having trouble doing this, it suggests that the child has not hit the required developmental milestones and should be considered having developmental delay. 

Other options
  • Option 2 - Draw square - child learns to draw a square at 4.5 years of age. Hence, not able to draw square at 3 years is not developmental delay. 
  • Option 1 - Hop - Child learns to hop on 1 foot at 4 years of age. Hence, not able to hop at 3 years is not developmental delay. 
  • Option 4 - Climb downstairs alternate feet - Child learns to climb downstairs alternate feet at 4 years of age. Hence, not able to Climb with alternate feet downstairs at 3 years is not developmental delay. 










Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 44,45,50,51

questions.text: Craniopagus is basically the fusion of:
questions.solution:
Craniopagus is a rare type of parasitic twinning, in which two partially formed twins remain joined at the head only. Each retain its own heart and vertebral column, but share brain tissue and its blood vessels. The degree of shared brain tissue can range from a simple association of brains, to partial brain separation with fused hemispheres, and, in some cases, almost complete brain separation. 





Other options 

Option 1 -  Fusion of the spines is called Rachipagus

Option 2 - Fusion at the thorax/head - Cephalothoracopagus

Option 4 - Fusion of thorax only  - Thoracopagus



Reference-https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7342745

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the pediatric assessment triangle?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Heart Rate 

PAEDIATRIC ASSESSMENT TRIANGLE:
It is a rapid evaluation tool that establishes a child’s clinical status and his/her category of illness to direct initial management priorities. It has also been incorporated widely into the paediatric resuscitation curriculum.

The THREE components of the Paediatric Assessment Triangle include -
(1) Appearance
(2)Work of Breathing
(3)Circulation  



Reference-https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4318552/

The correct option is (2): 3 years

questions.text: Goldenhar's syndrome is associated with the abnormal development of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: First and Second Branchial Arches 

GOLDENHAR SYNDROME:
  • Goldenhar syndrome , a rare congenital defect is also known as OCULOAURICULAR VERTEBRAL SPECTRUM syndrome.
  • It is associated with anomalous development of the first and second branchial arch.

CLINICAL FEATURES:
1. Incomplete development of the ear, nose, soft palate, lip, mandible (usually on one side )
2. Preauricular skin tags

5. Microphthalmia

questions.text: Which of these is not an alternative way to measure height in a 4 year old boy?
questions.solution:
Head circumference (option 1) is not a measure of height.
 
  • Knee height can be used as a surrogate to measure height where the child sits on a stool and Length/ height of knee from ground is taken, but it is not used commonly. 
  • Arm span in a child is a surrogate marker of height (Arm span is equal to height at 10-11 years of age and later arm span is more than height by only 1-12 cm) and can be used as an Alternative way to measure height.
  • Stadiometer is an instrument which is used to measure height of child after 2 years of age.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page no 151, 881.

questions.text: Handedness is established by?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is option (1) 3 years.

Handedness, or the preference for using one hand over the other, is typically established around the age of 3 years.
However, it becomes more pronounced and stable as the child grows, with clearer hand preference emerging by 4-5 years.  

Important milestones attained by a 3-year-old child
  • Climb stairs upwards by 1 feet/step
  • Develops Handedness
  • Make a 9 Block Tower
  • Knows Name, Age, Gender
  • Ride Tricycle
  • Copies circle


A few single-liners frequently tested in exams:
  • 3-5 months – HAND REGARD.
  • 4 months - BINOCULAR VISION
  • 4-6 months – MOUTHING
  • 9 months – OBJECT PERMANENCE
  • 1 year – CASTING – Deliberately throwing objects to the ground
  • 3 years – HANDEDNESS – Child starts using one hand for daily use


Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page no 143.

choices.text: Weight under 75th centile and height under 25th centile

questions.text: Adequate nutritional status in an infant with birth weight of 2.8 kg is assessed by:
questions.solution:
The normal pattern of growth generally implies an average of readings obtained in a group of healthy individuals, along with a permissible range of variation between the 3rd and 97th percentiles. (option C)
  • The average birth weight of Indian neonates is about 3 kg.
  • After initial loss of extracellular fluid over the first few days, infants regain their birth weight by 10 days of life.
  • For the first three months, they gain approximately 20-40 g per day.
  • For the remaining year, they gain about 400 g of weight every month. (option B)
  • The infant measures approximately 50 cm at birth, and about 75 cm at one year of life. This corresponds to an increase in about 25 cm in the 1st year of life.
  • The anterior fontanelle closes by 18 months of age. (option D)


Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21th Edition, Page. No- 151, 3055.

questions.text: A child presents with a history of late wound healing and repeated infection. Dryness and rash is noted around the mouth and nose. Which mineral deficiency is likely to be seen in this child?
questions.solution:
These constellations of findings given represent zinc deficiency in the child and are managed by oral supplementation of zinc.
Severe zinc deficiency is characterized by dermatitis with the following features:
  • Typically erythematous, scaly, vesiculobullous, or pustular lesions
  • Site: Perioral and perianal areas or on extensor surfaces of the limbs



Acrodermatitis enteropathica refers to an autosomal recessive condition where absorption of zinc from the GI tract is impaired. It requires a higher dose of oral zinc supplementation.

Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 31th Edition, Page. No- 263.

questions.text: A child came with the following finding. Which vitamin deficiency is responsible?
questions.solution:
The given image shows bowing of the legs or genu varum, which occurs due to Rickets that results from the deficiency of vitamin D. Deficiency of vitamin D results in poor calcium/phosphate absorption in gut and that in turn results in poor mineralization(deposition of Calcium/Phosphate) of bone, leading to rickets.  


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2531.

questions.text: Which of the following primitive reflexes would persists throughout life?
questions.solution:
The parachute reflex is a primitive reflex that persists throughout life. It is elicited by holding an infant's trunk and suddenly lowering them, simulating a fall. In response, the infant extends their arms to protect themselves, which is crucial for future motor skills such as walking.



This reflex typically begins to emerge around 7-8 months of age, fully develops by 10-11 months, and remains present throughout life.

Primitive reflexes appear and disappear at specific stages of development. The persistence or absence of these reflexes can indicate developmental delay and potential central nervous system dysfunction.





Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK554606/

questions.text: What is the glucose content of ReSoMal?
questions.solution:
ReSoMal, which stands for Rehydration Solution for Malnutrition, has a glucose content of 125 mmol/L. It is an oral rehydration solution specifically designed for severely malnourished children and is typically used in inpatient centres for treating dehydration in children having severe acute malnutrition.

ReSoMal contains a higher glucose concentration (125 mmol/L) and a lower sodium concentration (45 mmol/L) compared to standard WHO-ORS. This formulation helps effectively address the hypoglycemia/hypernatremia seen in children with SAM.

questions.text: A child is being assessed for developmental milestones. At what age of life can the child transfer objects from one hand to another?
questions.solution:
The child reaches out for objects with one hand (unidextrous reach) and transfers objects from one hand to the other at 6 months of age(option 2)

Other milestones at 6 months of age:
 
  • Gross Motor: The child can sit independently with arms forward for support, often described as "tripod" sitting.
  • Social and Adaptive: The child recognizes strangers and may exhibit stranger anxiety.
  • Language: The child begins to produce monosyllabic sounds, such as "ba," "da," and "pa."

Other options

-A child attains a mature pincer grasp around 12 months of age.
-A child can build a tower of two blocks and imitate scribbling around 15 months of age.
-A child can build a tower of three blocks at around 18 months of age.

questions.text: Stranger anxiety is seen at which age?
questions.solution: Stranger anxiety typically emerges around 6-7 months of age. This is a developmental stage where infants may show distress or apprehension when interacting with unfamiliar individuals.

questions.text: Which is the Ideal maintainable fluid of choice in children
questions.solution:
5% dextrose and Normal saline(DNS) is the ideal maintenance fluid in children.Hypotonic fluids increase the risk of hyponatremia, hence Isotonic fluids(like normal saline) with 5% dextrose are recommended as standard maintenance fluid except in neonates.5% dextrose provides 17 calories/100 mL and nearly 20% of the daily caloric needs.


Note: #controversial - Till 2010's - ideal maintenance fluid in children used to be considered as 1/2 NS + 5%D. However, recent research in AIIMS/PGIMER Chandigarh and MAMC concluded that isotonic fluids like NS + 5% D should be preferred over 1/2NS + 5% due to increased risk of hyponatremia with hypotonic fluids. Hence, option (2) >> Option(1).  The answer has been confirmed after checking with Pediatrics Professor Dr Rakesh Lodha at AIIMS, New Delhi. 

(Answer might be given as N/2 +5%D in non updated Q-banks and by old faculty who are not updated with new research and guidelines)


Reference:
1. Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page No 426.
2.0.45% Versus 0.9% Saline in 5% Dextrose as Maintenance Fluids in Children Admitted With Acute Illness: A Randomized Control Trial. https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/36040464/

questions.text: What is the rate of increase in head circumference in the first 3 months of life?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is option(2) 2 cm/month.

When a child is born - At birth, the head circumference(HC) is 33-34cm. 

Head circumference(HC) after birth Grows at the following rate:
 
  • 2 cm/month in first 3 months (option 2)
  • 1 cm/month in the next 3 months
  • 0.5 cm/month in the next 6 months.
At 1 year, HC is 46 cm. At 2 years - head circumference is 48cm (90% of adult HC). As an adult - the HC is 52-53cm. 





Reference: Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 9th Edition, Page No 12-14.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is wrong about Rota Virus Vaccine
questions.solution:
• Rota Virus Vaccine is not a subunit Vaccine.
  • It is Oral Live Attenuated vaccine available as Monovalent and Pentavalent forms.
  • According to CDC guidelines Rotavirus should not be given beyond 8 months of age
  • Rotarix (Monovalent) - 2 oral doses at gap of 4 weeks not later than 24 weeks
  • Rotateq (Pentavalent) - 3 doses at 2,4 and 6 months. All doses before 32 weeks
  • Rotavac ( Monovalent Liquid Frozen) - 3 oral doses 4 weeks apart at 6,10 and 14 weeks.
Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page No 270.

questions.text:
The anthropometry of a 5y old is as follows.
Weight for height:  -1.2SD,
Height for age :  -2.5 SD,
Weight for Age :  -2.7 SD.
According to WHO criteria, what does the child have?
questions.solution:
According to WHO criteria, since H/A is less than -2SD but W/H is normal (between +2 to -2SD) the diagnosis of this child is Chronic Malnutrition. (option 1) 

Note:  Weight for age(W/A) is also below -2SD in the example - that would make the child "underweight" - but it is not in options. Remember, acute malnutrition is defined using low Weight for length ( W/L <-2SD) while chronic malnutrition is defined using low Height for age (H/A <-2SD). Weight for age is not used in definition of either and a child with low W/A is simply called underweight.  

Below is the table with classification of Malnutrition.



Other options
 
  • Option 2 - Only H/A is low, W/L is normal - hence child does not have acute on chronic malnutrition.
  • Option 3 -  W/L is normal ( between +2SD and -2SD) - hence child does not have acute malnutrition
  • Option 4 - W/L is normal ( between +2SD and -2SD) - hence child does not have acute malnutrition

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page No 334.

questions.text: 15 y old child presents with short stature. His Upper segment/Lower segment ratio is 0.8:1. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Normal U:L segment ratio in child >7 y is more than 1.
  • Causes for Low U:L ratio -
  1. Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia,
  2. Marfan syndrome,
  3. Vertebral anomalies.
  • High U:L ratio cause-
  1. Rickets,
  2. Achondroplasia,
  3. Turner,
  4. Congenital hypothyroidism.
Reference: Ghai essential Pediatrics, 9th Edition, Page No 32.

questions.text:
In which of the following conditions is live vaccination not contraindicated?
A. Digeorge
B. Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome
C. Ataxia telangiectasia
D. Complement deficiency
questions.solution:
Correct answer is option (2)D only

Live vaccines are not contraindicated in cases of (D)Complement deficiency. Individuals with complement deficiency have intact T-cell and B-cell immunity and hence, can mount an effective immune response to live vaccines. While these patients are more susceptible to bacterial infections caused by Neisseria/Pneumococcus species due to a malfunction in the complement system, their adaptive immune system remains functional. Therefore, live vaccines are generally safe for them.

However, they are contraindicated in patients with impaired T cell function (i.e. impaired cell mediated immunity) - like DiGeorge syndrome, Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome, and Ataxia Telangiectasia due to the risk of severe or fatal infections. In DiGeorge syndrome, Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome, and Ataxia Telangiectasia, the patients‘ T-cell immunity is compromised, making them vulnerable to serious complications from live vaccines. 

Other options

Digeorge Syndrome or CATCH -22 syndrome is caused to 22q11 deletion leading to failure of formation structures from 3/4th pharyngeal pouches(ie thymus and parathyroid gland are not formed). Its characterised by Cardiac anamolies, Abnormal facies, Thymic aplsia,  Cleft palate and Hypocalcemia - hence CATCH-22. Thymic aplasia leads to loss of T-cell maturation/T cell lymphopenia and loss of cell mediated immunity. 

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS) is an X-linked recessive immunodeficiency disorder caused by mutations in the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASp), primarily affecting T lymphocytes. It has a triad of 1. Eczema, 2. Thrombocytopenia and 3. Loss of Cell mediated immunity.

Ataxia telangiectasia is caused by mutations in the ATM gene, which is essential for repairing double-strand DNA breaks. This defect in DNA repair impairs immunoglobulin isotype switching and the formation of antigen receptors, resulting in partial T-cell deficiency. Consequently, live vaccines are contraindicated in these patients.
 


Reference: Essential Pediatrics by O.P Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 179 .

questions.text: Which of the following is not a correct match for ABCD according to paediatrics advanced life support?
questions.solution:
According to Pediatric Advanced Life Support (PALS), D-dehydration is incorrectly matched.

The American Heart Association's Pediatric Advanced Life Support (PALS) curriculum emphasizes the structured ABCDE format for primary assessment: Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, and Exposure.

Airway: The first priority in the primary survey is ensuring the patient's airway is clear. Simple maneuvers like a chin-lift or jaw thrust can help re-align the airway. Artificial airways such as oropharyngeal (OPA) and nasopharyngeal airways (NPA) may be used when appropriate.

Breathing: Assessment includes evaluating the respiratory rate, effort, abnormal sounds, and pulse oximetry. Central cyanosis is a sign of severe hypoxia, indicating the need for oxygen supplementation and respiratory support.

Circulation: Cardiovascular function is evaluated by assessing skin color, temperature, heart rate, rhythm, pulses, and capillary refill time.

Disability: This focuses on the child's neurological status, particularly the level of consciousness. Light reflexes and pediatric scoring systems (like AVPU or Glasgow Coma Scale) are used for assessment. Immediate cardiorespiratory evaluation is required if there is a depressed level of consciousness.

Exposure: After stabilization, the child should be exposed to check for any undetected injuries. A focused physical exam should assess for burns, bruises, bleeding, fractures, or joint issues.

questions.text: What is the fluid of choice for shock in a child with severe acute malnutrition?
questions.solution:
The recommended fluid for resuscitating a child with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in shock is Ringer's lactate with 5% dextrose.

Clinical Indicators of Shock in SAM:
Lethargy or unconsciousness
Cold extremities
Delayed capillary refill (>3 seconds)
Weak and fast pulse
Intravenous Fluid Resuscitation for SAM with Shock:
In children with SAM, IV fluid resuscitation is only indicated in cases of shock. The following fluids are recommended:

Ringer's lactate with 5% dextrose
Half-normal saline with 5% dextrose
Half-strength Darrow's solution with 5% dextrose
If these mixtures are unavailable, Ringer's lactate can be used as an alternative.

10% Glucose:
This is used to treat hypoglycemia in SAM and is not intended for restoring intravascular volume. It can be administered orally or intravenously to manage low blood sugar.

questions.solution:
Parenteral fluid in ml/kg/day for neonates with a birthweight <1500 gms
 
Bodyweight <1500 gms

questions.text: Calculate the mid-parental height of a male child whose father's and mother's height are 185 cm and 175 cm, respectively.
questions.solution:
Mid-parental height for a male child = (Mother's height + Father's height / 2) + 6.5

Mid-parental height for a female child = (Mother's height + Father's height /2) - 6.5

Ref -Ghai essential Pediatrics 9th edition Page 32

questions.text: Which is the best indicator of long-term nutritional status in the pediatric population.
questions.solution:
Height for age indicates chronic malnutrition.
Nutritional status is often assessed in terms of anthropometry
• Low weight for height, or wasting, indicates acute malnutrition.
• High weight for height indicates overweight.
• Low height for age, or stunting, indicates chronic malnutrition. This is the best indicator of long-term nutritional status in the pediatric population.
• Low weight for age indicates acute or chronic malnutrition. It does not differentiate between wasting and stunting. Hence, it has limited clinical significance. Ref- Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics 20th Edition • Page no 298

questions.text: At what age does the posterior fantanelle ideally close?
questions.solution:
The posterior fontanelle is present between the junction of the sagittal and lambdoid suture and closes at around 2-3 months of birth.
The anterior fontanelle closes at around 18-24 months and sphenoid fontanelle at around 2-3 months following birth
Ref: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition
• Page no: 418

questions.text: Identify the chromosomal abnormality from the karyotyping shown below
questions.solution:
The given karyotype is trisomy 13 suggestive of Patau syndrome.
Patau syndrome, also called trisomy 13, is the least common and most severe of the viable autosomal trisomies. Median survival is fewer than 3 days.
It is characterized by forebrain and midline facial abnormalities.
-Patients develop holoprosencephaly, characterized by fused frontal lobes and a single ventricle.
-Olfactory bulbs are absent.
-midline facial abnormalities include cleft lip, cleft palate, nasal defects, and a single central eye ("cyclops").
-Other defects associated with Patau's syndrome include polydactyly, rocker-bottom feet, and congenital heart diseases.Ref- Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics 20th edition Page 611

questions.text: A child can walk upstairs and downstairs 2 feet per step and able to speak in simple sentences. What is his approximate age
questions.solution:
At 2 years a child with attain the following milestones
• Motor: Walks up and downstairs, one step at a time
• Adaptive: Makes a tower of 6 blocks
• Language: Simple sentences, a vocabulary of 50-100 words, uses pronouns at 2.5 yrs
• Social: Asks for food and starts toilet training, listens to stories. Ref- Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics 21st edition Page 142

questions.text: In which of the following condition the bone age will be lesser than chronological age?
questions.solution:
Short stature can be defined as growth below m -2 SD for age and sex. If a child's stature is less than -3 SD below the average for their age and gender it is more likely to indicate pathological short stature. A child's height between -2 and -3 SD is more likely due to physiological, i.e. familial or constitutional short stature.
Constitutional delay: Bone age < Chronological age
• Familial short stature: Bone age = Chronological age
Bone age is more than chronological age in precocious puberty and obesity. Nelson textbook of pediatries 21st edition • Page 155-156

questions.text: Which of the following is part of the WHO criteria for Severe Acute Malnutrition(SAM)?
questions.solution:
The World Health Organization (WHO) defines severe acute malnutrition (SAM) as any of the following conditions for children between the ages of 6 and 59 months:

1. A weight that is less than three standard deviations (SD) of the WHO Child Growth Standards for length (or height).

2. Bilateral edema is seen.

3. A circumference around the mid-upper arm (MUAC) of less than 11.5 cm.

To summarize, a MUAC of less than 11.5 cm is indicative of SAM.

Reference
Nelson textbook of pediatrics 21st edition - Page no. 336
Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition - Page no. 97

questions.text: In the pediatric wards, you notice a baby completely preoccupied with play and a mother trying hard to spoon-feed him. He is busy stacking toy cubes on top of each other and starts gleefully clapping once he makes a tower of 6 cubes. What is the likely age that this milestone corresponds to?
questions.solution:
• Stacking 6 cubes and showing delight on achievement corresponds to a fine motor milestone around 24 months.

  • At this age, children are developing more precise hand-eye coordination and goal-directed play, which includes stacking multiple cubes.

Other options:

  • 15 months: Typically stacks 2–3 cubes; still developing basic hand-eye coordination.

  • 18 months: Can stack 4–5 cubes, clapping and self-recognition emerge but 6 cubes is less common.

  • 36 months: Stacks 9–10 cubes and engages in more complex constructive play.



Reference: 
Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition - Page no. 49

questions.text: A mother brings her child to the pediatric outpatient department complaining of recurrent infections. On examination, her child has a length-for-age less than —2 standard deviations below the median. There is a history of improper feeding in the past. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Stunting is defined as length/height-for-age < –2 SD below the median of the WHO growth standards.

  • It reflects chronic malnutrition and is associated with recurrent infections, poor feeding history, and long-term growth failure.

Other options:

  • Wasting: Low weight-for-height (< –2 SD); indicates acute malnutrition.

  • Underweight: Low weight-for-age (< –2 SD); can result from both acute and chronic malnutrition.

  • Malnutrition: A broad term encompassing stunting, wasting, and underweight; not a specific diagnosis.



Reference
Nelson textbook of pediatrics 21st edition - Page no 334

questions.text: The most important source of reducing equivalents for fatty acid synthesis in the liver is:
questions.solution:
The most important source of NADPH in hepatocytes (liver cells) is the Hexose Monophosphate (HMP) shunt, also called the Pentose Phosphate Pathway (PPP).

Since the GMP shunt pathway and fatty acid synthesis occur in the cytosol of the cell, there are no membranes or permeability barriers to NADPH transport.

This NADPH is involved as a donor of reducing equivalents in the reduction of 3-ketoacyl and 2,3-unsaturated acyl derivatives.

In the liver, HMP shunt accounts for the majority of NADPH production used for lipogenesis, cholesterol synthesis, and detoxification (e.g., glutathione reduction).

Other sources:
* Extramitochondrial isocitrate dehydrogenase (minor source)
* Malic enzyme.

 
Feature NADPH NADH
Role Reducing power for biosynthesis ATP generation via ETC
Produced in HMP Shunt Glycolysis, TCA, Beta-oxidation
Used in Fatty acid/steroid synthesis, antioxidant defense Oxidative phosphorylation
Cellular location Cytosol Mitochondria

Key Enzyme Reactions Involving Reducing Agents
Enzyme Cofactor/Reducing Agent
Fatty acid synthase NADPH
Glutathione reductase NADPH
Cytochrome P450 monooxygenase NADPH
Lactate dehydrogenase NADH ↔ NAD
Pyruvate dehydrogenase complex NAD, FAD, lipoic acid
Succinate dehydrogenase FAD
Ribonucleotide reductase Thioredoxin (reduced)


Other options: 

  • The TCA (Tricarboxylic Acid) cycle primarily produces NADH and FADH, which are used in oxidative phosphorylation to generate ATP.

    • It does not produce NADPH, and thus, is not a direct source of reducing equivalents for fatty acid synthesis.

    • However, citrate from the TCA cycle can exit the mitochondria and be used to generate acetyl-CoA for lipogenesis, but not NADPH.

  • Glycolysis generates pyruvate, ATP, and NADH, but not NADPH.

    • While glycolysis provides intermediates like pyruvate (which can be converted to acetyl-CoA), it does not contribute reducing equivalents directly.

  • The uronic acid pathway is involved in the metabolism of glucuronic acid and some sugars.

    • It generates very little NADPH and is not a significant contributor to fatty acid synthesis.


Reference: Harper's illustrated Biochemistry 31st edition

questions.text: Dystrophin protein is absent completely in which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Dystrophin is a structural protein crucial for muscle fiber stability. It links the cytoskeleton of muscle cells to the extracellular matrix via the dystrophin-glycoprotein complex.

1. Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD)
Dystrophin is completely absent due to frameshift or nonsense mutations in the DMD gene on the X chromosome.

  • Onset: Early childhood

  • Severity: Most severe muscular dystrophy

  • Clinical features: Gower's sign, calf pseudohypertrophy, progressive muscle weakness

  • Diagnosis: Absent dystrophin on muscle biopsy or immunohistochemistry

    Etiology & Genetics

  • Inheritance: X-linked recessive

  • Gene affected: DMD gene on Xp21, one of the largest known human genes

  • Mutation: Most commonly frameshift or nonsense mutations → leads to complete absence of dystrophin

    Dystrophin Protein

  • A cytoskeletal protein that connects actin filaments to the extracellular matrix via the dystrophin-glycoprotein complex

  • Acts as a shock absorber for muscle cells during contraction

  • Absent in DMD, leading to muscle membrane instability, degeneration, and progressive muscle damage

    Diagnosis: 

  • Serum creatine kinase (CK): Very high (often >10,000 IU/L)

  • Genetic testing: Confirmatory – identifies DMD gene mutations

  • Muscle biopsy: Shows absence of dystrophin on immunohistochemistry or western blot

  • Other options:

2. Myasthenia Gravis
Autoimmune disorder involving antibodies against acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction.

  • Dystrophin is normal

  • Symptoms: Fatigable muscle weakness, ptosis, diplopia

3. Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS)
Autoimmune disorder with antibodies against presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels, impairing acetylcholine release.

  • Dystrophin is normal

  • Symptoms: Proximal muscle weakness that improves with activity

4. Becker’s Muscular Dystrophy (BMD)
Dystrophin is present but reduced or abnormal due to in-frame mutations in the DMD gene.

  • Onset: Later than DMD

  • Severity: Milder than DMD

  • Muscle biopsy: Shows reduced or truncated dystrophin


Reference:Nelson textbook of pediatrics 21st edition Page no 3281-3283

questions.text: The next step in the evaluation for a newborn at 48 hours after birth who has a history of not passing meconium is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Lower GI study

Delayed Passage of meconium can occur due to various causes like :
  1. Prematurity
  2.  Sepsis
  3. respiratory distress
  4. Gastrointestinal obstruction
The next step in the evaluation for a newborn at 48 hours after birth who has a history of not passing meconium is a lower GI study. This helps assess for potential causes such as intestinal obstruction or Hirschsprung disease.

Option 1 and 2 are specific tests for the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis
Option 4 Manometry is done to assess the smooth muscle tone of the GI tract.

Some important points to remember in case of CF are
  • AR disorder
  • CFTR gene mutation – located on Chr 7q. [ delta F 508 – deletion of phenylalanine is most common mutation]
  • Mucoviscidosis as Cl- ions cannot enter into the lumen leading to thick secretions
  • Symptoms in newborns may include:
Delayed growth
Failure to gain weight normally during childhood
No bowel movements in first 24 to 48 hours of life
Salty-tasting skin
 
  • Diagnostic criteria :
  1. Presence of typical clinical features
  2. History of CF in a sibling
  3. Positive newborn screening test – immunoreactive trypsin test
If any 1 of the above is present, CF should be confirmed with lab tests
  1. 2 elevated sweat chloride concentrations
  2. Identification if 2 CF mutations
  3. Abnormal transepithelial nasal potential difference
If any 1 lab test is positive, diagnosis of CF is made.
  • Management
  1. Antibiotics – Amoxiclav
  2. Mucolytics
  3. CFTR modulators – ivacaftor, lumacaftor, tezacaftor.


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page No 280,281

questions.text: Which among the following is concerning if observed on day 10 of life?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia

Direct bilirubin >2mg/dL at any time after birth is considered pathological hyperbilirubinemia.

Physiological jaundice represents the inability of the underdeveloped liver of neonates to handle increased bilirubin production. It starts from 24 hours after birth and lasts till 14 days. This is unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia can be indicative of liver dysfunction or obstruction of the biliary system and is thus concerning if observed on day 10 of life.

 

Option 1 : Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia is normal because of excessive hemolysis after birth and the absence of enzymes to conjugate the elevated levels of bilirubin

Option 3 : Infants lose weight during the first 7 days after birth. Term infants lose 10% of their body weight and preterms lose 15% they regain this lost weight till 10-14 days of life. Thus no weight gain by 10th day is normal

Option 4 : dolls eye reflex also known and oculocephalic reflex appears in neonates soon after birth and persists for life. It is routinely checked by doing the Dolls eye test to assess brain stem function in neonates.



Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page No 168-170

questions.text: A newborn is experiencing bilious vomiting on the first day of life. The initial investigation to be carried out is
questions.solution:
The correct option is (1): Abdominal X-ray

The initial investigation to be carried out in case of bilious vomiting should be an abdominal X-ray (erect). A neonante presenting with Bilious vomiting can have 3 diagnoses which can be differentiated on the basis of X-ray.



Common congenital GI conditions seen in Neonates and differentiating features:





Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 1951

choices.text: Diagnosed only by persistent presence of IgM antibody after 6 months
It is the most common cause on nonsyndromic sensory neural hearing loss
Mothers of developing countries who transmit the virus are usually symptomatic

questions.text: Which statement regarding congenital CMV infection is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: It is the most common cause on nonsyndromic sensory neural hearing loss

Option 1 : Prenatal diagnosis includes the presence of IgM antibodies in the mother. Postnatal diagnosis involves isolation of the virus from Urine or Saliva via DNA PCR or culture within first few weeks of life. Thus the first option is incorrect.

Option 2 : Is the true statement. CMV infection stands out as the most common non-genetic cause of sensorineural hearing loss. Other infections that can cause congenital SNHL are toxoplasmosis, rubella.

Option 3 : Congenital CMV infection is mostly asymptomatic at birth and symptoms occur only in about 10% of neonates. Asymptomatic newborns have a lesser risk of sequale as compared to others.

Option 4 : Although the risk of transmission of infection is higher in symptomatic females, in most populations the total number of infants who have acquired an infection is 3-4 times more from asymptomatic mothers than symptomatic as the number of females with active CMV infection are less and most are asymptomatic.

Thus, option 2 stands out as the most correct option among all others.

Some points about Congenital CMV infection
  • Infants present with petichial rashes, jaundice, chorioretinitis, HSaM.
  • seen
 



     




Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page No 264,265

questions.text: Calculate the Silverman Anderson score in a preterm newborn who has audible grunting, marked chest and xiphoid retractions, and see-saw movements but No nasal flaring.
questions.solution:
The Silverman-Anderson score of the child is 8 - option 2.
 
Findings with the score:
 
Audible grunt - 2
Nasal flare - 0
See-saw upper chest movement - 2
Xiphoid recessions-2
Lower chest retractions-2

Total = 2+0+2+2+2= 8.
 
The preterm newborn's respiratory distress is measured by a score called the Silverman-Anderson score. Five features are observed for the index case, and each is given a score of 0, 1, or 2. An increase in the score represents a higher respiratory distress.



INTERPRETATION OF SILVERMAN ANDERSON SCORE
  • 0 → No respiratory distress
  • 1–3 → Mild distress - Give oxygen
  • 4–6 → Moderate distress - Give CPAP
  • 7–10 → Severe respiratory distress - Intubate and Mechanical ventilation

Reference- https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC10313036/

questions.text: The following is the preferred treatment option for a 4-day-old baby with bilirubin of 8 mg/dL:
questions.solution:
• The recommended course of treatment for a newborn who is 4 days old and has bilirubin of 8 mg/dL is to continue breastfeeding and receive phototherapy.
  • In contrast to breast feeding jaundice, breast milk jaundice is a distinct condition that results in chronically high indirect bilirubin levels in flourishing, healthy infants.
  • Breast feeding must be done as breast milk is essential for nutrition of the fetus and it doesn't aggravate the condition. 
  • These levels often start to fall in the second to third week of life. Infants with severe or persistent jaundice should be examined for issues such hemolysis, hypothyroidism, galactosemia, and a urinary tract infection.





Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page No 169-172

questions.text: What does APGAR stand for?
questions.solution:
Apgar score assesses appearance, pulse, grimace, activity, and respiration.

APGAR score:
• Helpful clinical tool for determining which newborns need resuscitation and evaluating the success of any such efforts.
• Useful technique for quickly and thoroughly evaluating newborn newborns.
• Fetal distress, premature birth, and medicines given to the mother during labour may all contribute to a poor score.
• 1-minute Apgar score: Indicates that emergency resuscitation is required.
• The 5-minute score, in particular the difference between the 1- and 5-minute scores, is a useful indicator of the success of resuscitative measures.
• The 5-minute Apgar score also has predictive importance for newborn survival since neonatal status in the delivery room is directly associated with survival.





Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page No 127

questions.text: What does APGAR stand for?
questions.solution:
Apgar score assesses appearance, pulse, grimace, activity, and respiration.

APGAR score:
• Helpful clinical tool for determining which newborns need resuscitation and evaluating the success of any such efforts.

• The 5-minute score, in particular the difference between the 1- and 5-minute scores, is a useful indicator of the success of resuscitative measures.
• The 5-minute Apgar score also has predictive importance for newborn survival since neonatal status in the delivery room is directly associated with survival.



Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page No 127

questions.text: Which of the following will increase the likelihood that a newborn has RDS?
questions.solution:
• An air bronchogram on the chest X-ray of a newborn is a sign of Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS).
  • RDS is a breathing disorder seen in premature newborns that is caused by lack of surfactant, that helps keep the air sacs in the lungs from collapsing.
  • The air bronchogram appears on the X-ray as light-colored streaks of air within the areas of the lungs where there would normally be lungs tissue.
  • Air bronchograms indicate that the affected lung tissue is collapsed and not providing adequate gas exchange for the newborn.
  • Treatment for RDS includes supplemental surfactant, oxygen and other supportive therapies.


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page No 165,166

choices.text: IV Antibiotics and Removal of necrosed portion of Intestine

questions.text: What is the treatment for a neonate who has Bell's stage 1 necrotizing disease and is stable?
questions.solution:
Conservative management is done in Bell's stage 1. 




Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 951

questions.text: A newborn was diagnosed with hepatomegaly during a routine checkup soon after birth. The remainder of the exam was largely ordinary. Investigations revealed that anti-HCMV antibodies were present. What long-term consequences could the youngster face?
questions.solution:
• Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) antibodies that are positive at birth are indicative of congenital infection with CMV that is not symptomatic.
  • The risk of mental retardation is higher in children who have symptoms of CMV infection, while the chance of sensorineural hearing loss is higher in asymptomatic children—up to 7%.


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page No 264,265

questions.text:
A newborn who was 6 days old and 2800 gm at birth was brought in with complaints of fever, poor feeding, and ineffective activity. Both vomiting and diarrhea are absent. The child has a 39°C axillary temperature, sunken eyes, a depressed fontanelle, decreased urine output, and decreased skin turgor. Her mother also has a history of producing less milk and giving top feeds.
What is the likely cause for the above?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Neonatal sepsis
 
A LBW newborn, with poor breast feeding history and fever without the presence of diarrhoea or vomiting points towards late onset Neonatal sepsis.

Some points about Neonatal sepsis
  • Causative organism – klebisiella > staph aureus
  • 2nd most common cause of neonatal mortality after prematurity.
  • Diagnosis is made by presence of clinical features of sepsis along with bacteremia in 1st month of life.
  • Sepsis occouring within 72 hours of birth is transmitted from the mother’s birth canal during birth and leads to early onset pneumonia.
  • Late onset sepsis is defined as onset 72 hours after birth. It is hospital acquired due to negligence in maintaining cleanliness. Seen more frequently in LBW and preterm babies or those who are not breastfed. It mostly manifests as Septicemia or meningitis.
  • Treatment should be started immediately after taking blood samples for culture and testing. A combination of Ampicillin (gram+) + Amikacin (gram-) is given.
  • Other antibiotics like cephalosporins, cloxacillin and vancomycin are added if no response is observed.   

  Sepsis screen : 5 components are included
 




Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page No 160-162

questions.text: A neonate who had hypoplasia in all of his limbs and cicatrizing skin lesions all over his body presents to you. Brain MRI results showed generalised cerebral atrophy. Which of these has the highest likelihood of being positive?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option (3) Anti-VZV antibody

Congenital varicella infection should be suspected based on the clinical picture given in the question-  cicatrizing skin lesions and presence of limb hypoplasia along with cerebral atrophy. This infection can be identified using anti-VZV(Varicella zoster virus) antibodies.

Other options

Option 1 - Anti- HCMV would be positive in congenital CMV infection. Congenital CMV infection presents with jaundice, Hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rash along with chorioretinitis, microcephaly and periventricular calcifications.
Option 2 - Congenital Toxoplasmosis has chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus and diffuse calcification
Option 4 - Congenital Rubella has a triad of PDA/Sensory neural hearing loss and cataract. 
 


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page No 210,211

questions.text: What degree of temperature should be provided for newborns in the delivery room (delivery room temperature)?
questions.solution:
• Each birth and resuscitation room's ventilation system must be built to regulate the surrounding temperature between 25 and 28 degrees Celsius during delivery, resuscitation, and stabilization of a baby.
  • A delivery room temperature of 25 to 28 degrees Celsius is advised by the WHO - it provides an optimal temperature for resuscitation, temperature of 37 C is very high and would instead result in hyperthermia for neonate. 
     

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page No 134

choices.text: Square root of height in feet by weight in grams
Weight in grams by cube of height in centimetres multiplied by 100
Mid-upper arm circumference to head circumference ratio

questions.text: What is Ponderal index?
questions.solution:
• Ponderal Index is calculated by first multiplying the weight (in grams) by 100, then divide by the cube of the length in cm.
  • Ponderal Index is more than 2 in Symmetric IUGR, Ponderal index is less than 2 in asymmetric IUGR. 


 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21st Page No 1048

questions.text: What is the ideal route of drug delivery in neonatal resuscitation?
questions.solution:
• For medications, the umbilical vein is used, for the drug to reach the foetus.
  • Since veins in the scalp or extremities are difficult to access during resuscitation, the umbilical vein is the preferred route.

No intracardiac injection is recommended.



Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page No 133

choices.text: Observe only, as it is likely physiological jaundice
Liver function tests and liver biopsy to evaluate for cholestasis

questions.text: A neonate develops jaundice on the first day of life. The mother’s blood group is O negative. What is the most appropriate management for this baby?
questions.solution:
• In term newborns, jaundice that appears after 24 hours or doesnt last longer than 14 days is referred to as physiological jaundice.
  • However in the given question - the child develops jaundice on the first day of life itself suggesting jaundice is pathological in nature.
  • The most common cause of jaundice on the first day of life are hemolytic diseases or congenital infections
  • Considering the mother's blood group is O negative - its likely child might have Rh isoimmunisation/ABO incompatibility leading to jaundice and hence, phototherapy is required for the treatment of jaundice.

Other options

Option 1 - Physiological jaundice does not appear on day 1. It usually starts after 24 hours, peaks around day 5, and resolves within 2 weeks in term infants. Jaundice on day 1 is pathological. 

Option 2 - Double Volume Exchange transfusion i.e DVET (not partial exchange) is used in cases of severe hyperbilirubinemia not responsive to phototherapy, or when bilirubin is very high (more than DVET Cutoff) at presentation. In a newborn with early hemolysis, the first-line treatment is phototherapy, not exchange transfusion. 

Option 3 - Cholestasis tends to present later, usually after the first 2 weeks of life, with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia (with child having high coloured urine and pale stools). On day 1, with an O negative mother, the clinical picture is of hemolysis, not cholestasis.



Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page No 169-172

choices.text: Inj. betamethasone 12 mg for 2 doses 12 hours apart
Inj. betamethasone 12 mg for 2 doses 24 hours apart
Inj. dexamethasone 6 mg for 4 doses 24 hours apart
Inj. dexamethasone 12 mg for 2 doses 12 hours apart

questions.text: Select the recommended dose of steroids for attaining fetal lung maturity.
questions.solution:
Inj Betamethasone 12 mg for 2 doses 24 hours apart must be delivered to achieve lung maturity.

Benefits:

  • 50% reduction in the incidence of respiratory distress syndrome
  • 50% reduction in the Incidence of intraventricular haemorrhage (IVH)
  • 40% reduction in mortality
Steroid dosage Memorizing Trick-
Dexamethasone- Dexa similar to Hexa- 6- 6 mg every 12 hours 4 injections
Betamethasone- B- 2nd letter of albhabet- 2 dosage twice the dose of Dexa and gap- 12 mg 2 injections 24 hours apart


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page No 166

choices.text: Start total enteral feeding and IV feeding not required
Start IV feeding with minimal enteral feeding
Start IV feeding and introduce feeding on 2nd day of life
Start parenteral feeding and institute oral feeding on 2nd day of life

questions.text: A primigravida gives birth to a 1410 gram neonate at 32 weeks. The infant's vital were stable, and resuscitation was not required at birth. The infant was moved to the NICU for care. How can we manage the infant's feeding?
questions.solution:
A 32 week preterm infant, weighing 1400 gm, with stable vitals admitted in NICU should be kept on total enteral nutrition. IV fluids/nutrition is not required. 





Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page No 156

questions.text: A mother with eclampsia who received IV magnesium sulphate gave birth to a baby at 32 weeks. The infant was revived and taken to the NICU. Twelve hours later, the infant displayed hypotonia, sluggishness, constricted pupils, and two seizures. Identify the stage of HIE?
questions.solution:
The presence of hypotonia, constricted pupils, and seizures indicates HIE stage 2.  In HIE Stage II - there is parasympatetic overactivity - this leads to bradycardia, miosis (constricted pupils) , low tone and lethargy/depressed reflexes in the neonate. 
Seizures are known to occur only in stage II HIE, they donot occur either in stage I or stage III HIE. 




 Reference-Nelson textbook of Pediatrics 21st edition Page no 918, Table- 120.7

questions.text: What does Moro's asymmetric reflex at birth indicate?
questions.solution:
• Moro's asymmetric reflex at birth may indicate Erb's palsy.
  • This condition can occur when there is damage to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus, often resulting from birth trauma, leading to asymmetric arm movement during the Moro reflex.
  • Asymmetric Moro's reflex could also be seen in case of - 1. Congenital hemiplegia 2. Erb's palsy 3. Fracture clavicle 4. Shoulder dislocation 
 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3059

questions.text: What is the most common fungal infection transmitted by health caregivers' hands to neonates among the given options?
questions.solution:
• Candida parapsilosis is an emerging major human pathogen that has dramatically increased in significance and prevalence over the past 2 decades, such that C. parapsilosis is now one of the leading causes of invasive candidal disease in neonates (most common non-albicans cause of invasive candidiasis)
  • Multiple studies suggest C. parapsilosis is primarily a nosocomial pathogen/associated with the colonization of healthcare workers' hands while C. albicans is acquired from the maternal genital tract. 
  • C.parapsilosis infections are also especially associated with TPN and its preparation


Reference: Cloherty and Stark's Manual of Neonatal Care South Asian Edition 2021 Print Page 733/734

questions.text: What is the most common cause of neonatal sepsis ?
questions.solution:
1. In India, unlike the Western/developed world - the most common cause of neonatal sepsis are gram-negative bacilli-like Kleibsella/Acinetobacter/E.Coli etc. 
2. In India - most common cause of neonatal sepsis is Acinetobacter as per AIIMS NICU Protocols. Other Indian textbooks give Kleibsella as the most common cause.
3. In western world - most common cause is gram positive organisms - GBS (Group B streptococcus)
 
  • Since the question was asked in AIIMS/INICET - best answer is option 3 (Acenitobacter)
  • If the question was asked in NEET - Kleibsella is a better answer. 
  • If the question had asked - most common cause in the world or developed nations - then the answer is Group B Streptococcus. 

Answer has been confirmed by Professors of NICU/Pediatrics at AIIMS, Delhi. Answer might be given wrong in other Qbanks which do not have inside AIIMS information. Please mark Acenitobacter if asked in INICET. 

#controversial

Reference - AIIMS NICU Protocols 3rd edition, Chapter - Neonatal Sepsis, pg 254

questions.text: GTCS develops in a premature newborn aged 2 days. What investigation should be conducted to diagnose the pathology?
questions.solution:
• A 2 days old premature neonate develops GTCS.The investigations done to diagnose the pathology is Transcranial ultrasound.
  • The major imaging technique for premature neonates is cranial ultrasonography, which is also ideal for studying newborns in general.
  • It is carried out at the patient's bedside and offers accurate measurement of the size of the ventricles and other fluid-containing lesions, as well as accurate observation of hemorrhagic and ischemic lesions and their development.
  • Transcranial USG could be done in neonates due to the presence of fontanelles. 
 

Reference: AIIMS NICU Protocols 2 nd Edition page no 78

choices.text: A baby born at 28 weeks of gestation

questions.text: A Pediatrician in a district hospital with a specialized neonatal care unit will consult with an ophthalmologist for which of the following newborns?
questions.solution:
• A pediatrician in a district hospital's specialized neonatal care unit will call an ophthalmologist for consultation for a baby born at 28 weeks of gestation in order to screen for retinopathy of prematurity.
  • Other newborns don't require screening for ROP/Ophthalmologist consult.
  • Retinopathy of prematurity occurs when premature newborns (32 weeks or less 1.5 kg) are exposed to high oxygen concentrations during their first 10 days of life, bilateral proliferative retinopathy can develop.
  • Screening/Prophylaxis Between 32 and 36 weeks post-conception, all infants with birth weights or gestational ages 1500 gm or 32 weeks should undergo an indirect ophthalmoscopy screening.
  • Infants who are premature shouldn't be kept in incubators with oxygen concentrations higher than 30%. Babies born prematurely should be screened at 1, 3, and 6 months old, as well as every 4 months up to 4 years old.
 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3377-3379

questions.text: On the first day, a baby starts frothing at the mouth with choking on feeding. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
• Esophageal atresia is the most probable diagnosis of a newborn with frothing from the mouth and choking present on day one of life.
  • Esophageal atresia is a pathology in which a baby's esophagus is not fully developed.
  • Esophageal atresia: When a baby spits up excessively and coughs or chokes during the first oral feeding, the diagnosis of esophageal atresia is considered.


 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 1929

questions.text: In India, neonatal sepsis is most likely to be caused by:
questions.solution:
• In India, unlike the Western/developed world - the most common cause of neonatal sepsis are gram-negative bacilli-like Kleibsella/Acinetobacter/E.Coli etc. 
  • In India - most common cause of neonatal sepsis is Acinetobacter as per AIIMS NICU Protocols. Other textbooks give Kleibsella as the most common cause. In western world - most common cause is GBS(Group B streptococcus)
  • Since the question was asked in AIIMS/INICET - better answer is option 1(Acenitobacter)

choices.text: Not able to go up and down stairs at 5 years of age
Not able to say 2 words phrase at 12 months of age

questions.text: All of the following are considered development delay except:
questions.solution:
Correct answer is option (4) - Not able to say 2 words phrase at 12 months of age

The ability to use two-word phrases develops at 24 months of age. At 12 months, a child is only expected to say one or two single words with meaning, such as “mama” or “dada.” Thus, not being able to form two-word phrases at 12 months is perfectly normal and cannot be considered a delay.

Other options


Option 1 -  Immature pincer grasp normally appears at 9 months. Failure to demonstrate that 12 months would mean fine motor delay.
 
Option 2 - Independent sitting is achieved by 8 months, and if a child is still unable to sit at 10 months, that means gross motor delay.

Option 3 - Children is able to go up and down stairs by 2 years of age. Inability to do so at 5 years indicates a delay in gross motor development. 

 

Reference - Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 44,46,48,49,50

questions.text: What among the following cannot be used to revive a newborn baby whose heart rate is less than 60 beats per minute?
questions.solution:
• Correct Option is 4: Slapping the back
  • According to the Neonatal Resuscitation Protocol, flicking the soles is done after the initial assessment of term, tone, and cry if the baby does not cry immediately. Slapping the back is NOT recommended.
  • If in term infants there are no improvements or the HR is <100 beats/min after stimulation, positive pressure ventilation using a bag and mask is provided.
  • If there is still no rise in HR, corrective ventilatory efforts MRSOPA should be taken.
  • If the HR falls below 60 in spite of corrective steps then the patient is intubated and given chest compressions, and 100% Oxygen. If the patient still doesn’t respond, IV epinephrine is given.



 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 126-133

questions.text: Which of the following accounts for the majority of ophthalmia neonatorum cases resulting in blindness
questions.solution:
• While Chlamydia is the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatorum, Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatorum that results in blindness! (hence option 1 is correct, not option 2).
