questions.text: What is the next step in management for a full-term baby with a birth weight of 2700g and on day 5 of life has bilirubin of 9-10 mg/dl.
questions.solution:
The correct option is option (3) -Normal newborn care.

In term neonates, physiologic jaundice typically peaks between day 3–5, with bilirubin levels around 10–12 mg/dL (can go up to 15 mg/dL in some cases). This infant’s bilirubin (9–10 mg/dL) is within the normal physiological range and no risk factors (prematurity, hemolysis, sepsis, cholestasis) are mentioned in the question. 

Hence, this serum bilirubin level is normal and indicates that the neonate has a physiological form of jaundice, which is expected in newborns. This child does not require any intervention and normal newborn care (option 3) should be continued. 

According to AAP, below are the Phototherapy/DVET cutoff values for bilirubin- above which PT/DVET should be given

Child's Bilirubin( 9-10mg/dL) is well below the cutoffs and hence, child does not require any Phototherapy (option 2) or Double volume exchange transfusion (option 1)
 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 168-172

questions.text: What is the name of the pigment causing Greenish-black color in thick stool passed by neonate after delivery?

questions.text: After initial steps in neonatal resuscitation, if H.R. < 100 which of the following is NOT done?
questions.solution:
According to NRP, after the initial steps of resuscitation, if a child is apneic or gasping or having HR<100 - Immediately start PPV(option 3), attach SpO2 monitor(option 2) and attach cardiac monitor(ECG) (option 4)

CPAP (option 1) can be considered in case of respiratory distress(laboured breathing or cyanosis) if HR>100, not when HR<100. Its not done when the neonates' HR<100.

questions.text: What is the most typical reason for bladder outlet obstruction in young male children?
questions.solution:
• The most common cause of Bladder Outlet Obstruction (BOO) in a male child is posterior urethral valve.
  • Posterior urethral valve is the most severe form of obstructive uropathy.
  • Usually affects boys & often presents in the post - natal period.

Clinical features—

—Post micturition dribbling.

—Increased frequency of micturition. 

—Frequent UTI’s.

—Hydronephrosis due to urinary pathway obstruction and uraemia .

Key hole sign seen. (PYQ)

questions.text: Bilirubin is transformed during phototherapy into:
questions.solution:
Bilirubin is converted to lumirubin by phototherapy. 

The mechanisms involved in phototherapy are- 

1. Irreversible structural isomerization- It involves formation of lumirubin from bilirubin which is excreted via kidneys. This is the most important mechanism.

2. Reversible photo-isomerization

3. Photo-oxidation

questions.text:
Which of the following can lead to seizures in newborns?
(i) Hyponatremia
(ii) Hypernatremia
(iii) Hypocalcemia
(iv) Hypomagnesemia
questions.solution:

  • They are medical emergencies because they signal a disease process that may produce irreversible brain damage.
  • A seizure is a paroxysmal behaviour caused by hyper - synchronous discharge of a group of neurons.

They can be Subtle, Tonic, Clonic, Myoclonic.
Metabolic Causes—Hypoglycemia, Hypocalcemia, Hypomagnesemia, Hyponatremia, Hypernatremia.

Memorizing Trick- All Hypo cause neonatal seizures

questions.text: A newborn displays all of the following thermogenic mechanisms when exposed to cold, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
• Neonates lack shivering mechanism.
  • Due to their high surface area-to-volume ratio, infants tend to lose more heat to the environment as compared to adults.
  • In addition, human newborns lack sufficiently developed skeletal muscle mass to maintain body temperature through shivering thermogenesis, an important source of heat in cold-exposed adults.

questions.text: What is the correct order of suctioning during neonatal resuscitation?
questions.solution:
•  If a newborn baby is born prematurely, isn't breathing, and does not have good tone, resuscitation is necessary.
  • After the umbilical cord is cut, the initial resuscitation steps should be taken, which include providing warmth by placing the baby under a radiant warmer, positioning them with their neck slightly extended with the help of a shoulder roll, clearing their airway by suctioning their mouth and nose, ensuring they are dry, and stimulating them.
  • Mouth is suctioned before nose as chances of aspiration from mouth is more common than nose. 
     

Trick to remember- Alphabetically M is followed by N. So Mouth followed by Nose.

questions.text: A Pre-term 32 weeks new-born baby with respiratory rate of 86/min with presence of grunting. On examination there was no nasal flaring, abdomen behind in movement than chest, minimal intercostal retraction and no xiphisternal retraction. The Silverman scoring for the neonate shall be:
questions.solution:
The Silverman scoring for the neonate shall be 4

Silverman - Anderson score

presence of grunting (2)
no nasal flaring (0)
abdomen behind in movement than chest (1)
no xiphisternal retraction (0)
minimal intercostal retraction (1)

Total becomes: 2+0+1+0+1 = 4




Reference- https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC10313036/

questions.text: Which of the following has no shunt reversal during the disease's normal course?
questions.solution:
The correct option is 3.TOF (Tetralogy of Fallot).

TOF is a cyanotic congenital heart disease characterized by four anatomical abnormalities:
1. Sub-pulmonic Stenosis
2. Right ventricular hypertrophy
3. Large unrestrictive VSD
4. Overriding of Aorta

The primary direction of blood flow in TOF is from right to left  due to the pulmonary stenosis (leading to R->L Shunt via the large VSD). This R->L Shunt leads to mixing of deoxygenated blood with oxygenated blood causing cyanosis. This will NOT reverse unless there's an intervention like surgery to relieve the stenosis. However, this is not part of the "normal course" of the disease but rather a result of treatment. 

In other options(ASD/VSD Or PDA - all are acynotic CHD) -normally there is L->R shunt but shunt reversal can happen which is called Eisenmenger syndrome. 

Hence, the only disease without shunt reversal is TOF.
 

Reference- Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 417-419

questions.text: A preterm infant with poor respiration at birth starts having seizures 10 hours after birth. What should be the epilepsy medication of choice?
questions.solution:
Anti-epileptic of choice in this case shall be phenobarbitone.

Phenobarbital is drug of choice in case of neonatal seizures.
Loading dose: 20 mg/Kg
If this dose is not effective, then additional doses of 5-10 mg/kg can be given until a dose of 40 mg/ kg is reached.
After 24 hours of loading dose, maintenance dosing can be started at 3-6 mg/Kg/day, usually administered in two separate doses.


 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 922

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about respiratory distress syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Correct statement about respiratory distress syndrome is option(4) air bronchograms seen on X-ray chest
  • In respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), the classic chest radiographic findings consist of pronounced hypo aeration, bilateral fine granular opacities in the pulmonary parenchyma, and peripherally extending air bronchograms.
  • It can be seen immediately post-birth, Antenatal steroid use is known to prevent it and typically occurs in preterm pregnancy. 

 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 164-167

questions.text: Which of the following situations makes it beneficial to utilize PGE1 right away after birth?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: TAPVC
 

In the context of Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC), PGE1 (Prostaglandin E1) plays a critical role in the management of newborns with certain types of this congenital heart defect.

Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC):

TAPVC is a rare congenital heart defect where all four pulmonary veins do not connect normally to the left atrium. Instead, they connect abnormally to the right atrium or other nearby veins. This results in a mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood, leading to significant cardiovascular compromise.

Role of PGE1:

  1. Ductal-Dependent Circulation:

    • In some forms of TAPVC, particularly those where the pulmonary veins connect to systemic veins or the right atrium, there may be obstruction or severe restriction of pulmonary venous return to the left heart.
    • Newborns with this type of TAPVC may be dependent on a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) for adequate pulmonary blood flow.

  2. Maintaining Ductal Patency:

    • PGE1 is a potent vasodilator that acts to maintain patency (openness) of the ductus arteriosus. This is crucial in neonates with TAPVC who have obstructed pulmonary venous return, as it helps to ensure adequate pulmonary blood flow until definitive surgical repair can be performed.

  3. Preoperative Stabilization:

    • PGE1 is often initiated in newborns suspected or diagnosed with obstructive TAPVC to stabilize their condition and optimize oxygenation while preparations are made for corrective surgery.

  4. Diagnostic Aid:

    • PGE1 infusion can sometimes be used diagnostically in suspected cases of obstructive TAPVC. If there is improvement in oxygenation and hemodynamics with PGE1, it may suggest ductal dependence


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 423,424

questions.text: Which of these is a cyanotic heart disease with increased pulmonary blood flow?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Transposition of great arteries [TGA]

In TGA the aorta arises from the right ventricle and pulmonary artery from the left ventricle.

Desaturated blood returning from the body to the right side of the heart goes inappropriately out the aorta and back into the body again, whereas oxygenated pulmonary venous blood returning to left side of heart is returned directly to the lungs. Thus systemic and pulmonary circulations act as two parallel circuits.

The left ventricle is larger and contacts with more pressure which leads to increased pulmonary blood flow.









Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 421-423

questions.text: What does early closure of coronal suture lead to?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Brachycephaly

Premature fusion of skull sutures is defined as CRANIOSYNOSTOSIS.
When skull suture fuses the skull also expands along that same direction.

questions.text: What is this condition shown in the image?

Correct Option is 1: Omphalocele

THE FOLLOWING TABLE IS TO CONSOLIDATE  A VERY IMPORTANT TOPIC OF VENTRAL WALL DEFECTS FREQUENTLY ASKED :-

Caudal Fold Closure – BLADDER EXTROPHY

CONGENITAL UMBILICAL HERNIA :-

  • Associated with congenital disorders like Down Syndrome, Congenital Hypothyroidism

questions.text: For the prognosis of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH), which of the following is the most important determinant?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Pulmonary Hypertension 

CONGENITAL DIAPHRAGMATIC HERNIA :-
  • They are of 2 types :- BOCHDALEK, MORGAGNI
  • FEATURES :-

-Pulmonary Hypoplasia
-Mediastinal shift
-In severe cases :- Increased risk of birth asphyxia
 
  •  MANAGEMENT :-
-Birth Asphyxia – Start resuscitation ( Avoid bag and mask ventilation )
-First 48 hours – Nasogastric tube to decompress intestine; Mechanical ventilation to expand lungs
-After 48 hours – Surgery
 
  • BAD PROGNOSTIC FACTORS :-
-Pulmonary hypertension
-Liver found in hernia sac in USG
-Early onset respiratory distress after birth


[TRICK TO REMEMBER :-
*BOCHDALEK – Posterior Left ---à BPL
*MORGAGNI – Anterior Right ]

questions.text: In congenital diaphragmatic hernia, which of the following is the least important prognostic factor?
questions.solution:

  • Pulmonary Hypertension – Most important prognostic factor
  • Early age at antenatal diagnosis / Gestational age at diagnosis
  • Herniation of the stomach or liver à This depends on the size of the defect
  • Low Apgar scores
  • Severe respiratory distress
  • Severe hypoxemia

questions.text: Which of the following represents the best management option in a case where a neonate delivered at 38 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 2.2 kg develops intolerance to feed/abdominal distension second day. Physical examination is unremarkable. Sepsis screen is negative. PCV is observed to be 72%?
questions.solution:
• Correct Option is 2: Partial Exchange Transfusion 
  • The given clinical vignette describes the clinical condition called Neonatal Polycythaemia.
  • PCV values of more than 65% indicate Polycythaemia in neonates.
  • Neonatal polycythaemia can be associated with Post-term babies/SGA babies/hypertensive or diabetic mothers/Twin–twin transfusion syndrome (the recipient infant)
  • MANAGEMENT: Symptomatic and/or PCV >75% - Partial Exchange Transfusion, if asymptomatic or PCV<75%  -Fluids/Hydration. 
  • In the clinical stem - the child is symptomatic - so best treatment is PET(Partial Exchange Transfusion).

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 971

  •  SpO2 = 60%-65% at 1 min

questions.text: Which autoantibodies in the mother are associated with complete heart block in newborn lupus?

A FEW IMPORTANT POINTS ABOUT SLE – (FREQUENTLY TESTED ):-

-Serositis – Pleuritis, pericarditis

-Antinuclear antibodies
-Immunologic disorders
-Neurologic disorders
 
  • ASSOCIATIONS :-
-LIBMAN SACKS ENDOCARDITIS
-LUPUS NEPHRITIS – IgA, IgG, IgM C1qC3 gets deposited; subepithelial and subendothelial deposits are found; FULL HOUSE EFFECT ( IMP BUZZWORD )
 
  • ANTIBODIES :-
-ANTI SSA/ANTI Ro ANTIBODY in a pregnant femaleà They have increased risk of giving birth to newborns with congenital heart blocks ( NEONATAL LUPUS )

questions.text: You are called to a new born baby's house to look at the baby, you notice CTEV, At what age will you advice the baby's parents to get the cast correction for CTEV?

questions.text: Best alternative to mother's breast milk in a low birth weight baby?
questions.solution:
The best alternative to a mother's breast milk in a low Birth Weight baby is human donor breast milk.

All LBW babies should only receive breast milk from the mother or human donor irrespective of the mode of feeding.

questions.text: Which of the following is the Best indicator for the adequacy of ventilation as per NRP?
questions.solution:
• The best indicator for the adequacy of ventilation in neonatal resuscitation, according to the Neonatal Resuscitation Program (NRP) guidelines, is the improvement in heart rate (HR).
  • During neonatal resuscitation, the primary goal is to establish effective ventilation and support the baby's oxygenation. While all the options provided can be important signs of adequate ventilation, the improvement in heart rate is the most reliable and crucial indicator of successful ventilation.

When effective ventilation is achieved, the baby's heart rate should increase or improve.


 Reference: Essential Pediatrics by O.P Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 130,131 .

questions.text: A 2-month old presents with swelling over his head since birth. The following X-Ray was taken. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A unilateral fluid collection bounded by suture lines of the skull with evidence of peripheral calcification is seen.
This is most likely a Cephalhematoma:
  • Cephalohematoma is a collection of blood in between the pericranium and the flat bone (subperiosteal) of the skull, usually unilateral and over a parietal bone.
  • It is never present at birth but gradually develops after 12-24 h.
  • The swelling is limited by the suture lines of the skull as the pericranium is fixed to the margins of the bone.
Reference: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th Edition, Page No 452.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about Congenital CMV?
questions.solution:
• CMV is the most common Congenital infection after congenital Syphillis.
  • Clinical manifestation include Microcephaly, Petechial rash, Jaundice, Chorioretinitis.
  • Imaging shows Intracranial periventricular calcification
  • Long term Sequelae include SNHL.(Most common cause of non syndromic SNHL.
  • Diagnosis is done by PCR/Viral culture within first three weeks of life with saliva/blood/urine. No definitive treatment.
  • Gancyclovir is indicated in symptomatic patients- patient with neurological/systemic disease and/or deafness. Asymptomatic infants don't require treatment but close audiological followup is necessary due to the risk of SNHL later in life. 

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21th Edition, Page. No- 1720.

questions.text: 2m old child came with history of fever, irritability and neck stiffness. Child was diagnosed as Meningitis. The mother gives history of painful genital ulcers around 1 month back which resolved spontaneously. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an 18 month old child presenting with fever, irritability, next stiffness and positive kernel sign with the mother giving a past history of painful genital ulcers, is suggestive of neonatal herpes due to herpes simplex virus.
CMV, HPV and varicella zoster virus do not present with painful genital ulcers and can be easily rule out.
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of meningitis and in the background of mother with history of painful Genital ulcers, suggestive of Neonatal herpes mostly due to Herpes Simplex virus -2.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21th Edition, Page. No- 1705, 3567.

questions.text: Which of the following is criteria for Perinatal Asphyxia?
questions.solution:
Criteria for Perinatal Asphyxia -
  • Neonatal Multi organ Dysfunction
  • Neurological manifestations such as coma, lethargy, hypotonia, seizures, HIE in immediate neonatal period.
  • APGAR score 0-3 for more than 5 min
  • Umbilical cord arterial Ph <7.0.
Reference: Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 9th Edition, Page. No- 163.

questions.text: A term Neonate was found to be in Respiratory distress, tachypnoea and scaphoid abdomen. Neonate was diagnosed with Congenital Diaphragmatic hernia. Which of the following is avoided in resuscitation of the baby?
questions.solution:
Bag and mask ventilation is contraindicated in Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia as it may increase abdominal distension and reduce expansion of lungs
MC type of CDH- Bochdalek hernia and is usually on left side.
Two complication- Pulmonary Hypoplasia and Hypertension.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th Edition, Page. No- 863.

questions.text: A 7-day-old neonate is brought with failure to pass meconium since birth. The baby's abdomen is markedly distended and he aspirates on feeding. Rectal suction biopsy shows a lot of hypertrophied nerve bundles with increased acetylcholinesterase staining and aganglionosis. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Presentation: Neonate with failure to pass meconium, abdominal distension, and vomiting/aspiration.

  • Rectal suction biopsy findings:

    • Aganglionosis (absence of ganglion cells)

    • Hypertrophied nerve bundles

    • Increased acetylcholinesterase staining → classic for Hirschsprung's disease

  • Pathophysiology: Lack of enteric ganglion cells in the distal colon → functional obstruction → proximal bowel dilatation.

Differentiation:

  • Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Presents 2–8 weeks after birth with projectile non-bilious vomiting, not failure to pass meconium.

  • Wilkie syndrome (SMA syndrome): Rare, usually older children or adults, presents with duodenal obstruction.

  • Functional constipation: No biopsy abnormalities; ganglion cells are present.

questions.text: A newborn at birth was noticed to have a mass in the abdomen, as shown in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Omphalocele is a midline abdominal defect characterized by the presence of abdominal contents covered by a peritoneal or umbilical sac. Infants born with omphalocele should be thoroughly evaluated for associated congenital anomalies, including cardiac defects, neural tube defects, and trisomies.

Management typically involves the following steps: administering intravenous fluids and antibiotics, preserving the sac with sterile saline gauze or a bowel bag, and ultimately performing surgical closure.
 

Key points to differentiate:

  • Omphalocele:

    • Midline defect at the base of the umbilical cord

    • Abdominal contents herniate into a sac

    • Often associated with other congenital anomalies (cardiac, chromosomal)

  • Gastroschisis:

    • Paraumbilical defect (usually right side)

    • No covering sac; intestines exposed to amniotic fluid

    • Less associated with other anomalies

  • Umbilical hernia:

    • Usually covered by skin, reducible, small, appears after birth

  • Ectopia cordis:

    • Heart protrudes through the chest wall, not abdominal contents

Hence, the most probable diagnosis for a midline abdominal mass at birth covered by a sac is omphalocele.

questions.text: An infant is brought to the OPD with a swelling which developed after around 15 hours after birth. The clinical image is given below. What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The swelling appears 15 hours after birth and is limited to one cranial bone, suggesting cephalhematoma.

Key points:

  • Cephalhematoma:

    • Subperiosteal hemorrhage; does not cross suture lines.

    • Usually develops within 24–48 hours after birth.

    • Risk factors: instrumental delivery, prolonged labor.

    • Typically resolves spontaneously over weeks.

  • Caput succedaneum:

    • Edematous swelling of the scalp, crosses suture lines.

    • Present immediately at birth, soft, pitting.

  • Encephalocele:

    • Congenital defect, usually present at birth.

  • Subgaleal hematoma:

    • Bleeding beneath the galea aponeurotica, can cross sutures.

    • Usually appears within hours, associated with significant blood loss and shock.

choices.text: Self inflating O2 bag kept over baby's Mouth
Reservoir Bag with O2 attached kept over Baby's mouth and nose
O2 mask kept over babys mouth and nose
Oxygen tube kept close to Babys mouth and nose

questions.text: Which of the following methods of Oxygen delivery to newborn Baby is not suitable?
questions.solution:
• Self inflating bags are not used for Free flow oxygen delivery.
  • They are used to provide positive pressure ventilation. Hence they are used in Neonatal Resuscitation.
Effective ventilation can be confirmed by 
  • Chest rise on Squeezing the bag
  • Capnography shows exhaled C02
  • Condensation in the clear mask
  • Pulse Oximeter shows improved saturation.

Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th Edition, Page No 1387.

questions.text: Downe's score includes all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Downe scoring is used to assess Respiratory distress. It does not include feeding.

questions.text: INSURE is associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
• INSURE stands for intubate-intratracheal surfactant administration-extubation and is performed in new borns with respiratory distress especially in preterm where surfactant production is reduced.
  • Indications include neonates who are not maintaining oxygen saturation >90% while breathing 40-70% FiO, in nasal CPAP (continuous positive airway pressure).
  • Extubation back to nasal CPAP is done immediately once the infant is stable, usually within minutes to <1 hr of surfactant administration.
Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th Edition, Page No 934.

questions.text: In a baby born with meconium-stained liquor, which of the following are recommended as per Neonatal Resuscitation guidelines?A. Intrapartum suction of nose and mouth before delivery of shoulderB. Intratracheal suction in case of nonvigorous babyC. Gentle suction of nose and mouth in case of vigorous babyD. PPV in case of non vigorous baby after early steps
questions.solution:
In the case of a baby born with meconium-stained amniotic fluid, management depends on the baby‘s condition at birth:

1. **Vigorous Baby:** If the baby is vigorous, meaning they have good breathing and normal muscle tone, gentle suction of the nose and mouth is performed. The baby can then be kept with the mother. Routine tracheal suctioning is not recommended in this scenario.

2. **Non-Vigorous Baby:** If the baby is non-vigorous, meaning they have poor or no breathing and decreased muscle tone, initial resuscitation steps are taken. If the baby does not respond to these steps, positive pressure ventilation (PPV) with a bag and mask is provided.


**Neonatal Resuscitation Guidelines:**

- **Heart Rate <100:** Provide PPV and monitor oxygen saturation (SpO2). Ensure adequate ventilation.
- **Heart Rate <60:** Initiate chest compressions over the lower third of the sternum at a rate of 90 compressions per minute. The recommended rate of ventilation is 30 inflations per minute. The ratio of compressions to ventilations should be 3:1.
- **Heart Rate Still <60:** If the heart rate remains below 60 despite effective compressions and ventilation, administer IV epinephrine.

Assess the baby‘s response to resuscitation based on heart rate and adjust interventions accordingly.


Reference : Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page no 925-927.

questions.text: According to the neonatal resuscitation protocol, below what heart rate are chest compressions initiated?
questions.solution:
In the neonatal resuscitation protocol, chest compressions are initiated when the heart rate falls below 60 beats per minute.

The response to resuscitation is evaluated by the heart rate:

Heart rate < 100 beats/min: Positive pressure ventilation (PPV) is provided using a bag and mask with room air, and SpO2 monitoring is started. Oxygen concentration can be increased based on the need to improve ventilation.
Heart rate < 60 beats/min: Chest compressions are initiated over the lower third of the sternum at a rate of 90 compressions per minute. The compression-to-ventilation ratio is 3:1.
If the heart rate remains <60 beats/min despite effective chest compressions and ventilation, intravenous epinephrine is administered.

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication for breastfeeding?
questions.solution:
Breastfeeding is strictly contraindicated in infants with galactosemia.

Classical galactosemia results from a complete deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase, leading to an accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate. Infants with this condition present with symptoms such as jaundice, hepatomegaly, vomiting, hypoglycemia, seizures, irritability, and feeding difficulties. Since breast milk contains galactose, it should not be given to these infants.

Contraindications to breastfeeding can be categorized as follows:

Absolute Contraindications to Breastfeeding:
Classical galactosemia
HTLV (Human T-cell lymphotropic virus) or Ebola infection
Maternal active illicit drug use
Relative Contraindications to Breastfeeding:
Maternal HIV: The risks of not breastfeeding may outweigh the risk of HIV transmission.
Hepatitis B: Breastfeeding can occur after the infant has received hepatitis B immunoglobulin and the vaccine.
Active herpes lesions: The mother can continue breastfeeding with the unaffected breast.
Tuberculosis in the mother: Breastfeeding should be delayed until two weeks of therapy have been completed.
Varicella infection: The infant should receive immune globulin and have no contact with active lesions.


Not Contraindications:
Alcohol consumption
Tobacco smoking
Hepatitis C infection

questions.text: How much percentage of oxygen is given to a term infant with respiratory distress during resuscitation?
questions.solution:
In term infants, resuscitation is typically performed using room air (21% oxygen).

Resuscitation Guidelines in Term Infants:
If the infant shows signs of apnea, gasping, or has a heart rate <100/min, positive pressure ventilation (PPV) should be administered using a bag-mask device with 21% oxygen (room air).
Using room air in term infants is effective and may reduce risks like hyperoxia, reduced cerebral blood flow, and free radical generation.
Ventilatory Adjustments:
If there is no improvement in 30 seconds, perform ventilatory corrective steps and adjust the oxygen concentration to achieve the expected oxygen saturation.
If the heart rate drops below 60/min, initiate chest compressions, intubate the infant, and increase the FIO2 to 100%.
Preterm Infant Resuscitation:
In preterm infants, resuscitation is initiated with an inspired oxygen fraction of 21-30%, which is then adjusted based on the infant's oxygen saturation.

questions.text: How long is exclusive breast feeding recommended for?
questions.solution: Breastfeeding should be started as soon as possible after birth. Breastfeeding should be started as soon as possible after birth. For an infant to be called exclusively breastfed, pre-lacteal feeds and even water are not to be given. Exclusive breastfeeding is recommended for 6 months. Complementary foods rich in iron and other micronutrients should be introduced at about 6 months of age. Ref: Nelson textbook of pediatrics 21st edition • Page no: 323

choices.text: Orogastric tube feeds plus occasional paladai feeds

questions.text: Which of the following methods would you employ for initial feeding in a neonate born at 29 weeks of gestation?
questions.solution:
For a newborn born at 29 weeks gestation, orogastric tube feedings should be the primary mode of feeding, supplemented sometimes with paladai feeds.
 

A neonate born at 29 weeks of gestation falls within the 28-31 weeks category, as per the feeding guidelines.

  • At this gestational age, propulsive gastric motility is present, sucking bursts develop, but coordination between sucking, swallowing, and breathing is still immature.
  • Primary feeding method: Orogastric (or nasogastric) tube feeding is the preferred choice since gastic motility is present but the baby cannot effectively suck and swallow
Neonates are fed differently according to their development level and gestational age



Reference:Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition - Page -126, 151, 155-157

choices.text: Infants born to an HbsAg positive mothe

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication for breastfeeding?
questions.solution:
Infants born to an HBsAg positive mother:
 

  • Not an absolute contraindication.

  • If the baby receives HBIG + Hepatitis B vaccine within 12 hours of birth, breastfeeding is safe.

    Alcoholic mother

  • Not absolute.

  • Occasional alcohol is discouraged but not an absolute reason to stop breastfeeding.

    Classic galactosemia in the infant

  • Absolute contraindication.

  • Galactose in breast milk can cause vomiting, diarrhea, hepatomegaly, cataracts, and even death in these infants.

  • Such infants require a galactose-free formula (soy-based formula).

    Mother with HIV infection

  • Depends on resources and guidelines:

    • In high-income countries where safe formula feeding is available → absolute contraindication.

    • In resource-limited settings (e.g., many LMICs), WHO recommends exclusive breastfeeding with ART because the risk of death from malnutrition/infection outweighs HIV transmission risk.

  • So, it is context-dependent, not an absolute contraindication everywhere.




Reference:Nelson textbook of pediatrics 21st edition Page no 322

questions.text: Vitamin K supplementation Is given to neonates to prevent __.
questions.solution:
• Vitamin K is essential for the synthesis of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X.

  • Neonates are born with low stores of vitamin K due to:

    • Poor placental transfer

    • Sterile gut (no bacterial synthesis of vitamin K)

    • Low levels in breast milk

      Without supplementation:

  • Infants are at risk for Vitamin K Deficiency Bleeding (VKDB), also known as Hemorrhagic Disease of the Newborn (HDN).

    Types of VKDB:

Type Onset Cause Presentation
Early Within 24 hrs Maternal drugs (e.g., anticonvulsants) Severe bleeding
Classic Days 2–7 No prophylaxis Umbilical, GI, or skin bleeding
Late 2 weeks to 6 months Exclusively breastfed, no vit K Intracranial hemorrhage

Options: 
Option Explanation
1. Keratomalacia Due to vitamin A deficiency, not vitamin K.
2. Scurvy Caused by vitamin C deficiency.
3. Hemorrhagic disease of newborn Correct – caused by vitamin K deficiency. Prevented with IM vitamin K at birth.
4. Breast milk jaundice Related to substances in breast milk affecting bilirubin metabolism – not prevented by vitamin K.

Reference:Nelson textbook of pediatrics 20th edition Page no 888

questions.text: A 31-year-old lady with diabetes mellitus delivers a term neonate. Which of the following problems is associated with a baby born to this lady?
questions.solution:
Babies born to diabetic mothers (especially if maternal diabetes is poorly controlled) are at risk of multiple neonatal complications due to the effects of maternal hyperglycemia on the fetus.

Pathophysiology of Hypoglycemia in the Neonate:

  • Maternal hyperglycemia → excess glucose crosses the placenta

  • Fetal pancreas responds with hyperinsulinemia (high insulin production)

  • After birth, the maternal glucose supply stops, but fetal insulin remains high

  • This leads to a rapid drop in blood glucose levels = neonatal hypoglycemia

    Common Complications in Infants of Diabetic Mothers (IDM):

System Complication
Metabolic Hypoglycemia, hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia
Respiratory Delayed lung maturity → RDS
Cardiac Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (especially septal)
Congenital anomalies Neural tube defects, sacral agenesis, VSD, TGA
Growth Macrosomia (large for gestational age)
Electrolyte imbalances Hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia

Reference:Nelson textbook of pediatrics 20th edition Page no 898

choices.text: Contains high amount of lactose and low amounts of protein.
It is the breastmilk that is seen in the initial 3-4 days.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about colostrum?
questions.solution:
Colostrum is the first breast milk secreted by the mother in the first 3–5 days postpartum, even during late pregnancy (can be expressed from 28 weeks onward).

  • Color: Yellowish or golden (due to beta-carotene)

  • Consistency: Thick and sticky

  • Volume: Small (~2–20 mL per feed) but nutritionally and immunologically dense

    Composition of Colostrum vs Mature Milk

Component Colostrum Mature Milk
Protein High (esp. IgA, lactoferrin) Moderate
Fat Low High
Lactose (carbohydrate) Low High
Calories Lower Higher
Immunoglobulins (esp. IgA) Very high Lower than colostrum
Leukocytes High Lower
Growth factors High (EGF, insulin-like GF) Moderate

Functions: 

  1. Immunologic Protection

    • Rich in secretory IgA: coats mucosa to prevent pathogen entry

    • Contains lactoferrin, lysozyme, and leukocytes (macrophages, neutrophils)

  2. Gastrointestinal Priming

    • Prepares neonatal gut for digestion

    • Promotes growth of beneficial gut flora

    • Facilitates meconium passage, reducing risk of neonatal jaundice

  3. Protection against infections

    • Especially protective against necrotizing enterocolitis, respiratory and GI infections


Reference:Ghai essential Pediatrics 9th edition page no 147

questions.text: A woman brings her malnourished 3-year-old daughter to a remote clinic. She had a hemoglobin of 5 g/dL. Along with a subtle rash on her knees, ankles, and elbows, the girl also has edema over her knees and ankles. What is the most likely type of worm infection causing these symptoms?
questions.solution:
• The given features are suggestive of a Hookworm infection as the child is suffering from anemia caused by loss of blood from hookworm infestation, which can lead to general weakness, joint swelling, and hemoarthrosis.
  • Hookworms are parasites which feed on human blood and can cause anemia, due to the anti-coagulant they secrete which prevents clotted blood. It is not known to cause bleeding from areas other than the gut.


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 265,266

choices.text: Both acute rheumatic fever and acute glomerulonephritis

questions.text: A 12 years old boy develops sore throat of 4 days duration. On examination, yellow grayish patch was seen over both the tonsils and foul smell coming from his mouth. Which of the following non-suppurative complication is of concern?
questions.solution:
• Streptococcal pharyngitis can complicate into acute rheumatic fever as well as acute glomerulonephritis 
  • Streptococcal skin infection in the form of impetigo leads to only acute glomerulonephritis.


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 367

questions.text: A 4 years old child presented in emergency with stridor, respiratory difficulty and noisy breathing with drooling of saliva. Emergency X-ray showed thumb sign. Diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Acute epiglottitis is a potentially life-threatening illness in which the epiglottis, the flap of cartilage at the back of the throat, becomes severely inflamed.

Child with acute epiglottitis has a toxic look and presents with high fever, stridor & respiratory difficulty.

On X ray lateral view of neck, inflamed epiglottis looks like a thumb projecting. This is referred to as Thumb sign. 
 


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 368,376

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with a persistent fever and signs of sepsis had a blood pressure reading of 90/60 mm Hg, a pulse rate of 144/min, and a respiration rate of 30/min. What is the preferred starting fluids for management?
questions.solution:
• In hypovolemic or septicemic shock, replacement of intravascular volume by Isotonic fluids is the main stay of treatment.
  • Hence, Normal saline resuscitation with 20 ml/kg  is the best answer here.


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 727-729

questions.text: A 4-year-old unvaccinated patient with fever and red eyes arrived at OPD. The patient's body was covered in the following form of rash at the time. What complication associated with this condition is most likely to occur
questions.solution:
• A history of no vaccination along with fever and a maculopapular rash is suggestive of Measles.
  • The most common complication associated with measles infection is Acute Otitis Media. Complications associated with measles include: Otitis media (most common) Bronchopneumonia (most severe) Hecht’s pneumonia/ giant cell pneumonia Subacute sclerosis panencephalitis (chronic, fatal)

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 209,210

questions.text: What is the cause of Hydrops fetalis?
questions.solution:
• The most frequent infectious cause of hydrops fetalis is parvovirus Bl9, which also causes anemia by infecting fetal erythroid progenitor cells.
  • Severe anemia also causes high-output cardiac failure and hydrops fetalis.
  • Parvovirus is a single stranded DNA virus.
  • The receptor for parvovirus B-19 is CD-21 or complement receptor 2. 
     

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 213

questions.text: Transplacental transmission of the organism given in the image which causes microcephaly?
questions.solution:
Microcephaly is Head circumference < -3 S.D and is seen in Zika Virus infection.
Transplacental Transmission of the virus may cause:
i. Severe microcephaly
ii. Decreased brain tissue and brain damage with a specific pattern- Micrencephaly
iii. Damage to the back of the eye - Macular scarring
iv. Joints with limited range of motion, such as club foot - CTEV
v. Too much tone causing birth to be restricted after birth - Hypertonia



 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 232,233

questions.text: In a child who 2 months back experienced bloody diarrhoea with fever followed by swollen red and erythematosus joint now, there is an indication of the presence of:
questions.solution:
• The clinical history of bloody diarrhea with fever followed by joint symptoms such as swollen, red, and erythematous joints suggests a post-infectious reactive arthritis.
  • The given features are suggestive of shigella infection.
  • Shigella infection (shigellosis) can cause bloody diarrhea and fever.
  • It is also a well-known trigger for reactive arthritis, especially in individuals with a genetic predisposition (HLA-B27).

    In case of enteric fever following are some post infection complications
    • Guillain-Barry syndrome due to campylobacter
    • Reactive arthritis due to salmonella, shigella, yersinia and campylobacter.


Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 1508-1511

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy is diagnosed with myoclonus jerk, which affects his academic performance.
There is a history of fever and rash at the age of one year. The features mentioned above point to:
questions.solution:
• History of fever and rash at one year of age (probably measles) & current presentation at 10 year of age with myoclonic jerks indicate chronic complication seen in measles called Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE).
  • It is a progressive neurological disorder of children and young adults that affects the central nervous system (CNS).
  • It is a slow, but persistent, viral infection caused by  measles virus.
  • More common in regions with low vaccination rates.
  • Stages of SSPE- 
Stage 1: Gradual onset of behavioral changes, personality changes, memory loss, school difficulties, and irritability.

Stage 2: Development of myoclonus (involuntary jerking movements), seizures, and progressive intellectual decline.

Stage 3: Further neurological deterioration with worsening myoclonus, spasticity, and severe dementia.

Stage 4: End-stage disease characterized by a vegetative state, decerebrate rigidity, and eventually death.
Diagnosis- 
  • EEG: Periodic, high-voltage discharges (burst-suppression pattern).
  • CSF analysis: Elevated measles antibodies (oligoclonal bands or high titers of anti-measles IgG).
  • MRI: Brain shows signs of inflammation and demyelination.
  • Measles antibody titers: Significantly elevated in both the blood and cerebrospinal fluid.


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 209,210

choices.text: Blood culture and CSF culture from shunt tap

questions.text:
Due to shunt malfunction, a 4-year-old child with hydrocephalus who has ventricular shunt had it changed.
The youngster now complains of irritation and lack of appetite that has lasted for three days with no other symptoms; the rectal temperature was 38.7 C. What will be the next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Blood culture and CSF culture from shunt tap
  • The child is complaining of irritation and lack of appetite, a recent history of changing shunt along with these symptoms is suggestive of shunt associated meningitis.
  • The next best step in this case will be taking blood culture and CSF sampling from shunt tap.
  • Shunt aspiration is preferable to a lumbar puncture as it allows better detection of microbes and avoids the need of a separate procedure reducing the risk of contamination.

Option 1 – Blood culture should be done on all cases of suspected meningitis but the diagnosis of meningitis is confirmed by CSF analysis obtained from shunt tap.

Option 3 – IV antibiotics are the mainstay of treatment but should be started after taking blood and CSF samples, this is not the best next step.

Option 4 – shunt patent studies are performed to determine whether shunt revision surgery is needed in the malfunctioned VP shunt. It is done using radionucleotide dyes.



Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 561-563,578

choices.text: About 20-30% of CMV infections are symptomatic at birth
A triad of hearing loss, PDA and cataract is seen
Hearing loss can appear later in life in asymptomatic babies
Babies born to mothers who have IgG CMV are always 100% immune to the transplacental spread

questions.text: Which of the following statement about congenital CMV infection is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct asnwer is option(3).
 
  • 90% of neonates with congenital CMV infections are asymptomatic at birth and will not show any clinical symptoms. However, 10% of infected newborns present with symptoms. Hence, option 1 is incorrect.(10% of babies are symptomatic, not 20-30%)
  • Infants with symptomatic congenital CMV infections typically have a triad of Jaundice, Petechiae, and hepatosplenomegaly.  A triad of hearing loss, PDA, and cataracts is seen in congenital Rubella syndrome, not CMV.
  • The most frequent long-term complication of neonatal CMV infection is hearing loss (SNHL) - It is the most common cause of non-syndromic SNHL. Around 50% of newborns with congenital CMV infection go on to experience hearing loss in later infancy and early childhood. Hence, option 3 is correct.
  • CMV can also be transmitted from mother to fetus if the mother had a CMV infection in the past and was immune at the time of conception. This transmission can occur due to reinfection during pregnancy. Hence, option 4 is incorrect. 

Answer has been confirmed with Professors of both Microbiology and Pediatrics at AIIMS, Delhi. It's given wrong in many Qbanks.
 

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics 21st edition Page no 1719-1720

questions.text: A 34-week-old baby was born prematurely. The baby had a bullous lesion on the body. An X-ray shows periostitis. What is the next investigation?
questions.solution:
• Bullous lesion and periosteitis in a premature baby suggest congenital syphilis.
  • The initial evaluation of infants younger than one month should include a quantitative non-treponemal test (RPR or VDRL) on infants serum.

  •

questions.text: How long should a child be quarantined after being told that they have bacterial meningitis in order to stop the spread of the disease?
questions.solution:
Bacterial meningitis (e.g., meningococcal, Hib) is contagious and can spread via respiratory droplets. After antibiotics are started, the child is however generally no longer contagious after 24 hours. Hence, a quarantine for 24 hours after antibiotics are started is sufficient.

Other options

  • This no need to wait for cultures to become negative (option 2) or for the full antibiotic course to be completed (option 3). 
  • Quarantine for only 12 hours after admission (option 4) is too short.

Hence, isolation precautions are recommended until 24 hours of effective antibiotic therapy is completed. 


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 161

questions.text: What is the most common organism causing neonatal sepsis (India)?
questions.solution:
• Most common organism causing neonatal sepsis  among the given options in India is Klebsiella.
  • Klebsiella>Staph. aureus>E coli are the most common organisms in both early and late sepsis in intramural and extramural births.


Reference -Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 160

questions.text: Which of the following specimen yields the maximum organism in a case of visceral leishmaniasis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Spleen

Parasite detection is the gold standard for diagnosing Visceral Leishmaniasis.
The amastigote forms ( LD bodies) can be seen in tissue smears from lymph nodes, bone marrow or spleen in preparations stained with Giemsa or Leishman stain.
  • Splenic smears have the sensitivity of 93 –98 %.
  • Bone marrow have sensitivity of 52-85%
  • Lymph node smears have lower sensitivity of 52–58% .
