choices.text: It is the M/c cause of non-syndromic SNHL in children
Can be confirmed by CMV DNA PCR in blood of baby
In developing countries major cause of cong. infections from mother

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Cong. CMV infection?
questions.solution:
• CMV - m/c Intrauterine Infection
  • However, in developing countries. Post natal secondary infection > intrauterine transmitted infection.
  • Almost all cases are asymptomatic. Only 10% are symptomatic
  • Sample - Urine - for confirmatory test - CMV DNA PCR
  • Saliva - Screening test.


Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Page no 2010-2015.

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1487, 1488.

questions.text: A baby born with prematurity, has low birth weight, decreased hearing, bilateral cataract and PDA. What is the most likely cause ?
questions.solution:
The premature LBW child has deafness, cataract and congenital heart disease (patent ductus arteriosus), the classic triad of congenital rubella syndrome.
  • The classic triad of CRS—clinical manifestations of cataracts, hearing impairment, and heart defects—is seen in ~10% of infants with CRS. Infants may present with different combinations of defects depending on when infection occurs during gestation. Hearing impairment is the most common single defect of CRS.
  • However, as with acquired rubella, laboratory diagnosis of congenital infection is highly recommended, particularly because most features of the clinical presentation are nonspecific and may be associated with other intrauterine infections.
  • Early diagnosis of CRS allows the prompt implementation of infection control measures and facilitates appropriate medical intervention for specific disabilities.
  • Diagnostic tests used to confirm CRS include serologic assays and virus detection. In an infant with congenital infection, serum IgM antibodies are normally present for up to 6 months but may be detectable for up to 1 year after birth.
  • In some instances, IgM may not be detectable until 1 month of age; thus, infants who have symptoms consistent with CRS but who test negative shortly after birth should be retested at 1 month.
  • A rubella serum IgG titer persisting beyond the time expected after passive transfer of maternal IgG antibody (i.e., a rubella titer that does not decline at the expected rate of a twofold dilution per month) is another serologic criterion used to confirm CRS.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 1613.

questions.text: A 3-week old child with mild rhinorrhea and nasal congestion previously had apnea after cough paroxysms. What drug should be given for the treatment?
questions.solution:
The neonate experiencing mild rhinorrhea, nasal congestion, cough paroxysms and an episode of apnea most likely has pertussis infection.
Bordetella pertussis is the causative organism.  
The management of this case will be as follows:
  • Hospitalization: Pertussis < 3 months old child is an indication for hospitalization.
  • Isolation: Droplet precautions for 21 days (untreated) or 5 days (after treatment)
  • Supportive care: Fluid, nutrition, avoiding triggers for cough paroxysms
  • Antimicrobials:
    • The macrolide antibiotics - erythromycin, azithromycin, and clarithromycin are the preferred antimicrobial therapies for the treatment of pertussis
    • Azithromycin is the drug of choice in all age-groups, for treatment or postexposure prophylaxis.
    • For neonates it is given as 10 mg/kg per day in a single dose for 5 days.
Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th Edition, Page. No- 1493.

questions.text: A child presents with petechial rash, hepatosplenomegaly and jaundice. Periventricular calcifications are seen and the screening test for hearing is negative. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The child with petechial rash, HSM, jaundice, periventricular calcifications (as shown in the NCCT below) and hearing loss has a constellation of findings which are most consistent with congenital CMV infections.


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 1488.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child was brought to the outpatient department with a history of fever and upper respiratory tract infection for the past few days. On examination, the following is observed. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Fifth disease (Erythema infectiosum) is caused by Parvovirus B19 and commonly affects school-aged children (4–10 years).

Key features:

  • Prodrome: Mild fever, runny nose, and malaise for a few days.

  • Rash: Classic “slapped cheek” appearance on the face, followed by a lacy, reticular rash on the trunk and limbs.

  • Usually self-limiting and resolves in 1–2 weeks.

  • Unlike Sixth disease (Roseola), the rash in fifth disease appears while the child is otherwise well, and fever is usually mild or resolves before the rash.

Other exanthems for comparison:

  • First disease: Measles – Koplik spots, confluent maculopapular rash

  • Sixth disease: Roseola – High fever first, then rash appears after fever subsides

  • Fourth disease: Rare, historical classification

questions.text: Conjunctival xerosis is due to the deficiency of which of the following vitamin?
questions.solution:
Conjunctival xerosis is a hallmark of vitamin A deficiency, which affects the ocular surface and vision.

Key points:

  • Vitamin A is essential for:

    • Rhodopsin formation (visual pigment in rods) → night vision

    • Maintaining epithelial integrity of conjunctiva and cornea

  • Clinical features of deficiency:

    • Conjunctival xerosis: Dryness of conjunctiva

    • Bitot’s spots: Foamy patches on conjunctiva

    • Night blindness

  • Other vitamin deficiencies:

    • Vitamin D: Rickets, osteomalacia

    • Vitamin B1 (Thiamine): Beriberi, Wernicke-Korsakoff

    • Vitamin B3 (Niacin): Pellagra

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the diagnostic criteria of mucocutaneous lymphnode syndrome
questions.solution:
Diagnostic criteria of Kawasaki disease:
Fever of at least 102.2 F for five days or more duration plus four out of the following five criteria:
1. Oropharyngeal changes (90% of cases)
2. Changes in peripheral extremities (90% of cases)
3. Cervical lymphadenopathy (~75% of cases)
4. Polymorphous rash (95% of cases)
5. Bilateral non-purulent conjunctival injection (90% of cases)

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page No 513.

questions.text: A 20 day old baby presented with history of altered sensorium with neck rigidity and vesicular lesions over the face and body. The mother had history of painful Genital Ulcers in the past. CSF study revealed Multi nucleate giant cells. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Given the history of meningitis in a neonate with history of mother having painful Genital ulcers during delivery is suggestive of Herpes Simplex virus being implicated and more commonly involved with Genital ulcers is HSV-2.
  • Painful genital ulcers are seen in Genital Herpes and Chancroid due to Hemophilus Ducreyi.
  • When left untreated can lead to HSV encephalitis and long term neurological sequelae in neonates.
  • Acyclovir is the TOC
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 1474-1475.

questions.text: The causative agent of this condition is associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The image showing the classical “slapped cheek” appearance is highly indicative of erythema infectiosum, which is caused by Parvovirus B19. This virus is also linked to pure red cell aplasia.

Clinically, Parvovirus B19 infection can present in several ways:

1. Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease): After infection, the incubation period typically lasts 1-2 weeks. The hallmark feature is a characteristic rash, starting as erythematous facial flushing, commonly referred to as a “slapped cheek” appearance. This rash often spreads quickly or simultaneously to the trunk and proximal limbs as diffuse macular erythema. The child may also develop a fever.


2. Transient Aplastic Crisis: This may occur in individuals with chronic hemolyticanemias, such as sickle cell disease, thalassemia, hereditary spherocytosis, or RBC enzyme deficiencies like pyruvate kinase deficiency. Patients experiencing an aplastic crisis typically present with fever, malaise, pallor, tachycardia, and tachypnea due to severe anemia. A rash may or may not be present.


3. Pure Red Cell Aplasia: The virus primarily uses the erythrocyte P blood group antigen as its receptor. In immunocompromised patients, a persistent Parvovirus B19 infection can cause chronic bone marrow suppression and lead to pure red cell aplasia.


4. Maternal Infection: In pregnant women, Parvovirus B19 infection is associated with nonimmune fetalhydrops and intrauterine fetal demise.


5. Joint Involvement: Approximately 7% of children with erythema infectiosum experience joint symptoms, whereas 80% of adults report joint involvement. Additionally, the virus may cause infection-associated hemophagocytic syndrome in immunocompromised patients.



The diagnosis of erythema infectiosum is typically clinical and does not require further investigation in most cases. However, in immunocompromised patients or for prenatal diagnosis, viral DNA detection through PCR or nucleic acid hybridization may be performed.

The infection is generally self-limiting and resolves without treatment, though IVIG can be administered to immunocompromised children.

 

Reference: Nelson’s Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page no 1697-1700.

questions.text: The perinatal transmission of infection shows the spectrum of anemia, possibly myocarditis, high output cardiac failure, and ascites. Identify the causative agent.
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of anemia, myocarditis, high-output cardiac failure, and ascites, along with an image showing hydropsfetalis, suggesting a diagnosis of erythema infectiosum (Fifth disease) caused by parvovirus B19. This virus infects fetal erythroid progenitor cells, leading to anemia. The severe anemia can result in high-output cardiac failure and hydropsfetalis. Additionally, the liver, which is involved in erythropoiesis during early fetal life, is affected, contributing to the development of ascites.

Erythema infectiosum typically presents after an incubation period of 4-28 days with a prodrome that includes low-grade fever, headache, and mild upper respiratory tract symptoms. The characteristic rash of erythema infectiosum develops in three stages:

1. **Stage 1**: Erythematous flushing of the face, giving a “slapped cheek” appearance.
2. **Stage 2**: Diffuse macular erythema spreads to the trunk and proximal extremities.
3. **Stage 3**: Central clearing of the macular lesions occurs, resulting in a lacy, reticulated appearance.

The rash is usually more prominent on the extensor surfaces and spares the palms and soles. By the time the rash appears, affected children are typically afebrile and appear well. Importantly, children with erythema infectiosum are generally not infectious at the time of presentation.

Complications of erythema infectiosum include:

- **Arthralgias or arthritis**
- **Transient Aplastic Crisis**: Characterized by a temporary arrest of erythropoiesis and reticulocytopenia, especially in individuals with chronic hemolytic conditions such as sickle cell anemia.
- **Thrombocytopenic purpura**
- **Myocarditis**
- **Papular-purpuric “gloves-and-socks” syndrome**
- **Neurological complications**: Including aseptic meningitis, encephalitis, peripheral neuropathy, and stroke in children with sickle cell disease.
- **Infection-associated hemophagocytic syndrome** in immunocompromised patients
- **Maternal infection**: Associated with non-immune fetalhydrops and intrauterine fetal demise.

There is no evidence to support the use of intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) for post-exposure prophylaxis. However, IVIG has been used successfully in some cases to treat B19-related anemia and bone marrow failure in immunocompromised children. There is no specific antiviral therapy available for parvovirus B19 infection.



Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page no 1697-1700 .

questions.text: Which of the following has the least risk of perinatal transmission?
questions.solution:
Rubella has the least risk of perinatal transmission.

Rubella or German measles has an intrauterine transmission that causes serious infection in pregnancy which results in abortions or severe fetal defects if infection occurs in the first trimester. The classical triad of congenital rubella syndrome is deafness, cataract, and congenital heart disease.


Reference : Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd Edition, Page no 1155,1156 .

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the clinic with a fever, cough, red eyes, running nose, and rash. The appearance of the child is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This child, based on the provided clinical vignette and rash, is likely diagnosed with measles.

Measles is a common cause of fever accompanied by a rash, transmitted via respiratory droplets. The illness typically begins with a prodromal phase featuring cough, conjunctivitis, and coryza, alongside fever. One notable sign is Koplik spots—small white lesions with surrounding erythema found on the buccal mucosa, opposite the lower second molars. Around the fourth day of illness, a reddish macular rash emerges behind the ears, quickly evolving into a maculopapular rash that spreads to the face, neck, chest, arms, trunk, thighs, and legs.

questions.text: What is the most common sequelae that can develop in a neonate with Bacterial Meningitis ?
questions.solution:
sensorineural hearing loss is the most common sequelae which can develop in cases of bacterial meningitis.
Sensory neural hearing loss is a result of cochlear infection or direct inflammation of the auditory nerve. All patients with bacterial meningitis should undergo an audiological assessment before discharge from the hospital, or immediately after. Neurological sequelae of meningitis include:
• Hearing loss (most common)
• Cognitive impairme & behavioral problems
• Recurrent seizures
• Delay in the acquisition of language
• Visual impairment
• Noncommunicating hydrocephalus
Bacterial meningitis may be caused due to Meningococcus, Streptococcus pneumonia, or Haemophilus influenzae type b. The nonspecific symptoms and signs include fever, rash, lethargy, refusal to feed, vomiting, etc. Specific symptoms and signs such as photophobia, nuchal rigidity, bulging of the fontanel, and clinical signs of meningeal irritation (Kernig and Brudzinski's sign), are not usually seen in infants. Seizures and focal neurological signs may be present. Ref - Nelson textbook of Pediatrics 20th edition page 2936

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with fever, cough, conjunctival congestion, and coryza. On examination, there are red maculopapular rashes on the neck and forehead. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The child presents with the classic triad of measles: fever, cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis.

  • The maculopapular rash appears on the face and neck first and then spreads centripetally to the trunk and limbs.

  • Koplik spots (small white spots on the buccal mucosa) may also be seen, which are pathognomonic.

Other options:

  • Varicella Zoster: Rash appears as vesicles ("dew drops on a rose petal"), not maculopapular.

  • Erythema roseolum (Roseola infantum): Usually occurs in infants 6 months–2 years, high fever precedes a truncal rash.

  • Mumps: Mainly presents with parotid swelling, not generalized rash.




Reference
Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition - page no 209-210 ,212, 213

questions.text: A primigravida presented to the hospital in active labor and was found to be HIV positive. She is not on any antiretroviral therapy. According to the NACO guidelines, what is the minimum prophylactic antiretroviral therapy to be started in the neonate after birth?
questions.solution:
• The neonate is born to an HIV-positive mother not on ART, putting the baby at high risk of HIV transmission.

  • According to NACO guidelines, the minimum postnatal prophylaxis for high-risk infants is:

    • Zidovudine (AZT) for 6 weeks.

  • If the child is at very high risk (mother with high viral load or late diagnosis), a combination regimen of AZT + Nevirapine may be considered.

Other options:

  • Nevirapine 12 weeks: Not recommended alone for standard prophylaxis.

  • Nevirapine + Zidovudine 12 weeks: Reserved for very high-risk situations.

  • Nevirapine + Zidovudine 6 weeks: Used for high-risk neonates if additional risk factors are present, but not the minimum standard.


Reference:Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th edition,Page no. 322

questions.text: Which of the following is not used to treat cyanotic episodes in a TOF patient?
questions.solution:
Calcium chloride is not given in the treatment of cyanotic spells in a patient of TOF.

Cyanotic spells are seen in tetralogy of fallot.

Tetralogy of Fallot:

  1. Pulmonary stenosis
  2. Ventricular septal defect
  3. Right ventricular hypertrophy
  4. overriding of aorta.
 

Management of anoxic or cyanotic spells:

In case of cyanotic spells there is reduced pulmonary blood flow. Thus the target is to increase the peripheral resistance so that the systemic flow is reduced and pulmonary flow increases. 

  • Knee chest position, humidified oxygen & Morphine  0.1 to 0.2 mg/kg SC.
  • If acidosis detected :  sodium bicarbonate 1-3 ml/kg IV
  • Propranolol 0.1 mg/kg/IV-0.5-1 mg/kg/6hourly
  • Vasopressors like Phenylephrine & Methoxamine IM or IV drip.
  • Manage the anaemia and consider surgery.
 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 419

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely in PDA?
questions.solution:
• Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA) is a common congenital heart defect where the fetal ductus arteriosus (DA) fails to close shortly after birth, allowing oxygenated and deoxygenated blood to flow between the aorta and the pulmonary artery.
  • This creates a shunt between the two vessels, resulting in increased pulmonary and systemic circulation, eventually resulting in volume overload.
  • Features: Increase in pulmonary flow and systemic flow, Bounding pulses
  • Heart Sounds: The second heart sound is slowly fading and the diastolic murmurs may be present
  • CO2 wash out is not seen in PDA
  • It can lead to necrotizing enterocolitis and pulmonary hemorrhage.

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 414-416

questions.text: Which of the following is the most reliable indication of a cyanotic spell in a child with tetralogy of Fallot who also has a fever and diarrhea?
questions.solution:
• There is a characteristic temporary decrease or absence of systolic murmur during a cyanotic spell because of decreased flow across the right ventricular outflow tract.


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 419

questions.text: A ten-year-old child with seizures arrives at the pediatric emergency room. The upper extremity's blood pressure was recorded as 200/140 mm hg. There were no discernible femoral pulses. The following is the most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Coarctation of the Aorta 

Hypertension in upper limb with absent femoral pulses in a child are suggestive of coarctation of aorta.

Option 1 – Takayasu aortoarteritis is a medium vessel disease affecting middle aged individuals of 40-50 age group.

Option 2 – renal parenchymal disease will present with features of edema, ascitis, hypertension, hematuria and reduced urine output. Femoral pulses will be present normally.

Option 3 – Grand mal seizures will only present with tonic clonic seizures affecting the whole body. Hypertension may be present but brachio-femoral BP difference is unlikely.

Some points about Coarctation of aorta
  • Obstructive lesion
  • Location : junction of arch and descending aorta
  • Clinical features :
  1. Intermittent claudication
  2. Feeble femoral pulse
  3. Radio femoral delay
  4. Hypertension
  5. Complete narrowing in neonates leads to shock
  6. Renal damage
  • Diagnosis – X-ray (inferior rib notching and 3 sign )
  • Management – angioplasty followed by balloon dilatation




Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 428,429

questions.text: What is the diagnosis in a cyanotic child with the following chest X-ray:
questions.solution:
Given chest X ray shows Boot-shaped heart suggestive of Tetralogy of Fallot (option 1)

Other options
 
  • Option 2 - TAPVC - shows Snowman or figure of 8 Appearance
  • Option 3 - Ebstein Anamoly shows box shaped heart
  • Option 4 - TGA Shows egg on string appearance






Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 417-419

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis in a a child with coarse Elfin facies, hypercalcemia and cardiac findings/murmur suggestive of supravalvular AS
questions.solution:
• Patients with Williams Syndrome often display Elf-like facial features, a friendly personality, low IQ, and heart problems like supravalvular aortic stenosis.


 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 666,668,995

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a child who presented with fever for > 5 days, conjunctivitis and unilateral cervical Lymphadenopathy ?
questions.solution:
All these features (conjunctivitis/fever/unilateral cervical lymphadenopathy) are suggestive of Kawasaki disease. Kawasaki disease is an acute, medium-vessel vasculitis of childhood. Diagnosis requires Fever ≥ 5 days plus ≥4/5 clinical criteria (conjunctivitis, rash, extremity changes, oral mucosal changes, cervical lymphadenopathy). 

This child already has fever, conjunctivitis, and cervical lymphadenopathy - the pattern is  strongly suggestive of Kawasaki.



Other options
  • Option 2 -Scarlet fever - Caused by Strep pyogenes (erythrogenic toxin). Presents with fever, sore throat, sandpaper rash, strawberry tongue, does not cause conjunctivitis or isolated unilateral lymphadenopathy.
 
  • Option 3 - Measles - Presents with high fever, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, Koplik spots, followed by maculopapular rash starting on face. Doesnot cause unilateral lymphadenopathy. 
 
  • Option 4 - Henoch–Schönlein Purpura (HSP)presents with  - Palpable purpura (lower limbs), abdominal pain, arthritis and renal involvement. 

Reference- Nelson textbook of Pediatrics 21st edition Page No 1314-1316

questions.text: Where is the highest oxygen concentration found in a fetus
questions.solution:
• Correct Option is 2: IVC The placenta through the umbilical vein provides oxygenated blood to the fetus. The umbilical vein through ductus venosus bypasses the liver and opens into IVC. Thus, IVC carries oxygenated blood and has the highest oxygen concentration among the options given above.
  • Superior Vena Cava (SVC): This carries deoxygenated blood from the upper body, so it has a low oxygen concentration.
  • Lungs: The fetal lungs are not yet functioning for gas exchange, so they have very low oxygen concentrations.
  • Aorta: The aorta carries mixed blood (oxygenated from the IVC and deoxygenated from the SVC and ductus arteriosus), so its oxygen concentration is lower than that of the IVC above the ductus venosus.

 

Reference:Nelson textbook of pediatrics 21st edition Page no 2344,2345

choices.text: For the Pulse oximetry test for Cyanotic congenital heart disease(CCHD)
Used in resuscitation of a normal baby
In the delivery room for assessment of the mother

questions.text: All of the following are uses of the given instrument EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• A neonatal pulse oximeter attached to lower limb is displayed in the image.
  • It is used for delivery room assessment of neonate, not mother (option 4). 
Applications/Uses of pulse oximeter
  1. Checking for endotracheal tube placement and the efficiency of the bag and mask ventilation.
  2. Detecting cyanosis (in CCHD like TOF) (option 2)
  3. Monitoring for hypoxia during suction and laryngoscopy.
  4. Monitoring for apnea (Indicating bradycardia and desaturation) - (option 1)
  5. It can be used in addition to Allen's test to determine the potency of the ulnar artery.
  6. It aids in the assessment of the body's response to resuscitation. (option 3)


Reference - Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics, Edition 21st , Page No 588

questions.text: VSD is corrected to prevent which of the following condition:
questions.solution:
Correction of VSD is done to avoid or correct failure to thrive.

Following are the indications for correction of VSD:
  • large VSD with medically uncontrolled symptomatology and continued FTT
  • Age 6-12 months with large VSD and pulmonary hypertension
  • Age > 24 months with Qp:Qs ratio > 2:1
  • Supracristal VSD of any size secondary to risk of developing AV insufficiency.


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 411-414

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is admitted with cyanosis. What is the most likely diagnosis in light of the chest X-ray results?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Supracardiac TAPVC

The chest X-ray is suggestive of figure of 8 appearance with the history of cyanosis points towards TAPVC (total anomalous pulmonary venous connection).




 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 423,424

questions.text:
Lower limb pulses cannot be felt in a 10-year-old child who has upper limb hypertension. On chest X-rays, the ribs were notched.
What medical diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Coarctation of Aorta

Coarctation of the aorta in older children presents as:
  • Intermittent claudication pain
  • Feeble femoral pulse
  • Radiofemoral delay
  • Upper limb Hypertension due to descending aorta obstruction
  • Inferior rib notching due to development and dilation of collaterals.
  • Esophageal compression appearing as Reverse 3 sign.



 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 428,429

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sign of PDA in a preterm baby?
questions.solution:
Narrow pulse pressure is not a sign of PDA in a preterm baby.
  • Apnea: This is a common symptom in preterm infants with PDA due to respiratory distress and increased pulmonary blood flow.
  • Tachycardia: PDA can cause increased cardiac workload, leading to faster heart rates (tachycardia).
  • Necrotizing Enterocolitis (NEC): PDA can contribute to NEC due to gut hypoperfusion and increased shunting of blood.
  • Narrow pulse pressure: In PDA, there is often a wide pulse pressure due to the large difference between systolic and diastolic pressures (systolic pressure is high due to increased cardiac output, while diastolic pressure is low due to runoff of blood into the pulmonary circulation).


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 414-416

questions.text: The following statement regarding the configuration of heart and its cause is incorrect:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Snowman's sign : Ebstein anomaly

DIFFERENT X-RAY FINDINGS AND SIGNS FOUND IN COGENITAL HEART DISEASES :-




 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 420,421

questions.text: Which of the following conditions results in an enlarged size of the right atrium?
questions.solution:
In an atrial septal defect, there is left-to-right shunting of blood between the atria,(LA pressure>RA pressure) which leads to increased blood flow from left atrium into the right atrium (LA -> RA). This results in right atrial enlargement due to the volume overload.
 
  • Ventricular septal defect (VSD): Causes left to right shunt from LV to Right ventricle - leads to volume overload in the right ventricle and pulmonary circulation, not the right atrium.
  • Aortopulmonary window: Causes left-to-right shunting at the great artery level, leading to increased blood flow to the pulmonary circulation
  • Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA): Also leads to left-to-right shunting at the great artery level( from Aorta into the pulmonary artery) causing volume overload in the pulmonary circulation and this increased pulmonary blood flow reaches LA/LV and hence volume overload/size increase of primarily the left atrium and left ventricle.

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 409-411

questions.text: What does the existence of a pulmonary plethora, a increased left atrium, and a normal aorta in a patient with a left-to-right shunt imply?
questions.solution:
• Correct Option is 2: VSD
  • In VSD, blood flows from the left ventricle(higher pressure) to the right ventricle(lower   pressure). From the right ventricle, blood flows through the pulmonary artery into the lungs leading to increased pulmonary blood flow and the development of Pulmonary plethora.
  • This large volume of blood finally reaches the left atrium contributing to its increased size(sizeable left atrium). Thus left atrium is enlarged.

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 411-414

questions.text: In pentology of Fallot, which of the following represents the additional component:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Atrial Septal Defect (ASD) 

The components of TETROLOGY OF FALLOT include :
  •  Infundibular Pulmonary Stenosis
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy
  • Overriding of aorta
  • VSD
In addition to the above components the presence of Atrial Septal Defect (ASD) or Patent Foramen Ovale makes it Pentology of Fallot.

Trilogy Fallot- 
  • ASD
  • Pulmonary stenosis
  • Right Ventricular Hypertrophy 



Reference:https://radiopaedia.org/articles/pentalogy-of-fallot

questions.text: Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) can be differentiated from Atrial septal Defect (ASD) by which of the following features on an X-ray chest?
questions.solution:
The correct Option is 1:  Enlarged Left Atrium.
  • In VSD, blood flows from the left ventricle to the right ventricle. From the right ventricle, blood flows through the pulmonary artery into the lungs leading to increased pulmonary blood flow and the development of Pulmonary plethora.
  • The large volume of blood finally reaches the left atrium contributing to its increased size. Thus left atrium is enlarged.

Reference:https://radiopaedia.org/articles/pentalogy-of-fallot

questions.text: A child presented with a decreased pulse in the lower limb with delay as compared to pulse felt in the upper limb. What can be the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Coarctation of the aorta is a congenital condition where there is a narrowing of the aorta, typically in the region of the ductus arteriosus. This narrowing can cause a decrease in blood flow to the lower limbs, leading to:

  • Decreased pulses in the lower limbs, often felt weaker or delayed compared to the upper limbs.
  • Higher blood pressure in the upper limbs compared to the lower limbs.

This discrepancy in pulse is a hallmark sign of coarctation of the aorta, which can be confirmed by imaging studies like echocardiography or MRI.


Other options:
 

  1. TGA (Transposition of the Great Arteries): This condition involves the aorta and pulmonary artery being swapped but typically does not cause a pulse discrepancy between upper and lower limbs.

  2. VSD (Ventricular Septal Defect): This is a defect in the heart’s septum and doesn't cause differential pulses between limbs.

  3. TOF (Tetralogy of Fallot): This condition involves four heart defects and typically leads to cyanosis and clubbing, but not a significant discrepancy in pulses between limbs.



Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page no 2389-2391.

questions.text:
Nada‘‘s Minor Criteria includes:
A. Systolic mumur Grade 3
B. Diastolic murmur
C. Abnormal second heart sound
D. Abnormal BP
questions.solution:
Nada‘s Minor Criteria include an abnormal second heart sound and abnormal blood pressure.

Nada‘s criteria are used to diagnose congenital heart disease in children. A diagnosis of congenital heart disease is indicated by the presence of either one major criterion or two minor criteria.

 

Reference: Essential Pediatrics by O.P Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 403 .

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presented with a history of fever, conjunctival congestion, and erythematous desquamation of the skin as shown in the images below. A 2D echo shows a coronary aneurysm. What is the first line of treatment for his condition?
questions.solution:
Kawasaki disease, also known as mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome, is a vasculitis condition of unknown etiology. It often presents with a history of fever, conjunctival congestion, strawberry tongue, and erythematous desquamation of the skin. The primary treatment for Kawasaki disease is intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG).

**Clinical Features:**
Patients typically exhibit a high, spiking fever that is unresponsive to antipyretics, lasting between 5 days to 3-4 weeks. The diagnosis of Kawasaki disease requires the presence of fever and at least four of the five principal clinical criteria, which include:

1. **Bilateral nonexudative conjunctival infection** with limbal sparing.
2. **Erythema of the oral and pharyngeal mucosa**, including strawberry tongue and red, cracked lips.
3. **Edema and erythema of the hands and feet**.
4. Various forms of **rash**, including maculopapular, erythema multiforme, or scarlatiniform.
5. **Nonsuppurative cervical lymphadenopathy**.

**Complications:**
Myocarditis is a common complication during the acute phase of Kawasaki disease, often presenting as tachycardia and reduced ventricular systolic function, with tachycardia being disproportionate to the fever. Coronary artery aneurysms can develop in the 2nd to 3rd week of illness. These aneurysms are typically asymptomatic and are diagnosed via echocardiography, which should be performed at diagnosis and repeated after 1-2 weeks. Large aneurysms pose a risk of death.

**Additional Symptoms:**
Other symptoms may include periungual desquamation, gastrointestinal symptoms (vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea), cough, rhinorrhea, and arthritis. Laboratory findings usually show elevated leukocytes, platelets, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and C-reactive protein levels.

**Treatment:**
The first line of treatment involves administering 2g/kg of intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) as an infusion over 10-12 hours, ideally within 10 days of onset. Moderate to high-dose aspirin should also be administered until the patient is afebrile.


Reference : Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page no 1310-1315 .

questions.text: A newborn presented with cyanosis, and tachypnea on evaluation found to have moderate severe hypoxia. Chest x-ray is as follows. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given x-ray shows egg on string appearance and along with a history of tachypnea, cyanosis and hypoxia the h clinical scenario is suggestive of Transposition of great arteries.
Transposition of the great arteries (TGA), also known as transposition of the great vessels (TGV), is the most common cyanotic congenital cardiac anomaly presenting during the newborn period, with cyanosis in the first 24 hours of life.

It occurs as a result of ventriculoarterial discordance, with the aorta arising from the right ventricle and the pulmonary trunk from the left ventricle. Systemic and pulmonary circulations exist as two parallel circuits. Survival in the immediate neonatal period is due to the mixture of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood provided by the foramen ovale and the ductus arteriosus. vast majority of patients are then diagnosed between the first day and end of the first week of life with marked central cyanosis without respiratory distress. Most patients also have an associated ventricular defect . Ref- Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics 21st edition Page 590,948

questions.text: A 7-year-old child has a grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur along the left sternal border. S2 is widely split and does not vary with respiration. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The child presents with a systolic ejection murmur along the left sternal border, which is usually soft (grade 2/6).

  • Widely split S2 that does not vary with respiration is classic for ASD, due to delayed closure of the pulmonary valve from right heart volume overload.

  • Many children are asymptomatic and the murmur is found incidentally.

Other options:

  • Ventricular septal defect: Harsh holosystolic murmur at the lower left sternal border; S2 may be normal or loud.

  • Patent ductus arteriosus: Continuous “machinery” murmur at the left infraclavicular area; bounding pulses.

  • Tetralogy of Fallot: Harsh systolic murmur due to pulmonic stenosis; cyanosis is usually present.


Reference
Nelson textbook of pediatrics 21st edition - Page 2374, 2375, 2379, 2384, 2385

questions.text: Tetralogy of Fallot is most commonly associated with which of the following:
questions.solution:
Syndrome CHD Commonly Associated ToF Association
Down syndrome (Trisomy 21) AV septal defect (endocardial cushion defects), VSD Rare
Klinefelter syndrome (47,XXY) No major structural CHDs commonly associated No
Edwards syndrome (Trisomy 18) VSD, PDA, Tetralogy of Fallot, polyvalvular disease  Yes
Turner syndrome (45,X) Bicuspid aortic valve, coarctation of aorta Rare
 

Tetralogy of Fallot is a congenital heart defect and the most common cause of cyanotic heart disease in children. It arises due to abnormal development of the infundibular (conal) septum during embryogenesis, leading to malalignment of the ventricular septum.

The condition includes four classical anatomical abnormalities:

  1. Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD): This is typically a large, non-restrictive defect in the membranous portion of the septum, allowing free communication between the left and right ventricles.

  2. Pulmonary Stenosis: This refers to obstruction of the right ventricular outflow tract. It may be due to narrowing at multiple levels, including the pulmonary valve, the infundibulum (subvalvular), or even above the valve. The degree of this obstruction is the primary determinant of symptom severity.

  3. Right Ventricular Hypertrophy (RVH): Due to the increased workload against the pulmonary stenosis, the right ventricle thickens over time, which is visible both anatomically and on ECG.

  4. Overriding Aorta: The aorta is positioned over the septal defect instead of being connected solely to the left ventricle. This results in the aorta receiving blood from both the right and left ventricles, contributing to systemic desaturation.

Clinical Features of Tetralogy of Fallot include:

  • Cyanosis, especially during feeding or crying, usually becomes apparent within the first few months of life.

  • Tet spells or hypercyanotic episodes are paroxysms of deep cyanosis, irritability, and even syncope due to sudden worsening of right-to-left shunting.

  • Clubbing of fingers and toes may develop in chronic cases.

  • Boot-shaped heart on chest X-ray due to right ventricular hypertrophy and an upturned apex.

  • A harsh systolic ejection murmur is commonly heard due to right ventricular outflow obstruction.

Diagnosis is confirmed by echocardiography, which visualizes the anatomical defects. Cardiac catheterization may be done in complex or borderline cases.

Treatment involves initial stabilization and surgical correction, which is typically done in infancy. Complete repair involves closure of the VSD and relieving the RV outflow obstruction. Some infants may need a Blalock–Taussig shunt as a palliative procedure if early repair isn’t feasible.


Reference:Nelson textbook of pediatrics 20th edition Page no 2211-2212

questions.text: A 6-year-old child was brought to her pediatrician for routine well-child care. Her physical examination is normal except for a systolic murmur and a widely split-second heart sound that does not vary with respiration. She has no family history of heart disease. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER:

  1. ATRIAL SEPTAL DEFECT

    • Systolic murmur due to increased flow across the pulmonary valve (not from the defect itself).

    • Fixed splitting of the second heart sound (does not vary with respiration).

    • Murmur heard best at the left upper sternal border.

    • Usually asymptomatic until school age or later.

    • No cyanosis, normal development.

      Other options:

  1. Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD):

    • Produces a holosystolic murmur best heard at the lower left sternal border.

    • Second heart sound is normal and not widely split or fixed.

    • Common in infants; large VSDs can lead to signs of heart failure.

    • The murmur does not persist in asymptomatic older children if the defect is small or closed.

  2. Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC):

    • A cyanotic congenital heart disease.

    • Typically presents in neonates or infants with cyanosis and respiratory distress.

    • Associated with right heart overload, but symptoms are usually not silent in a 6-year-old.

    • Not typically associated with isolated systolic murmurs and fixed splitting.

  3. Pulmonic Stenosis:

    • Causes a systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border.

    • Second heart sound is often delayed and soft.

    • The split of the second heart sound varies with respiration.

    • Fixed splitting is not a feature


Reference:Nelson textbook of pediatrics 20th edition Page no 2190

questions.text: Which of the following is considered the investigation of choice for childhood acute appendicitis?
questions.solution:
With its lack of ionising radiation, USG should be the investigation of choice/best diagnostic investigation for acute appendicitis in children. Ultrasound has a sensitivity of 85-90% and specificity of 95-100% for diagnosing appendicitis.

Computed tomography may be done in cases if the diagnosis is in doubt. CT is considered the Investigation of choice in adults, not in children. 
 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 281,282

questions.text: What kind of test should be used to rule out biliary atresia in a 1-month-old baby?
questions.solution:
• Investigation of choice to rule out biliary atresia in a 1-month-old child is Hepatic scintigraphy.
  • Hepatobiliary scintigraphy with technetium-labeled iminodiacetic acid derivatives (HIDA scan) is used to differentiate biliary atresia from non­ obstructive causes of cholestasis.
  • Uptake by hepatocytes is intact, but excretion depends on patent bile ducts.
  • In biliary atresia -uptake occurs, but no excretion into intestine (even after pretreatment with phenobarbital, which stimulates bile flow).
  • High negative predictive value - if tracer passes into intestine, BA is ruled out.
  • Hence, the Investigation of choice/test to rule out BA.


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 327

questions.text: A one-month-old baby was diagnosed with intrahepatic cholestasis and conjugated bilirubinemia. Hepatocytes were found to contain red-colored granules after liver tissue staining with PAS. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
One-month-old child with conjugated bilirubinemia and intrahepatic cholestasis suggests neonatal cholestasis syndrome.
The biopsy from the liver is PAS positive.
So, the most probable diagnosis would be Alpha-I Antitrypsin deficiency.


 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2225,2226

questions.text: Ursodeoxycholic acid and steroids were administered to a 3-month-old baby who had a history of passing clay-colored stools and dark yellow urine since one month. Further examination revealed that he had direct bilirubin of 6 mg%. Which of the following tests is most accurate for diagnosing the aforementioned condition?

Correct Option is 2: HIDA scan

The most likely diagnosis for an infant passing clay coloured stools and showing conjugated hyperbilirubinemia is Biliary atresia.
For diagnosis of biliary atresia,
  • USG – triangular cord sign
  • HIDA scan – (screening test)will show absent uptake of the radiotracer in the biliary tract
  • Liver biopsy – confirmatory test
  
The above images show triangular cord sign and HIDA scan respectively.

Option 3 and 4 : Liver function tests and CT abdomen are not specific tests.

questions.text:
For the past six days, a 1-year old baby has experienced 10 to 12 episodes of watery stools per day.
What additional medications should be given to the infant in addition to the zinc supplements?

questions.text: A one-month-old boy who had been suffering of a fever for two days was brought to the subcenter by his mother. The child weighs 2 kilograms. Upon examination, it was discovered that the youngster was drowsy,felt very hot, that a skin pinch had returned very slowly, oral mucosa was dry, and the eyes were sunken. His forehead had ten pustules. What actions should be taken at the subcenter?
questions.solution:
The child must be given the first dose of antibiotics and referred to a higher center.(with sips of ORS)

The patient here has multiple signs of possible serious bacterial infection/very severe disease - (drowsy child/multiple pustules/felt hot suggesting high grade fever). Hence, According to IMNCI child should immediately referred after first dose of IV antibiotic. Since child also has severe dehydration - he should be ensured to have ORS on the way. 

Other options
 
  • Option 1 - Patient should be referred after giving the first dose of IV antibiotic, not without giving the first dose of IV Antibiotic and with ORS on the way - not water. 
  • Option 2 - Child does have severe dehydration(sunken eyes/drowsy child , delyed skin pinch) - however - According to IMNCI - if the child has severe dehydration with other signs of very severe disease/severe classification - child should be referred with ORS on the way rather than giving IV fluids at the subcentre.  See the image from IMNCI given below. 

 
  • Option 4 - Child has signs of severe bacterial disease - needs t be admitted and hence cannot be sent back home


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 289-292

questions.text: On day 6 of life, a very preterm baby receiving 30 mL/kg of internal feeding suddenly experienced significant abdominal distension with apparent bowel loops. Lethargy and fluctuating temperatures were also present in the infant. Portal venous gas was visible on the abdomen's X-ray. What is his NEC's staging?

In stage IIb (Bell's classification of NEC) , portal venous gas is seen in imaging.

questions.text: The effectiveness of phototherapy is unaffected by?
questions.solution:
Efficacy of phototherapy is not affected by skin pigmentation.

Efficacy of phototherapy is affected by:

  • irradiance
  • surface area exposed
  • distance from phototherapy unit
  • initial serum total bilirubin
  • adequacy of breastfeeding.

questions.text: A 3 days old baby is admitted with intraventricular hemorrhage. Baby develops abdominal distention. The X-ray abdomen showed pneumatosis portalis (portal vein gas). What would be the stage of NEC?
questions.solution:
The presence of pneumatosis portalis signifies that the stage of Necrotizing Enterocolitis is stage 2B. The 'Modified Bell's staging criteria’ is used to determine the severity, radiography, and management of Necrotizing Enterocolitis.
According to this staging, 'pneumatosis portalis’ (presence of gas in the portal vein) indicates stage 2B; Pneumatosis intestinalis is 2A.




Reference:https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Modified-Bell-s-Staging-Criteria-for-Necrotizing-Enterocolitis-NEC_tbl1_273870645

questions.text: Which is the most common cause of passage of drops of blood through the rectum in a toddler?
questions.solution:
• Most common cause of passage of a few drops of blood per rectum in a toddler is Juvenile rectal polyp.
  • Juvenile polyps are the most common form of colorectal hamartoma and are mostly found in children under the age of 5.
  • It occurs due to SMAD 4 mutation. 
  • They usually present as a single lesion in the rectum and may cause rectal bleeding, mucus discharge, diarrhea, and abdominal pain.
  • They are also known as retention polyps due to their occurrence as a result of the obstruction of the crypt necks leading to dilation of the mucus-filled glands.

There is no increased risk of cancer associated with juvenile polyps


Reference:Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition Page no 805

questions.text: A 364 day-old child weighing 6 kg is experiencing acute gastroenteritis, accompanied by signs such as sunken eyes and skin tightness that does not quickly return to normal. What is the next course of treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: RL infusion 180 ml in the first hour followed by 420 ml in the next 5 hours

Management of Diarrhea should be done on the basis of clinical features and the presence and severity of dehydration.



Plan A :


Plan B :


Holiday Segar formula for calculation of daily maintenance fluid:
  • 100 ml/kg for 1st 10 kg
  • 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg
  • 20 ml/kg for remaining weight
Plan C – 100 ml/kg Ringer lactate IV


In the above example, the child is showing features of severe dehydration, so plan C must be followed.
Age of the child is less than 1 year, so fluids will be given across 6 hours
Weight of the child is 6 kg, so total 600 ,l fluid should be given.
30% in the first 1 hour = 180ml
70% in the next 5 hours = 420ml.

questions.text: A newborn has a fever, lethargy, distension in the abdomen, vomiting, and constipation. Clinically, he was identified as having a possible perforation and volvulus neonatorum. Best imaging modality would be:
questions.solution:
• Correct Option is 1: Plain X-ray to see free gas under diaphragm. 
  • Option 2 and 4 : Barium enema and barium meal follow through are contraindicated in a case of suspected perforation as barium causes chemical peritonitis.
  • Option 3: Upper GI endoscopy also cannot be done as an endoscope itself may cause more perforations. Hence, in a case of volvulus neonatorum, plain X-ray abdomen standing becomes the best option among the ones given.
 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 1953

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy reports having stomach ache and complaints of blood in stools. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Intussusception




 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 283

questions.text: Which of the following  is not a feature of severe dehydration?
questions.solution:
Following are the features of severe dehydration except option A- Thirsty child.

Features of severe dehydration are:
  • Lethargic, apathetic, unconscious child
  • Drinks poorly, unable to drink
  • Skin pinch recoil in > 2 seconds


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 289

questions.text: An infant of three days old is experiencing repeated bilious vomiting. The results of an abdomen X-ray are displayed below. Which of the following will come next in the care of the patient in question?
questions.solution:
Radiographs are not always reliable in distinguishing between small and large bowel in newborns, making contrast studies, such as those with Water-soluble enemas (Gastrografin, Hypaque), beneficial for differentiating jejunoileal atresia from a meconium ileus or Hirschsprung disease, as was suggested by the X-ray that showed multiple dilated bowel loops and a history of recurrent bilious vomiting.



Reference:https://radiopaedia.org/articles/water-soluble-contrast-challenge

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in a previously healthy infant presenting with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain? The mother says that the child has been passing altered jelly like consistency stool after episodes of pain, but gives no history of vomiting or bleeding per rectum.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Intussusception 

The history given in the clinical vignette is of recurrent episodes of abdominal pain and passage of altered jelly like consistency stools best matches with Intussusception. Intussusception is characterised by telescoping of one intestinal segment into another which results in mesenteric ischaemia and damage to the blood vessels/gut epithelia. This sloughed off epithelium mixed with blood gives the stool its jelly like consistency along with red colour resulting in the characteristic red currant jelly like stools.

Other Options
Option 1: Rectal Polyps – Characterised by painless bleeding per rectum and no colicky abdominal pain. 

Option 3: Necrotizing Enterocolitis – It occurs due to immaturity of the gut in preterms. Characterised by abdominal distension, decreased bowel sounds, Pneumatosis intestinalis, Pneumatosis portalis, Pneumoperitoneum, Peritonitis.

Option 4: Meckel Diverticulum – Characterised by features like haematochezia/ melena, right lower quadrant pain and does not have stools with jelly like consistency. 



Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 283

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis in case of a 12 year old boy who is presented with hematemesis, Malena and mild splenomegaly? There is no obvious jaundice.
questions.solution:
• Clinical condition typically presents in children with portal hypertension due to obstruction of the portal vein outside the liver.
  • It often results in hematemesis (due to esophageal varices), splenomegaly, and normal liver function (no jaundice), making this the most likely diagnosis.

  • Non-Cirrhotic Portal Fibrosis (NCPF): This is also a cause of portal hypertension with splenomegaly and hematemesis, but it is more common in adults and would likely present with features such as ascites or liver dysfunction, which are not seen here.

  • Cirrhosis: Typically presents with signs of liver dysfunction such as jaundice, ascites, and potentially splenomegaly, along with portal hypertension. The absence of jaundice  in this patient makes cirrhosis less likely.

  • Malaria with DIC: Malaria can cause splenomegaly, but the absence of fever, jaundice, or signs of hemolysis makes malaria with DIC an unlikely diagnosis.



    Reference:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4455142/

questions.text: A 3 years old child presented with anorexia, irritability and abdominal bloating. There is a history of passing foul-smelling stools which stick to the pan. The condition was associated with HLA DQ2. What is the best treatment for such a patient?
questions.solution:
The above given clinical scenario of abdominal bloating, anorexia, irritability and passage of foul smelling stools along with positive class II HLA-DQ2 is consistent with diagnosis of celiac disease. 

Food items avoided in celiac disease
Mnemonic - BROW
 
  • B-Barley
  • R-Rye
  • O-Oats
  • W-Wheat

Food items allowed in celiac disease -
Mnemonic - So MRP
 
  • So- Soyabean
  • M- Maize
  • R-Rice
  • P-Potato 



Reference: Essential Pediatrics by O.P Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 297.

questions.text: An infant is having many episodes of vomiting and passing loose stools. He is lethargic and is not taking breastfeed. Skin when pinched goes back very slowly. Infant is having:
questions.solution:
• The clinical presentation of drowsiness, lethargy and inability to feed with delayed skin pinch is suggestive of severe dehydration as per IMNCI guidelines. 
 
  • Rotavirus and enterotoxigenic E. Coli are the most important causes of acute diarrhea in children. 


Reference: Essential Pediatrics by O.P Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 287-289.


You can also watch this video for an explanation of the same.

questions.text:
A 2-month old infant presented with progressive jaundice. The infant has raised direct bilirubin levels and the stools are pale-colored. Lab Investigations Revealed that baby has Conjugated Hyperbilirubinemia. Liver biopsy showed bile plugs and bile duct proliferation with a polymorphonuclear infiltrate. What is the most common cause?
1, Dubin-Johnson syndrome
2. Crigler-Najjar syndrome
3. Extrahepatic biliary atresia
4. Gilbert syndrome
questions.solution:
The infant has jaundice due to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia with pale-colored stools suggesting neonatal cholestasis (conjugated hyperbilirubinemia in first 3 months of life).
In such non-sick infants with pale stools, the main objective is to rule out biliary atresia (most common cause of neonatal cholestasis), and a liver biopsy showing bile duct proliferation with plugging and inflammation is suggestive of Biliary atresia in such cases.
 
  • In Dubin Johnson syndrome, liver biopsy reveals brown-black pigmentation. (option A)
  • Crigler-Najjar syndrome and Gilbert syndrome are genetic causes of unconjugated/ indirect hyperbilirubinemia occurring due to deficiency of enzymes responsible for conjugation of bilirubin. (option B, option D)
Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21th Edition, Page. No- 2099, 2103.

questions.text: Which among the following options does not hold true for some dehydration in a child?
questions.solution:
• Charecterstics of Some dehydration-
  1. Increased Thirst,
  2. Delayed Skin Pinch,
  3. Sunken eyes and
  4. Reduced urine Output.
Lethargy is a sign of Severe Dehydration.
Estimated fluid loss in :
  • No Dehydration - <50ml/kg
  • Some Dehydration-50-100ml/Kg
  • Severe Dehydration >100ml/Kg
Reference: Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 9th Edition, Page No 287-289.

questions.text: Which of the following is a reliable sign of some dehydration in severe acute malnutrition?
questions.solution:
• Increased thirst is the best indicator for some dehydration in severe acute malnutrition.
  • Imapired Skin pinch and sunken eyes can be seen due to loss of Subcutaneous fat in malnutrition.
  • Altered sensorium and lethargy is seen in severe dehydration.
Reference: Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 9th Edition, Page No 287-289.

questions.text:
An 18-month-old child with a 3-day history of watery diarrhea and vomiting presented with altered sensorium. Which of the following are differential diagnoses?
A. Severe dehydration
B. HUS
C. Cerebral Venous Thrombosis
D. Hyponatremia
questions.solution:
The differential diagnoses for a child presenting with a history of watery diarrhea and altered sensorium include severe dehydration, cerebral venous thrombosis, and hyponatremia. The absence of dysentery (bloody diarrhea) and the short interval between diarrheal episodes and the onset of symptoms help to exclude Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS). HUS is a form of microangiopathichemolyticanemia, typically seen in children under 5 years of age.

There are two types of HUS:

1. Typical HUS, which usually follows a gastrointestinal infection, most commonly caused by E. Coli. The infection damages the gastric mucosa, leading to endothelial cell injury, promoting platelet activation, and exacerbating the condition.


2. Atypical HUS, which results from deficiencies in certain proteins, such as complement factor H, factor I, or CD46.



Clinical features of HUS include bloody diarrhea, occurring 5-10 days prior to the onset of the syndrome, along with abdominal pain, fatigue, cramping, and vomiting. The most serious complication is renal failure, which may require dialysis or kidney transplantation. Treatment is primarily supportive, and the illness is generally self-limiting.

In a child with altered sensorium or seizures in the context of diarrhea, the differential diagnoses include:

Hypo- or hypernatremia

Hypoglycemia

Encephalitis or meningitis

Febrile seizures

Cerebral or sagittal sinus thrombosis.


 

Reference: Essential Pediatrics by O.P Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 487,488,572 .

questions.text: A neonate was brought with a history of frothiness from the mouth and respiratory distress. An X-ray of the neonate is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of frothiness, respiratory distress, and an X-ray revealing a nasogastric (NG) tube positioned in the proximal esophagus with a gas-distended stomach are indicative of esophageal atresia accompanied by tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF).

During development, a longitudinal furrow separates the trachea from the esophagus. Any deviation or abnormal growth of this septum can lead to the formation of an abnormal fistula, establishing a communication between the esophagus and trachea, known as a tracheoesophageal fistula. This condition is often associated with VACTERL anomalies, which include vertebral, anorectal, cardiac, tracheal, esophageal, renal, and limb defects.

Newborns with this condition typically exhibit excessive drooling and frothing shortly after birth. When fed, the baby may experience choking and cyanosis. Regurgitation of secretions and feed through the fistulous tract into the lungs can lead to aspiration pneumonia.

choices.text: USG is very sensitive in diagnosing this condition

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about CHPS? CHPS-Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis
questions.solution:
Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS) occurs due to the hypertrophy of the circular muscles of the pylorus, not the longitudinal muscles.

Key Points on IHPS:
Common Presentation:
Infants aged 3 to 6 weeks typically present with non-bilious projectile vomiting.
It is more prevalent in first-born male infants.
Pathophysiology:
Hypertrophy of the circular muscle causes gastric outlet obstruction.
A palpable olive-shaped mass can often be felt in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium.
Visible left-to-right peristalsis followed by projectile vomiting can be observed during test feeding.
Metabolic Abnormality:
Infants with IHPS commonly develop hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.

Diagnosis:
Ultrasound is the preferred diagnostic method.
Criteria for Diagnosis:
Muscle thickness of >4 mm.
Pyloric length of >16 mm.

Sonographic signs include:
Cervix sign: Hypertrophied pylorus resembling a uterine cervix.
Nipple sign: Protrusion of double-layered hypertrophic mucosa into the stomach.

Management:
Initial Step: Correct the metabolic abnormalities (hypokalemia, hypochloremia, alkalosis) before surgical intervention.
Surgical Treatment: Ramstedt's pyloromyotomy is performed to surgically correct the hypertrophic pylorus and relieve the obstruction.

questions.text: A child following a bout of dysentery presented to the emergency department with lethargy. On examination, the child is unresponsive, unable to take oral feeds, eyes dry and sunken, and severely malnourished. What is the fluid of choice in this child?
questions.solution:
Treatment of dehydration based on severity -
Plan A: For no dehydration or minimal dehydration. ORS is administered after each loose stool.
Age Amount
<2 years 50-100 mL
2-10 years 100-200 mL
>10 years As much fluid as they want
 
Treatment of dehydration based on severity - Plan B: Fore moderate dehydration
 Amount of oral rehydration solution (ORS) to be given is 75 mL/kg body weight (wt × 75).
 
Treatment of dehydration based on severity -
Plan C: For severe dehydration, treatment includes IV fluid administration.
Age First given 30ml/kg in Followed by 70ml/kg in Total 100ml/kg in
Infants (under 12 months) 1 hour 5 hours 6 hours
> 12 years 30 mins 2 ½ hours 3 hours

The given history is suggestive of severe dehydration along with severe malnutrition hence fluid of choice is ringer's lactate with 5% dextrose. Intravenous therapy should be given only for severe dehydration and shock or if the enteral route cannot be used. Children are given a total of 100 ml/kg of fluid for severe dehydration.
Treatment of dehydration based on severity. Ref- Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics 21st edition page 339

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia?
questions.solution:
Inherited unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia:
• Gilbert syndrome
• Crigler Najjar type 1
• Crigler Najjar type 2
Inherited conjugated hyperbilirubinemia
• Dubin Johnson syndrome
• Rotor syndrome.
Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a benign autosomal recessive disease that is characterized by chronic conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and conspicuous brown-black melanin-like pigment deposition in the liver.
The disease is caused by mutation in multidrug resistance protein 2 (MRP-2) in hepatocytes.
Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics 20th Edition • Page. no. 1938

questions.text: A neonate is brought to the pediatrician with complaints of bilious vomiting. The abdominal X-ray shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The neonate presents with bilious vomiting, which suggests a proximal intestinal obstruction beyond the stomach.

  • The classic abdominal X-ray finding in duodenal atresia is the “double bubble” sign, representing:

    1. Distended stomach

    2. Distended proximal duodenum

  • There is usually absence of gas in the distal intestines.

  • This is a congenital condition often associated with Down syndrome.

Other options:

  • Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Causes non-bilious projectile vomiting, X-ray may show a distended stomach, no double bubble.

  • Colonic atresia: Presents later with abdominal distension and failure to pass meconium, X-ray shows distal obstruction.

  • Jejunal atresia: Can present with multiple air-fluid levels; sometimes called “triple bubble”, not classic double bubble.



Reference
Sabiston Textbook of Surgery 20th Edition - Page nos 1870-71, 1869

questions.text: A child presents to the emergency department with lethargy. On examination, the child is unresponsive, unable to take oral feeds, eyes dry and sunken, and severely malnourished. What is the fluid of choice in this child?
questions.solution:
• The child shows signs of severe dehydration with malnutrition: lethargy, unresponsiveness, inability to feed, sunken eyes, and severe malnutrition.

  • Intravenous rehydration is required because the child cannot take oral fluids safely.

  • Ringer’s lactate with 5% dextrose is preferred because:

    • It restores extracellular fluid and electrolytes safely.

    • Dextrose provides energy for a severely malnourished child.

    • Avoids rapid sodium correction and helps prevent fluid overload.

Other options:

  • Normal saline: Can be used for initial resuscitation but lacks energy (dextrose).

  • DNS (Dextrose Normal Saline): May cause hypernatremia if used alone for rehydration in severe malnutrition.

  • ORS: Used in mild to moderate dehydration; not safe for severely malnourished or unresponsive children.


Reference
Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition - Page no 102

questions.text: A 10-month-old child undergoes treatment for diarrhoea with hypokalemia but the child does not respond to the treatment appropriately and on examination muscular weakness is noted, What is the most likely cause of treatment failure?
questions.solution:
A 10-month-old child with diarrhea and hypokalemia is not responding to potassium therapy and presents with muscle weakness. This pattern strongly suggests hypomagnesemia as the underlying cause of treatment failure.

Pathophysiology:

Magnesium and potassium are closely linked in renal physiology. In the kidneys:

  • Magnesium normally inhibits potassium secretion through its action on the ROMK channels in the distal nephron.

  • When magnesium is deficient, this inhibition is lost. The ROMK channels remain open, leading to increased potassium loss in urine, despite supplementation.

  • Also, low magnesium impairs Na/K ATPase activity, reducing cellular potassium uptake.

So, unless you correct magnesium levels, potassium will continue to be lost in the urine, making K replacement ineffective.

Clinical Clues to Hypomagnesemia:

  • Refractory hypokalemia despite supplementation

  • Muscle weakness, lethargy, or even seizures in children

  • Associated diarrhea, malnutrition, or prolonged nasogastric suction

  • ECG may show prolonged QT or nonspecific changes

    Management Strategy:

  1. Recognize the clue: Hypokalemia not improving = Think of hypomagnesemia

  2. Check serum magnesium: It’s often overlooked

  3. Treat with magnesium sulfate: Often IV in acute settings

  4. Once magnesium is corrected, potassium levels will respond


Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 300,303-308,2917

questions.text: A child is brought to the pediatrician with short stature. On evaluation, growth hormone levels are found to be high and Insulin-like growth factor(IGF-1) levels are low. Which among the following could be the abnormality here?
questions.solution:
This is a classic endocrine case involving disruption of the growth hormone (GH) – IGF-1 axis.

Normal Physiology:

  1. Hypothalamus secretes GHRH →

  2. Pituitary releases GH (Growth Hormone) →

  3. Liver and other tissues respond to GH by producing IGF-1 (Insulin-like Growth Factor-1) →

  4. IGF-1 mediates linear growth (especially in bones)

    In this child:

  • Short stature → Suggests a growth disorder

  • GH: High

  • IGF-1: Low

This indicates that GH is being produced, but it is not able to stimulate IGF-1 production, pointing to a problem at the GH receptor level.

This is characteristic of GH insensitivity, most notably:

Laron Syndrome (GH receptor defect):

  • Genetic disorder

  • Mutation in the GH receptor gene

  • Leads to high GH, low IGF-1

  • Short stature, prominent forehead, saddle nose, delayed bone age

  • No response to GH therapy (because receptor is defective)


Reference:Nelson textbook of pediatrics 20th edition Page no 2641

questions.text: An infant who was born with cyanosis and choking on feeding was later found to have a tracheoesophageal fistula and had surgery to repair it. He was brought to you complaining of an expiratory wheeze and a barking cough. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
The above case shows typical presenting features of Post TEF repair Tracheomalacia.

  • Option 2 : A child with subglottic stenosis will have inspiratory stridor.
  • Option 3 : Croup will have a history of barking or seal-like cough along with fever but wheezing is less likely. 
  • Option 4 : A child with Asthma will have a history of atopy, a family history of asthma, and night time worsening along with wheezing and no barking cough. 



Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2214

choices.text: Ventilation perfusion mismatch because of increased dead space ventilation

questions.text: A child with bronchial asthma who has been diagnosed presents with respiratory distress and a respiratory rate of 48 breaths per minute while speaking only 2 words. After receiving nebulized salbutamol, the patient was able to pronounce a complete sentence, however their Sp02 dropped from 95% to 85%. What explanation might there be?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Ventilation perfusion mismatch because of increased dead space ventilation
 
  • Ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) mismatch occurs when there is an imbalance between the amount of air reaching the alveoli (ventilation) and the blood flow to the alveoli (perfusion).
  • In bronchial asthma, the airways can become narrowed or obstructed, leading to inadequate ventilation of certain lung areas.
  • When salbutamol is administered, it helps to relax the airway smooth muscles and improve airflow, which may cause an increase in dead space ventilation (ventilation without effective perfusion). This can result in a V/Q mismatch and reduced oxygenation.

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2155

choices.text: Prescribe oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs and send them home
Give intravenous antibiotics and refer to a higher center

questions.text: An 18-month-old child weighing 11.5 kg arrives at the PHC with a fever and respiratory problems. The young child is lethargic/unable to feed. On examination, has a respiratory rate of 46 bpm and no chest retractions. What is the best course of action for this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Give intravenous antibiotics and refer to a higher center
  • In an 18 month old child, the respiratory rate of >40 is considered fast breathing. Additionally the child’s inability to feed and lethargy are danger signs.
  • If symptoms of pneumonia like fever and fast breathing are present along with danger signs then according to IMNCI this child is considered to have Severe pneumonia.
  • This should be managed by giving first dose of IV antibiotics and then referring to a higher centre.

IMNCI guidelines for assessment of severity of pneumonia:


Fast breathing is defined as :


Danger signs :  
  1. Lethargy
  2. inability to feed,
  3. vomiting
  4. convulsions


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 380
 Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 29

questions.text: A 4-year-old appeared with a fever and cough with expectoration. On the hemogram, the total leukocyte count was elevated. The chest X-ray has been presented below. What is the most likely causing organism?
questions.solution:
Fever and cough with expectoration and elevated total leukocyte count point towards Pneumonia. 

The given CXR shows pneumatoceles which are thin-walled, air-filled cysts that typically occur within the lung parenchyma when having Staphylococcus aureus pneumonia.




 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 378,379

questions.text: At 2:30 a.m., a 2-year-old child who had been coughing (cough was barking-like) for the previous two days was reported to the pediatric emergency room. On inspection, the patient's temperature was 39 °C, and the only time stridor was audible was when the patient was crying. There was no additional abnormality discovered. Which is the most appropriate management in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is option(1)
The scenario described above(barking cough with stridor) is diagnostic of laryngotracheobronchitis (LTB) or croup. Hence, Dexa­methasone will be the treatment of choice.

Other options
  • Option 2 -Racemic epinephrine can be added for symptomatic relief in moderate/severe LTB but it is not the management of choice. Drug of choice is always Dexamethasone.
  • Option 4- IV Antibiotics are indicated for Epiglottitis. LTB is a viral disease(caused by parainfluenza or influenza virus) - hence, antibiotics are not indicated. 


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 376,377

choices.text: 5-kg male baby delivered at term experiences respiratory difficulty shortly after birth and needs artificial ventilation.

questions.text:
After a straightforward pregnancy and delivery, a 3.5-kg male baby delivered at term experiences respiratory difficulty shortly after birth and needs artificial ventilation.
The lung fields on the chest radiograph appear like diffuse ground glass, despite the normal cardiothymic silhouette. Replacement of the surfactant does not
enhance gas exchange. The hypoxemia gets worse throughout the first week of life. Both echocardiographic findings and routing culture results are negative.
A female sibling who had respiratory trouble passed away at the age of one month. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history suggestive of no response to surfactant therapy and a family history of sibling death points towards a diagnosis of pulmonary alveolar proteinosis.
  • Pulmonary Alveolar Proteinosis (PAP) is characterized by pulmonary surfactant building up intra-alveolarly.
  • A granular, eosinophilic substance that is diastase-resistant and stains positively with periodic acid-Schiff reagent occupying the distal air spaces is seen on histopathologic examination.


 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2304

questions.text: A 6-month-old baby who has had a cough and cold for the past three days presents to the OPD. The rate of respiration is 48/min. The patient has wheezing but no chest indrawing when examined. Which of the statements below is false?
questions.solution:
Due to the absence of fast breathing for the age and any other serious symptoms, the child can be said to not have pneumonia. Hence, option (1) is a false statement. 

Criteria for fast breathing -
  • 0-2 months   >60 bpm
  • 2 months-1year  >50 bpm
  • 1- 5 yrs   >40 bpm

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 380

questions.text: A six-month-old baby has been complaining of a cough and a cold for the past three days. The rate of respiration is 48/min. The patient is having low grade fever, with no chest indrawing but wheezing. Which of the following is not correct?
questions.solution:
A 6 month old baby has been coughing and cold for the last three days. Respiratory rate is 48/min.
Patient is having low grade fever, there are no chest retractions but wheezing is present. This child is not suffering from pneumonia, as respiratory rate is <50/ minute and there is no chest indrawing/no high grade fever or any feature suggestive of severe pneumonia. 

In children under 2 months old, children between 2 months and 1 year old, and children between 1 and 5 years old, a high respiratory rate/fast breathing pneumonia is defined as >60 breaths per minute, >50 breaths per minute, or >40 breaths per minute respectively. 

As per IMNCI - for no pneumonia - only symptomatic management is required (salbutamol if wheezing/PCM for fever) - there is no need for antibiotics.
 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 377-380

choices.text: Nasal washings for Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) and influenza

questions.text: A 2-year-old child was brought to the emergency department at 3 AM. The child presented with a fever and cough. On examination, respiratory rate was 36/min, temperature was 39°C, and saturation on pulse oximetry was 96%. The child has a barking cough and stridor only on crying. Otherwise, the child was hydrated, able to drink and consolable. The next step in management would be:
questions.solution:
• The above clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of mild croup as the patient has stridor only on crying with normal sPO2.
  • . A single dose of dexamethasone (oral or intramuscular) is typically the first-line treatment for mild croup, even if the symptoms are not severe. It helps reduce airway swelling and improve symptoms.
  •   Single dose of dexamethasone- 015-0.6 mg/kg.


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 376,377

questions.text: A 4-year-old with pneumonia is admitted to the ICU and intubated for the same. Later, he experiences a sudden unexpected respiratory difficulty. The next chest X-ray done is displayed. What is your next step?
questions.solution:
• In the above chest X-Ray , we can see hyperinflated left lung with increased cardiac shadow and bilateral diffuse haziness.
  • In a patient of pneumonia on mechanical ventilation with the above clinical picture, it is indicative of the child developing Acute Respiratory Distress syndrome as a result of volutrauma.
  • Hence, decreasing mechanical ventilator settings is the management of choice.


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 377-380,393

choices.text: Respiratory failure not fully explained by fluid overload

questions.text: Which of the following is a part of the criteria for diagnosis of ARDS in children?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: All of the above
