Berlin's criteria is used to make the diagnosis of ARDS in children




 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 587

choices.text: not an emergency, give oral antibiotics and follow up
refer urgently to a tertiary care center
give antibiotics and refer to a tertiary care center

questions.text: A 3-year-old with fever arrives at PHC. His breathing was shallow, the child lethargic and his breathing rate was 48 breaths per minute with chest indrawing. Which of the following is the next management step
questions.solution:
• The given information suggests that this 3-year-old child has been diagnosed with Severe pneumonia with Chest indrawing as per IMNCI Given these two factors, immediate medical care is required, so the first dose of injectable antibiotic should be given and the child should be urgently referred to a higher-level medical facility for further treatment as per IMNCI
  • Criteria for fast breathing -
  • 0-2 months   >60 bpm
  • 2 months-1year  >50 bpm
  • 1- 5 yrs   >40 bpm


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 377-380

questions.text: Identify.
questions.solution:
• The image is showing narrowing of airway – Steeple sign seen in Acute Laryngotracheobronchitis, also known as Croup.
 

  •  


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 376,377

choices.text: Refer to tertiary care after IV antibiotics

questions.text: What is the next procedure according to IMNCI when a 2-year-old child presents to PHC with only a cough/cold and no fever. He had a respiratory rate of 44 per minute and weight 11 kg.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Given oral antibiotics and follow up

Here the respiratory rate of a 2 year old child is >40 which is classified as fast breathing.
  • Fast breathing without fever or chest indrawing is classified as non-severe pneumonia and should be treated with oral antibiotics with follow up after 2 days.

IMNCI guidelines for assessment of severity of pneumonia:



Fast breathing is defined as



Danger signs :  
  1. Lethargy
  2. inability to feed,
  3. vomiting
  4. convulsions


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 377-380

choices.text: Cotrimoxazole is the drug of choice, but the patient is allergic to sulpha drugs.
Ceftriaxone is the better IV drug compared to ampicillin
Some strains of H. influenza have developed modified penicillin-binding proteins

questions.text: Following a diagnosis of H. influenza pneumonia in a 14-month-old kid, ampicillin was originally prescribed, followed by ceftriaxone. What are the reasons for this decision
questions.solution:
• Earlier, the drug of choice in H. Influenza pneumonia used to be Ampicillin. But in recent years, there has been increasing reports of resistance to ampicillin among H. influenzae bacteria due to production of beta lactamase and alteration in the penicillin binding protein. 
  • In such cases, the most effective drug to treat such an infection is Ceftriaxone.
  • Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin, remains effective against most β-lactamase-producing and PBP-modified strains of H. influenzae and is often used when resistance is suspected or when initial empirical therapy with ampicillin fails. It offers broad-spectrum activity and has excellent central nervous system penetration. 



Reference- Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 379

questions.text: Identify the one which does not indicate Pediatric asthma:
questions.solution:
All are indicator of Paediatric asthma except option B- AM:PM variation > 15%

In case of Paediatric asthma the AM:PM variation is >= 20%

Features of Paediatric asthma are-
  1. Spirometry showing limitation of air flow- FEV1:FVC ratio < 0.8
  2. Bronchodilator response with improvement in FEV1 to >/= 12% and >/= 200 ml.
  3. Exercise Challenge- Worsening in FEV1 >/= 15%
  4. Daily peak flow- AM to PM variation of >/= 20%

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 382,383

questions.text: A child presents with recurrent chest infections and recurrent sinusitis. An X-ray of the chest reveals dextrocardia and situs inversus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in a child with history of recurrent chest infections and recurrent sinusitis with dextrocardia and situs inversus on chest X-ray is Kartagener 's syndrome.
  • It is also known as Primary ciliary dyskinesia.
  • It occurs due to mutation in dynein protein of cilia. 
  • Primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) comprises those respiratory disorders having in common the malfunction of airway cilia.
  • About 50% of patients with PCD have Kartagener's syndrome: Situs inversus, chronic sinusitis, otitis and airway disease leading to bronchiectasis.
 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2298,2299

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis in a child who is presented to the emergency department with fever and mild respiratory distress. He was started on oral antibiotics and showed initial improvement, but later deteriorated again with fever, wheeze and exaggerated breathlessness. Radiographs of chest showed hyperlucency and Pulmonary Function Tests showed an obstructive pattern?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Bronchiolitis Obliterans 

The given clinical vignette describes the clinical condition called Bronchiolitis Obliterans.
  • Causative organism is Respiratory Syncytial Virus
  • Clinical features include :
  1. Fever
  2. Respiratory Distress
  3. URTI
  4. Wheeze may be present
  • XRAY  shows Bilateral Hyperinflation / Hyperlucency of lung fields
  • Treatment : Inhaled Ribavirin

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2226,2227

questions.text: Which condition is associated with round pneumonia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Streptococcal pneumonia

ROUND PNEUMONIA :
  • This type of pneumonia is commonly found in paediatric populations
  • AGE GROUP : 5- 12 years
  • CLINICAL FEATURES include fever and cough.
  • CAUSATIVE ORGANISM : Mostly bacterial etiology
  • STREPTOCOCCUS PNEUMONIAE  - Most common cause
  • XRAY FINDINGS :- Solitary clearly defined round opacities representing infective consolidation. They are commonly found in the superior segments of lower zones of lungs

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 1436-1439

questions.text: Sweat chloride levels are measured for which disease?
questions.solution:
Demonstration of high sweat-chloride levels (>60 mEq/ L) on at least two occasions is used for the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis.
 
  • Serum levels can be used to diagnose antitrypsin deficiency. (option B)
  • Iron studies, liver function testing and HFE gene testing can be used in the evaluation of hereditary hemochromatosis. (option C)
  • Serum ceruloplasmin level, slit lamp eye examination and 24-hour urinary copper excretion are part of the initial workup for Wilson’s disease. (option D)
Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21th Edition, Page. No- 695, 2288.

questions.text: 8 month old child comes to PHC with Fever and cough. On examination RR- 45bpm. No chest indrawing. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
9 month old child with cough and fever. RR- 45 and no indrawing. Suggestive of No pneumonia. The cut off for age <12 months is 50bpm. Hence she is classified as cough and cold-No pneumonia. Ideal treatment for baby would be to explain danger signs and send home.

Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page. No- 188.

questions.text: Defection chloride channels are seen in which of the following gene mutations?
questions.solution:
Abnormalities in the CFTR gene lead to defective chloride (CI-) channels. CFTR (cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator) gene mutation is seen in cystic fibrosis. The most common CFTR mutation is F508 deletion on chromosome 7q. This encodes CFTR protein, which is involved in the regulation of CI-channel. This mutation results in a lack of Cl- secretion and an increase in ENaC-mediated Na+ and water reabsorption. Defect in the chloride channel results in the production of hyper-viscous, adherent secretions, which can obstruct the airways. Thus being more prone to infections specifically Pseudomonas aruginosa. Diagnosis is made by elevated sweat chloride levels. Sweat chloride levels are generally elevated > 60 mEq/L.
Nelsons textbook of pediatrics 21st edition • Page no: 695, 772-773, 2288, 3736

questions.text: A newborn developed tachypnea and grunting immediately after birth. On examination, the baby was cyanotic, with a scaphoid abdomen. A chest radiograph was taken, which is shown below. Which of the following should be avoided in the management of this baby?
questions.solution:
• The newborn presents with cyanosis, scaphoid abdomen, and respiratory distress, and the X-ray shows bowel in the chest, indicating a congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH).

  • Bag and mask ventilation should be avoided because:

    • It forces air into the stomach and intestines, worsening pulmonary compression.

    • This can increase the risk of gastric distension and further compromise lung function.

  • Preferred management:

    • Immediate endotracheal intubation and gentle ventilation to avoid barotrauma.

    • High-frequency oscillatory ventilation may be used if conventional ventilation is insufficient.

    • Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) can be considered in severe cases.

Other options:

  • Endotracheal ventilation: Correct, provides controlled oxygenation without gastric distension.

  • High-frequency oscillatory ventilation: Can be used for lung-protective ventilation.

  • ECMO: Reserved for refractory hypoxemia in severe CDH.


Reference
Nelson textbook of pediatrics 21st edition - Page no 944-946

questions.text: A newborn baby presents with irritability and cyanosis which subsides on crying. On examination, you are unable to pass a nasogastric tube and no mist formation is noted on the laryngeal mirror test. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
A newborn with irritability, cyanosis that improves on crying, and inability to pass a nasogastric tube is highly suggestive of bilateral choanal atresia.

Why this is Choanal Atresia:

  • Newborns are obligate nasal breathers.

  • Cyanosis that improves with crying is classic — crying forces mouth breathing.

  • Inability to pass nasogastric tube = physical obstruction.

  • No mist on laryngeal mirror test = no airflow through nares.

    Management Steps:

  1. Emergency Stabilization:

    • Secure the airway.

    • Use an oropharyngeal airway (e.g., McGovern nipple or soft feeding tube) to bypass the nasal obstruction and allow mouth breathing.

    • Avoid sedatives or unnecessary nebulization — these do not address the airway obstruction.

  2. Confirm the Diagnosis:

    • CT scan or endoscopy is done after airway is secured.

  3. Definitive Treatment:

    • Surgical correction via transnasal or transpalatal approach.

      Summary of Other Options:

  • Epinephrine nebulisation (options 1 & 3): Used for croup or airway edema — not effective in anatomical obstructions like choanal atresia.

  • Oxygen inhalation (option 2): Helpful as supportive, but not definitive — doesn’t bypass obstruction.

  • Oropharyngeal airway (correct choice): Immediately bypasses nasal obstruction in bilateral choanal atresia.

    Key Point:

In any neonate with cyanosis that improves on crying, always think bilateral choanal atresia — and your first step is to secure the airway, not medications.


Reference:Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat-PL dhingra 7th edition page no 47,183,199

choices.text: High doses of SABA to be given by a nebulizer only
Sedatives should be added to alleviate anxiety
Ahigh concentration of oxygen should be given by a face mask + Salbutamol nebulisation
Nebulized anticholinergics to be added immediately as the mainstay of treatment

questions.text: A 5-year-old male with known history of asthma developed sudden onset breathlessness, and wheezing . He was rushed to the emergency, where the preliminary assessment was done. The pulse is 140/min, respiratory rate 28/min, and the FEV1 is 40% of the predicted value. Which of the following is the best next step in treatment in this case?
questions.solution:
This child has a known history of asthma and presents with acute exacerbation, suggested by:

  • Sudden breathlessness and wheezing

  • Tachycardia (HR = 140/min)

  • Tachypnea (RR = 28/min)

  • FEV1 = 40% of predicted → indicates moderate to severe obstruction

    Goal in Acute Asthma Exacerbation:

  1. Correct hypoxemia

  2. Reverse airflow obstruction

  3. Reduce airway inflammation

    First-line initial management in acute asthma (as per GINA & BTS guidelines):

  • High-flow oxygen: Administered via face mask to maintain SpO ≥ 94%

  • Short-acting β2 agonist (SABA): Salbutamol nebulization every 20 minutes in the first hour

  • Systemic corticosteroids: Often added early (not mentioned in the options here)

    Best Immediate Action:

  • Start oxygen + salbutamol nebulization simultaneously

  • This improves oxygenation and relieves bronchospasm quickly

    Option 1: High doses of SABA by nebulizer only

  • Incorrect because oxygen is essential in acute asthma with hypoxia.

  • Nebulized salbutamol must be given with oxygen, not alone.

    Option 2: Sedatives to alleviate anxiety

  • Dangerous and contraindicated.

  • Sedatives can depress respiratory drive and worsen the condition.

    Option 4: Nebulized anticholinergics as mainstay

  • Not first-line alone.

  • Anticholinergics (e.g., ipratropium) are adjuncts, not primary therapy.

  • Always combined with SABA and oxygen.



Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 1968

questions.text:
A 3-day old male neonate who has not yet passed meconium developed abdominal distension. There is no history of fever. On rectal examination, forceful expulsion of stool was observed. A barium enema is performed and the findings are shown in the image below.



Which of the following is the gold standard for the diagnosis of the above condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of the newborn strongly indicates Hirschsprung's disease. It occurs due to failure of Neural crest cell migration to colon - leading to absence of myenteric plexus and hence, failure of contraction in affected part of colon - leading to delayed meconium passage and symptoms of obstruction(like distenstion).

The gold standard for diagnosis is Anorectal biopsy (option 4) which would show absence of ganglia.  Anorectal manometry (option 3) is used for Screening. 



Reference: Sabiston textbook of surgery 20th edition Page no 1876
.

questions.text:
Fever, pancytopenia, widespread weakness, and weight loss are observed in a 6-year-old child. He is pale and has widespread lymphadenopathy upon inspection. The patient's peripheral smear is displayed below.
What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The PBS shows Lymphoblasts and the patient is also young, hence this is a case of ALL. 




Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 594,595

questions.text: A newborn has bleeding from the umbilical stump. All the basic coagulation work up (Platelet count, PT/aPTT) was normal. Most probable cause of bleeding is:
questions.solution:
Correct answer is option 1 - Factor XIII deficiency.

From an entrance exam point of view, whenever the examiner asks for bleeding from the umbilical stump, one has to think of two conditions- Factor 13 deficiency and Glanzmann Thrombasthenia.  Since, Glanzmann Thrombasthenia is not there in options - the best answer is factor XIII deficiency. 

Factor XIII Deficiency
  • Factor 13 (Fibrin stabilizing factor ) deficiency is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner.
  • Factor XIII is responsible for cross-linking fibrin strands to stabilize the clot. In its absence, initial hemostasis and coagulation appear normal -hence, normal platelet count, PT, and aPTT. However, clots formed are unstable and break down, leading to delayed bleeding, especially from the umbilical stump in neonates
  • It is  also characterized by  poor wound healing, and wound dehiscence.
  • Platelet count, PT, aPTT and INR are normal. (as given in the clinical stem)

Other options

Option 2 -  von Willebrand Disease - Causes mucocutaneous bleeding not umblical stump bleeding and has prolonged aPTT ( not normal aPTT)

Option 3 - Haemophilia A- causes deep seated bleeds like bleeding in joints/muscle hematoma and factor VIII deficiency leads to prolonged aPTT

Option 4 - Bernard Soulier Syndrome - deficiency of GpIB on platelet leads to defective platelet adhesion and characterised by low platelet counts and muco-cutaneous bleeds.


Reference:  https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/209179-workup

questions.text: Which of the following has improved in terms of prognosis as a result of advances in cancer treatment?
questions.solution:
Approximately 30% of all pediatric cancers are of the Acute leukemia form.
  • Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is encountered five times more often than acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
  • Since the 1980s, there have been considerable developments which have improved the five-year overall survival rate of ALL to over 85%.
  • These advancements have come with the aid of research protocols which offer sequential, standardized treatments for numerous children.

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 594-599

questions.text: A 6-year-old Afro-American boy reported with abdominal pain, chronic hemolysis, and aberrant RBC shape on a peripheral smear. This condition is most likely caused by a:
questions.solution:
• An Afro-American kid of 6 years of age presented with abdominal pain ,chronic hemolysis and abnormal RBC shape on peripheral smear - Most likely this is Sickle Cell disease.
  • In Sickle cell disease, there is Point-mutation that affects the nucleotide triplet CTC, which codes for glutamic acid (or GAG in mRNA), is altered to CAC, which codes for valine (or GUG in mRNA).
  • Sickle cell anemia is caused by a single amino acid change that modifies the physicochemical characteristics of hemoglobin leading to formation of HbS.
  • The majority of people with sickle cell disease, a prevalent genetic hemoglobinopathy, are of African heritage.
  • Heterozygosity is as high as 30% in Africa HbS formed polymerises when a person experiences hypoxia or acidosis and causes hemolysis, micro vascular occlusions and tissue damage.

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 342,343

questions.text: A 14-month-old infant with hemoglobin levels of 6.2g/dl required frequent blood transfusions. There are multiple target cells on peripheral smear. Nine months have passed since the final transfusion. Which is the definitive diagnosis investigation?
questions.solution:
Decreased haemoglobin levels, multiple target cells on peripheral, smear and history of multiple blood transfusions point towards Thalassaemia.
  • In cases of thalassaemia, definitive diagnosis is done though Globin gene sequencing.
  • Investigations for haemoglobin disorders include:
  1. Screening by haemoglobin electrophoresis.
  2. Investigation of choice is HPLC.
  3. Definitive diagnosis though globin gene sequencing.



Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 339-341

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl who had arthritis, hematuria, and palpable purpura abdominal pain appeared. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Henoch Schonlein Purpura

The clinical scenario of arthritis, hematuria,  purpura and abdominal pain is suggestive of HSP.
  • Also known as IgA vasculitis as there is deposition of IgA in the small vessels of skin,joints, kidney and GI tract.
  • Type 3 hypersensitivity reaction
  • Occurs following a URTI by group A streptococcus
  • Clinical features :
  1. Palpable purpura in lower extremities and extensor surfaces
  2. Arthralgia and arthritis
  3. GI manifestations like abdominal pain, intususseption
  4. Renal manifestations like microscopic hematuria, PSGN
  • Management : symptomatic treatment by prednisolone, azathioprine, glucocorticoids.
     
 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 628-630

questions.text: A 5-year-old male child has had episodic anemia and jaundice since birth. Which one of the following is he least likely to have?
questions.solution:
• Clinical manifestations of sickle cell disease are not present at birth and usually begin to become apparent after the first few months of life as the concentration of HbS rises and HbF declines. (typically after 6 months , HbF almost disappears and only HbS remains)
  • Jaundice at the time of birth makes the diagnosis of sickle cell anemia the least likely among the given options. 
     

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 342

questions.text: What does "A" (dotted line)show in the illustration of a juvenile patient's serum immunoglobulin levels?
questions.solution:
• 'A' in the given image represents maternal and fetal IgG.
  • Maternal IgG can be transferred from mother to fetus. The fetus post-birth has maternal Immunoglobulins in circulation till 6 months of age. 
     
 

Reference:Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 180
Ananthnarayan and paniker's microbiology; 10th edition Page no 99

questions.text: In a child, an examination of the CSF is not useful for the diagnosis of?
questions.solution:
In a child, CSF examination is not used in the diagnosis of Hodgkin's lymphoma.

In the case of Hodgkin's lymphoma, there is no CSF spread or highly unlikely, so CSF examination is not used in the diagnosis.


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 594-607

questions.text: A child has seborrheic dermatitis, sinusitis, and chronic ear drainage. The child is found to be failing to thrive, with hepatosplenomegaly and exophthalmos. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Probable diagnosis is histiocytosis-X
  • Histiocytosis, also referred to as Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (LCH), and formally called Histiocytosis X represents a group of rare disorders involving clonal proliferation of Langerhans cells which are resident macrophages in dermal tissue.
  • This condition is characterized by the abnormal proliferation of Langerhans cells and can affect multiple organs, including the skin (seborrheic dermatitis), respiratory system (sinusitis, chronic ear infections), and cause failure to thrive, hepatosplenomegaly, and exophthalmos.
  • Diagnosis- Light microscopy shows cells with coffee bean nucleus, Electron microscopy shows Tennis Racket shaped granules. 


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 615-617

questions.text: A 6 years old child presented with painful swelling of the hand and feet. There is a past history of chest infection 2 years back and he was admitted in the hospital too. Hemoglobin electrophoresis showed HbF and HbS. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with electrophoretic findings of HbF and HbS is suggestive of sickle cell disease. 


Other options:
 
  • Option 1- Beta thalassemia is characterized by microcytic hypochromic cells with aniso and poikilocytosis, target cells. Hb electrophoresis will show increased HbA2 and HbF. 
 
  • Option 2- Anemia of chronic disease is mediated by IL-6 and is characterized with normocytic normochromic anemia along with underlying chronic systemic inflammatory disease- eg Rheumatoid Arthritis. 
 
  • Option 3- HbC disease occurs due to mutation in b-globin chain where glutamate is replaced with lysine in 6th position. PBS shows hexagonal HbC crystals. Hb electrophoresis shows increased HbC levels. 



Reference: Essential Pediatrics by O.P Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 394, 627.

Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 641-644.

questions.text: A child was subjected to routine hematological investigations and the peripheral blood smear showed microcytosis, hypochromia and target cells. His RBC indices were low MCV (60 fl), low MCH. RBC count was 5.2 x 106/ microL. Which investigation should be done to arrive at a clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The peripheral smear showing microcytic hypochromic cells along with Mentzer index < 13 is suggestive of thalassemia. Therefore, the next step in evaluation would be to estimate HbA2 levels. 

Mentzer Index= MCV/RBC count.
It is used to distinguish iron deficiency anemia from thalassemia.

Mentzer index
  • > 13: Iron deficiency anemia
  • < 13 : Thalassemia trait/ intermedia



Reference: Essential Pediatrics by O.P Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 340-342..

Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 644, 645, 647, 654, 655, 658.

questions.text: A 4-year old child has a lymphocyte count of 65000 cells/ mm3. Which of the following is common?
questions.solution:
The 4-year old child with a lymphocyte count > 50,000/ mm3 has lymphocytosis.
  • An increase in circulating lymphocytes (lymphocytosis) can be seen following infections such as infectious mononucleosis and pertussis, or in lymphoproliferative disorders such as acute and chronic lymphocytic leukemia.
  • Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL)/lymphoblastic lymphoma (LBL) is the most common childhood malignancy. 
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 596.

questions.text: A child who has overdosed on iron tablets comes with nausea and abdominal pain. What is the antidote for this toxicity?
questions.solution:
The antidote for iron overdose is deferoxamine.

Deferoxamine is a potent iron-chelating agent administered intravenously to bind absorbed iron and promote its excretion via urine and feces. A common side effect of deferoxamine infusion is hypotension. The deferoxamine-iron complex can turn the urine a reddish color.

Iron toxicity initially presents with symptoms like profuse vomiting, diarrhea (often bloody), and abdominal pain, leading to significant volume loss. Later, patients may develop multisystem organ failure, shock, and metabolic acidosis.

Other options:

  • British anti-Lewisite (Dimercaprol): Used for arsenic, gold, mercury poisoning.

  • Penicillamine: Used in copper poisoning (Wilson’s disease), lead, and sometimes cystinuria.

  • EDTA (Calcium disodium EDTA): Used for lead poisoning.

choices.text: 3 with a history of repeated blood transfusions. Investigations show MCV70 fl and the peripheral smear showed a hypochromic microcytic picture. Which of the following investigations should be done next in this child?

questions.text: A child presents with Hb 6.3 with a history of repeated blood transfusions. Investigations show MCV70 fl and the peripheral smear showed a hypochromic microcytic picture. Which of the following investigations should be done next in this child?
questions.solution:
The child presents with: 
 

  • Severe anemia (Hb 6.3 g/dL)

  • Repeated blood transfusions

  • MCV: 70 fL → microcytic

  • Peripheral smear: hypochromic microcytic picture

This suggests a chronic microcytic anemia that is transfusion-dependent.

Likely differentials include:

  • Thalassemia major (most common cause of transfusion-dependent microcytic anemia in children)

  • Iron-deficiency anemia (but not usually transfusion-requiring unless severe)

  • Hereditary spherocytosis (would show normocytic/normochromic anemia with spherocytes)

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia (Coombs positive, usually normocytic or macrocytic)

    Interpretation of Options:

Option Relevance
Hb electrophoresis Best next step. Detects hemoglobinopathies like thalassemia, which fits the picture.
Osmotic fragility test Used for hereditary spherocytosis, but not microcytic anemia.
Serum iron May help in IDA vs thalassemia trait, but not first choice in a transfused child. Iron studies are unreliable post-transfusion.
Direct Coomb’s test Used in autoimmune hemolytic anemia, which usually shows normo/macrocytic anemia and reticulocytosis. Not the case here.
 

The combination of microcytic hypochromic anemia, low MCV, and transfusion dependence strongly points to thalassemia major, and Hb electrophoresis is the most appropriate next investigation.



Reference:Nelson textbook of pediatrics 20th edition page no 2350

questions.text: Which of the following is the maximum steroid produced by the fetal adrenal?
questions.solution:
• The steroid produced in the maximum quantity by the fetal adrenal glands is DHEA-S.
  • The fetal adrenal gland is formed around 8-10 weeks.
  • Initially, the glands produce cortisol which acts to suppress ACTH production from the pituitary. During this phase, the gonadal development in males and females is taking place and such an action is necessary.
  • In the second trimester, cortisol production decreases and DHEA and DHEA Sulphate are produced in large quantities. The placenta uses these for the production of estrone and estradiol. 
  • In the third trimester again, cortisol production is increased but the hormone produced in maximum quantity stays DHEA-S.


 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2959

questions.text: Which form of aberration in sexual development has the best prognosis?
questions.solution:
• Congenital adrenal hyperplasia is a type of abnormality in sexual development, which has the best prognosis.
  • It is possible to treat congenital adrenal hyperplasia by giving the body enough glucocorticoids to stop the overproduction of androgens.
  • Surgery can be used to treat the genital abnormality (enlarged clitoris, fusion of labia minora).
  • The prognosis has improved as a result of efforts to treat CAH in pregnancy and newborn screening techniques to detect it. CAH patients can become pregnant and give birth to healthy children.


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 522-524

questions.text: Which medication is best for treating congenital adrenal hyperplasia caused by a 21-alpha hydroxylase deficiency during pregnancy itself?
questions.solution:
• Drug of choice for pre-natal treatment of congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-alpha hydroxylase deficiency is Dexamethasone. 
  • Hydrocortisone, prednisone, and prednisolone are inactivated by the placental type 2 11β-HSD; dexamethasone is not inactivated and should therefore be used in pregnant patients. 
     
 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2796

questions.text: A diabetic mother delivered a baby whose blood glucose level was 60 mg/dL at birth. What other investigation does the nurse anticipate the doctor would have her conduct?
questions.solution:
Babies of diabetic mothers are more prone to metabolic irregularities than those of non-diabetic mothers, including hypoglycemia, hypocalcemia, and hypomagnesemia.
Therefore, it is important to check for these quickly. 


Reference-:Nelson textbook of pediatrics 21st edition Page no 913, 983-985

Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 78, 175

questions.text: Infant of diabetics mother with weight 3.8 kg presented with seizures after 16 hours of birth. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Hypoglycemia 
The given clinical scenario is a baby with macrosomia due to diabetes in mother. 
  • The given clinical vignette describes a condition which occurs after 16 hours of birth, this rules out Birth asphyxia as its cause which generally occurs soon after birth.
  • Intraventricular haemorrhage is commonly seen in premature babies
  • Hypoglycaemia in neonates born to diabetic mothers , being a very common condition is thus the most appropriate answer to this question. 
 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 983-985

questions.text: Which of the following hormones should be replaced first in the case of a six-year-old child managed by complete surgical removal of craniopharyngioma and now has developed multiple endocrinopathies?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Hydrocortisone 

Complete surgical removal of Craniopharyngioma leads to the development of Pan hypopituitarism.
  • This leads to reduced production of pituitary hormones ultimately causing multiple endocrinopathies.
  • Of these the most dangerous outcome is the development of secondary adrenal insufficiency due to reduced production of ACTH from the pituitary gland.
  • Hence the first hormone that should be replaced is Hydrocortisone in order to prevent the development of secondary adrenal insufficiency. Thyroxine is replaced in the end because thyroxine supplementation increases BMR and it leads to consumption of other hormones if replaced earlier and deficiencies of other hormones could occur. 
 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2884,2676,2677

questions.text: On day 4, a neonate was found to have TSH>110 U/L. Ultrasonography revealed an eutopic thyroid gland. What should be done next?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, there is increased level of TSH which is suggestive of congenital hypothyroidism. 
The most appropriate next line of investigation would be to do a thyroid nuclear scan in order to confirm the presence of thyroid gland. 


Other options:
 
  • Option 2 and 4- Anti-peroxide antibodies are used in diagnosis of transient congenital hypothyroidism as a result of transplacental passage of TSH receptor blocking antibodies. 
 
  • Option 3- Urinary iodine concentration is used as an epidemiological indicator for the level of iodine deficiency in community. 



Reference: Essential Pediatrics by O.P Ghai, 10th edition, Page no 538.

choices.text: Initial ABC resuscitation and 10 mL/ Kg 0.9% IV Bolus NaCl with insulin 0.1 IU/ Kg/ hr
Initial ABC resuscitation and 15 mL/ Kg 0.9% IV Bolus NaCl then insulin 0.1 IU/ Kg/ hr
Initial ABC resuscitation and 25 mL/ Kg 0.9% IV Bolus NaCl with insulin 0.1 IU/ Kg/ hr

questions.text: A 10-year old child, weighing 30 Kg presents with loose stools for the last 2 days and vomiting causing decreased peripheral perfusion with cold clammy extremities and delayed capillary refill. pH is noted to be 7.1, blood glucose is 550 mg/dl and serum HCO3- is 7.3 meq/L. What is the management of the patient in the first hour of admission as per the ISPAD protocol?
questions.solution:
The child with signs of shock has metabolic acidosis with hyperglycemia, likely has diabetic ketoacidosis (pH < 7.3, HCO3- < 18 mmol/ L, blood glucose>200 mg/ dl) requiring management on an emergency basis.
The management as per the ISPAD protocol guidelines is summarized below.
The management proceeds as per the dehydration status of the patient.
This child has signs of shock, and thus will require:
  1. A: Secure the airway and airway management ,B: Breathing with 100% oxygen and C: Bolus of 0.9% NS administration at 20 mL/ Kg (600 mL in this patient)
  2. Fluid management should continue by IV therapy with potassium supplementation as adequate based on ABG values and ECG monitoring
  3. Start insulin infusion 1 hour after initiation of IV fluid treatment. The dose of insulin is Dose: 0.05–0.1 U/kg/h of regular (soluble) insulin.


Reference: Glaser N, Fritsch M, Priyambada L, Rewers A, Cherubini V, Estrada S, Wolfsdorf JI, Codner E. ISPAD clinical practice consensus guidelines 2022: Diabetic ketoacidosis and hyperglycemic hyperosmolar state. Pediatr Diabetes. 2022 Nov;23(7):835-856. doi: 10.1111/pedi.13406. PMID: 36250645.

questions.text: Gonadal growth corresponds with?
questions.solution:
Gonadal growth is associated with a growth spurt during puberty, leading to significant somatic or skeletal development.

During childhood, gonadal growth remains dormant and only becomes pronounced during puberty. Although skeletal growth is a continuous process, it accelerates significantly during the pubertal growth spurt.

Skeletal maturity occurs when the epiphysis (growth plates) fuse with the shaft (diaphysis), typically around 18 years for girls and 20-22 years for boys.

There is a close correlation between skeletal maturation and sexual maturation. Children with advanced sexual maturity often exhibit earlier skeletal maturation as well, which is why precocious puberty is often associated with short stature.

Other Options:

Option A: Lymphoid Growth occurs maximally between 4-8 years of age.

Option B: 90% of the Brain Tissue grows by 2 years of age.

Option D: Primary dentition starts to appear at 5 - 7 months  of age which is completed by 1.5 - 2.5 years; and the secondary dentition typically appears around 6-7 years of age.

choices.text: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia - 21 hydroxylase deficiency confirmed by measuring 17- hydroxyprogesterone levels
Congenital adrenal hyperplasia - 17 alpha hydroxylase deficiency confirmed by measuring 17- hydroxyprogesterone levels
Congenital adrenal hyperplasia - 17 alpha hydroxylase deficiency confirmed by measuring 17- hydroxypregnenolone levels
Congenital adrenal hyperplasia - 11-beta Hydroxylase deficiency confirmed by measuring 17- hydroxyprogesterone levels

questions.text: A 10 day old neonate presented with lethargy and poor feeds. On evaluation the neonate had sunken eyes, poor skin turgor, dry tongue and had ambiguous genitalia. Lab investigations revealed, hypoglycaemia, hyponatraemia and hyperkalaemia. Karyotyping evaluation demonstrated ?46 XX chromosomal pattern. Identify the condition and the method of confirming diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH)/adrenogenital syndrome is a family of autosomal-recessive disorders associated with the diminished synthesis of cortisol and aldosterone. The most common cause of ambiguous genitalia in a newborn is a classic 21-hydroxylase deficiency. Neonates usually present with salt-wasting crises as seconded by dehydration with hypoglycemia, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia. Ref- Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics 21st edition Page 2972-2976
Virilization is usually apparent at birth in females and within 2 to 3 years of life in males.
The diagnosis is confirmed by markedly elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels. Glucocorticoids are the mainstay of treatment. Patients with salt-wasting and virilizing forms are treated with hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone.
Surgical treatment is usually done between 2-6 months of age for significantly virilized females.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl was brought to the outpatient department by her mother saying she noted some abnormality in her genital area. On examination, there was presence of pubic and axillary hair. Which of the following is the least likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A 5-year-old girl with pubic and axillary hair suggests precocious adrenarche, i.e., early androgen exposure.

Let's examine each option:

1. 21-Hydroxylase deficiency

  • This is the most common cause of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH).

  • Leads to cortisol deficiency, aldosterone deficiency, and androgen excess.

  • Results in virilization in females, with early appearance of pubic/axillary hair, clitoromegaly, etc.
    Likely diagnosis

2. 11β-Hydroxylase deficiency

  • Another form of CAH, less common than 21-OHD.

  • Causes cortisol deficiency, androgen excess, and accumulation of DOC (a mineralocorticoid) leading to hypertension.

  • Also presents with early virilization, pubic/axillary hair, and clitoromegaly in girls.
    Likely diagnosis

4. 17-Hydroxylase deficiency

  • Rare cause of CAH.

  • Results in deficiency of cortisol and sex steroids → hypogonadism and lack of androgen production.

  • NO androgen excess, so no pubic or axillary hair.

  • Girls have delayed puberty, primary amenorrhea, and underdeveloped secondary sexual characteristics.
    Least likely diagnosis (Does not cause early pubic hair)

None of the above

  • Incorrect because both 21-OHD and 11β-OHD can explain the findings.

    Remember,
     

  • 21-hydroxylase and 11β-hydroxylase deficiencies → ↑ adrenal androgens → early pubarche/virilization.

  • 17-hydroxylase deficiency → low androgens (with hypertension, hypokalemia) → delayed/absent pubic hair, not early.





Reference:  Ghai essential Pediatrics 9th edition page no 523

questions.text: What is the most frequently used shunt for hydrocephalus?
questions.solution:
Therapy for hydrocephalus depends on the cause.
  • Medical management, including the use of acetazolamide and furosemide, can provide temporary relief by reducing the rate of CSF production, but long-term results have been disappointing.
  • Most cases of hydrocephalus require extracranial shunts, particularly a ventriculoperitoneal shunt.
  • Endoscopic third ventriculostomy (ETV) has evolved as a viable approach and criteria have been developed for its use, but the procedure might need to be repeated to be effective.
 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 578
 Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3080

questions.text: Gram-positive bacilli were discovered during a CSF test of a neonate who had meningitis. Which of the following organisms is most likely to be the cause?
questions.solution:
Listeria monocytogenes is a Gram-positive bacillus and a well-known cause of neonatal meningitis. It is typically transmitted vertically from mother to baby during delivery or in utero.

Other options
  1. Streptococcus pneumoniae: Gram-positive cocci (not bacilli), more common in older children and adults.
  2. Hemophilus influenzae: Gram-negative bacillus, typically associated with older children upto 3-5 years after the neonatal period.
  3. Neisseria meningitidis: Gram-negative diplococcus, more common in older children and most common cause in adolescents and adults.


 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3223-3232

questions.text: In the image below, which of the following congenital defects can be seen?
questions.solution:
The figure shows a skin-covered, brilliantly transilluminate defect in the back in a newborn. This is typical of a meningocele.
  • Meninges herniate through a gap in the posterior vertebral arches and result in a meningocele.
  • Although tethering, syringomyelia, or diastematomyelia may occur, the spinal cord often assumes a normal position in the spinal canal and is in a normal state.
  • Along the vertebral column, typically in the low back, is a fluctuant midline mass that may transilluminate.

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No  3066,3067

questions.text: A sick intubated neonate is having bilateral jerks of both right/left and upper limbs with some occasional twitching of the neck as well. Likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Multifocal clonic seizure is the most likely seizure in a patient who has bilateral jerks of both their right and left upper limbs as well as occasional neck twitching."
  •  Several bodily sections are involved in multifocal clonic seizures, which are migratory in character.
  • The migration has a non-Jacksonian pattern, meaning that jerks in the left arm can be associated with jerks in the right leg."

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3111

questions.text: On CT brain, a neonate was found to have periventricular calcification.What is the most effective method of diagnosing this etiological agent?
questions.solution:
Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection results in periventricular calcification.
  • Urine and saliva are the best specimens for culture while saliva and cord blood are the best for PCR in the diagnosis of congenital CMV infection.
  • Urine is the best choice out of the ones provided. Within 2-3 weeks. 
  • Definitive diagnosis: Viral isolation or PCR showing CMV DNA (done during the first 1–2 weeks of life).


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 264,265

choices.text: Generalized Tonic-Clonic Seizure on going to sleep

questions.text: What is the most typical presentation of JME(Janz syndrome)?
questions.solution:
Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME) typically begins in childhood or adolescence.
  • The most common clinical presentation of JME is myoclonus (involuntary muscle jerking or twitching), generally most prominent when waking up.
  • When the myoclonus occurs along with other seizure types more frequently and lasts more than a short duration, the diagnosis of JME is more secure.
  • Other seizure types that can occur with JME are tonic-clonic (grand mal), absence (petit mal) and tonic seizures.

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3098

questions.text: A child with recurrent seizures, glaucoma, and palpable plaques in the Ophthalmic and Maxillary distribution. Mother complained, it is present since birth and has not changed since then. Diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Sturge-Weber syndrome, or encephalotrigeminal angiomatosis, is a phakomatosis characterized by facial port wine stains and pial angiomas. 

  • The most common clinical manifestation is with childhood seizures, present in 71-89% of cases.
  • These usually begin in the first few years of life and are often associated with developmental delay and hemispheric symptoms including hemiplegia/hemiparesis and hemianopsia.
  • Approximately a third of patients have choroidal or scleral angiomatous involvement, which may be complicated by retinal detachment, buphthalmos or glaucoma.

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3146-3148

questions.text: Young child was brought to the OPD with difficulty in walking. Below is the image of his legs. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image above shows calf pseudohypertrophy, an abnormal expansion of the calves by fibrofatty proliferation
  • It is a hallmark of Duchenne muscular dystrophy, the most prevalent kind of muscular dystrophy.

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3281-3284

questions.text: As indicated below, a 34-week-old female foetus was born. Determine the congenital anomaly.
questions.solution:
• The given image shows a cleft through the developing brain and entire spine- s/o complete craniospinal rachischisis. 


Reference-:https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/veterinary-science-and-veterinary-medicine/rachischisis

choices.text: Craniotomy and sub-total excision/gross total excision of the tumor.
Radiotherapy 35-40 Gy was given to the whole craniospinal axis.

questions.text: A 1.5-year-old girl is brought to the clinic complaining of severe undernourishment, intolerance to feeds, and extreme head enlargement. A medulloblastoma causing obstructive hydrocephalus was suggested by MRI imaging. Which of the following describes an incorrect approach to patient management?
questions.solution:
• Radiotherapy 35-40 Gy was given to the whole craniospinal axis.
  • A multimodal treatment approach is pursued in medulloblastoma which includes chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and neurosurgery.
  • Craniospinal radiation in children less than 3 years old results in late neurological sequelae including microcephaly, cognitive impairment, neuroendocrine dysfunction, and secondary malignancies.
  • This observation has resulted in not giving radiotherapy to children less than 3 years of age for treatment of Medulloblastoma.
  • Treatment is stratified according to age groups
  • Surgical resection is done in all of them.


 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2674-2676

questions.text: A 13 years old male child presented with abnormal body movements with MRI showing Abnormal T2 hyperintensity in the putamen. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Most likely diagnosis is Wilson's disease.

  • Wilson disease has an autosomal recessive mode of inheritance and is characterized by tremors, rigidity, dementia, and pseudobulbar features. 
  • A Kayser-Fleischer ring may be discovered during a slit-lamp examination of the eyes. 
  • MRI in Wilson disease is characterized by high-intensity lesions in the basal ganglia, thalami, and midbrain on T2-weighted images.
  • The typical 'face-of-the-giant-panda' sign is caused by the normal low intensity of red nuclei and SN surrounded by abnormal high-signal intensity in the tegmentum of the mid brain. 
  • The best diagnostic clue is symmetrical T2 hyperintensity or mixed intensity in the putamen (with hyperintense putaminal rim) and globus pallidus, as well as the caudate nuclei and thalami.

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2103-2105

questions.text:
An eight-year-old boy experiences increased physical weakness. His calves are thick and exhibit muscle tightening after examination. His serum creatine kinase levels rise with ageing.
Which of the following diagnoses is more likely?
questions.solution:
• Most likely diagnosis is Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy due to Dystrophin deficiency.
  • DMD typically starts in early childhood (around 2-5 years of age).
    • It begins with weakness in the proximal muscles (those closer to the trunk), especially in the legs and pelvis, leading to difficulty with running, climbing stairs, and walking.
    • Over time, it affects other muscle groups, leading to generalized muscle wasting.

  • Gowers' Sign: This is a classic sign where the child uses their hands and arms to "climb up" their own body to stand up from a sitting or lying position due to weakness in the hip and thigh muscles.

  • Calf Muscle Pseudohypertrophy: The calves often appear large and muscular due to the replacement of muscle tissue with fat and fibrous tissue, a phenomenon called pseudohypertrophy.

  • Elevated Creatine Kinase (CK) Levels: Blood levels of CK, an enzyme released by damaged muscles, are significantly elevated in DMD patients, sometimes up to 10-100 times the normal range, even before symptoms appear.

  • Cardiac and Respiratory Complications: As DMD progresses, it affects the heart muscles, leading to cardiomyopathy and heart failure. Respiratory muscles also become weak, leading to breathing difficulties and an increased risk of respiratory infections, typically in the teenage years or early adulthood.



    Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3281-3284

questions.text: Newborn with meningomyelocele has been listed for surgery. The defect should be repaired right away with:
questions.solution:
Meningomyelocele is a caudal NTD which requires prompt and correct management from a skilled team in order to improve the chances of survival.
  • Surgical correction should be performed within 48 hours of delivery, and the infant should be placed in a prone position with a non-adherent, sterile saline dressing and a plastic shield wrap in order to maintain moisture and protect the defect from drying, trauma, and infection.Saline dressing helps to keep the exposed neural tissue moist and prevents infection while minimizing irritation
  • Early treatment and support will provide the best chance of recovery.



Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3066-3068

questions.text: In a child of Rett syndrome, all of the following are seen except:
questions.solution:
• Rett syndrome is a neurodevelopmental disorder caused due to MECP2 gene mutation that begins soon after birth and manifests around 1-2 years of age.
  • Its almost exclusively seen in females.
  • It is characterized by a neurodevelopmental regression(slowing of cognitive, social, and physical development) sudden behavior changes, and repetitive hand movements/autistic behavior.
  • Other features include seizures, slowed head growth causing microcephaly (NOT Macrocephaly as mentioned in option 1), difficulties with motor coordination, and scoliosis.
  • Trofinetide(Tripeptide - (Gly - Pro - Glu) - analog of the neuropeptide (1-3) IGF-1) is a new drug used for its treatment.

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3192,3193

questions.text: An abnormality was discovered during a routine ultrasound performed at 20 weeks of gestation on a pregnant 31-year-old woman. The patient requests a second opinion from you and brings the following ultrasound film. What birth defect would you describe to the couple?
questions.solution:
Anencephaly is a severe congenital condition in which a large part of the skull is absent along with the cerebral hemispheres of the brain.
  • On ultrasound, the cranial vault (bony calvarium) is symmetrically absent.
  • A "Frog-eye" or "Mickey mouse" appearance may be seen in coronal plane due to absent cranial bone and/or brain & bulging orbits.

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3068

questions.text: The most common cause of meningoencephalitis in children:
questions.solution:
• Correct Option is 4: Enterovirus Enteroviruses are the most common cause of meningoencephalitis worldwide.
  • Option 1 – Mumps : Mumps is caused by the paramyxovirus of the genus Rubulavirus spreads through respiratory droplets characteristic symptoms of mumps include swelling and tenderness of one or both parotid glands Complications : orchitis, oophoritis, meningitis, encephalitis, pancreatitis and deafness
  • Option 2 : arbovirus family transmits infection from mosquitoes, ticks or other arthropods to humans includes dengue, West Nile fever, Japanese encephalitis, eastern and western equine encephalitis.
  • Option 3 : HSV encephalitis is the most common cause of sporadic encephalitis in the world

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3232-3234

questions.text: Which of the following best marker for having neural tube defects
questions.solution:
• NTD occurs due to failure of closure of the Neuropore.
  • Antenatal diagnosis of NTD is usually done by USG at 14-16 weeks of gestation. The earliest it can be done by USG is at 10-12 weeks.
  • Maternal serum markers can also be used for diagnosis While Acetylcholine esterase and Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) both indicate NTD, Acetylcholine esterase is the most specific and best marker.
  • Acetylcholinesterase is an enzyme that is primarily found in nerve tissue. In the case of neural tube defects, the protective layer around the neural tissue may be compromised, allowing AChE to leak into the amniotic fluid.
  • Detecting elevated levels of AChE in amniotic fluid can, therefore, be indicative of NTDs.

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3064,890

questions.text: A 6-year-old baby was brought to the emergency department with Lower limb tenderness for 2 days and h/o fever, sore throat, and cough for the past 5 days. there is no abnormality currently except for pain on pressing the muscles. CNS examination and reflexes are normal. CK level is 2000. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is viral myositis. 

Option B- Normal reflexes and no significant motor weakness rule out GBS.

Option C- There are no cutaneous indications to support dermatomyositis, but dermatomyositis wouldn't have muscle discomfort either.

Option D- DMD doesn't manifest at this age and will have a far higher CPK level.


Reference:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5429052/

choices.text: Scalp EEG is diagnostic of frontal lobe epilepsy
10% of healthy people have epileptiform waves on EEG
EEG is mandatory for diagnosis of epilepsy
In progressive multi-focal Leucoencephalopathy lateralised epileptiform waves are seen

questions.text: Which of the following assertions about EEG is correct?
questions.solution:
5-10% of healthy people can have epileptiform waves on EEG.

Option 1 : Scalp EEG is used in the diagnosis of frontal lobe epilepsy, it is not diagnostic for frontal lobe epilepsy.

Option 3 : EEG is not mandatory for diagnosis of epilepsy. 

Option 4 : In progressive multi-focal leucoencephalopathy, diffuse slow waves are seen on EEG.

 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3063
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK563295/

questions.text: Neonatal seizures can be induced by which vitamin deficiency:
questions.solution:
Vitamin deficiency causing neonatal seizure is Pyridoxine.
  • Glutamate is an excitatory neurotransmitter increases the chances of seizure.
  • It is metabolized into GABA, which is inhibitory for the seizure by an enzyme called GAD (glutamic acid decarboxylase)
  • Vitamin B6 or pyridoxine is a coenzyme for GAD.
  • Therefore deficiency of pyridoxine can lead to accumulation of glutamate, which causes neonatal seizure.

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 118,119,553

questions.text: A 7-day-old infant has a leaky meningomyelocele. Which of the following is the most useful for the diagnosis and management of this condition?
questions.solution:
• Infants with leaking meningomyelocele are at risk of meningitis.
  • Ideally CSF study should be done, since its not given in the option, the best answer would be wound culture.
  • Open meningomyelocele and with leaking CSF provides a portal of entry for bacteria and predispose the patient to the development of infection.


Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3066-3068

questions.text: A newborn presents with congestive heart failure and, on examination, has bulging anterior fontanelle with a bruit on auscultation. Transfontanellar USG shows a hypoechoic midline mass with dilated lateral ventricles. What will be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• I’m Midline hypoechoic mass with dilated lateral ventricles (on USG), bruit on auscultation, hydrocephalus and high output cardiac failure in neonates/infants is diagnostic of vein of Galen malformation.
  • Vein of Galen malformation is characterized by aneurysmal dilatation and arteriovenous malformation of Galen. 
  • It most commonly presents in the neonatal period.







Reference: Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3215
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5296625/

questions.text: Certain diseases are brought on by delayed neuronal migration and organization. Which of the following scenarios has the lowest probability?
questions.solution:
• Delayed neuronal migration and organization leads to certain disorders. Least likely possibility is focal cortical dyplasia without balloon cells.
  • Neuronal migration disorders are characterized by defective movements of neurons from the place of origin along the lining of lateral ventricle, to the eventual place of residence in the correct laminar position within the cerebral cortex.
Types of neuronal migration disorders- •Schizencephaly
•Lissencephaly (Agyria): Smooth brain; characterized by the absence of cerebral convolutions.
•Pachygyria
•Polymicrogyria
•Heterotopia



 

Reference:Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3068-3070,3275

questions.text: You have been contacted to declare a 12-year-old child in the PICU brain dead. All of the following indicate brain death, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Guidelines to determine brain death
 1)Clinical criteria- Complete loss of consciousness, vocalization and volitional activity.
 2)Absent brainstem reflexes- Absence of papillary responses of light, oculocephalic
  reflexes, oculovestibular response, corneal reflex, jaw reflex, facial grimacing to deep      
  pressure on supraorbital ridge or temporomandibular joint, pharyngeal gagreflex, coughing    
 in response to tracheal suctioning, sucking and rooting reflexes.
  3)Apnea- Absence of respiratory drive at paCO2 of 60 mm Hg or 20 mm Hg above 
   baseline. 
  Prerequisites:a)Clinical and/or neuro imaging evidence of acute catastrophe severe enough to explain the condition.   
   b)Core temperature more than 32°C",No drug (sedatives, narcotics) or alcohol intoxication, poisoning
   or neuromuscular blockade

    c)Normal blood pressure
     d)No confounding conditions such as severe electrolyte, acid-base, metabolic or endocrine
  disturbances
                Two evaluations, separated by a time interval of 48 hours, if <2 month  old; 24 hours, if 2-12 months old; 12 hours, if 1-18 years old; and at any  interval, if > 18 years old.
  Ancillary Test:Two tests required if <2-month-old; one test if 2-12-month-old;
 tests optional if >1 year old.
                   1)Cerebral angiography
                   2)Electroencephalography
                   3)Transcranial Doppler ultrasonography
                   4)Cerebral scintigraphy

 
  • Decorticate and decerebrate posturing are not signs of brain death because they are reflexive responses that can be present in brain-injured patients who remain clinically alive.
  • Decorticate posturing is an abnormal flexed posture of the arms, hands and legs that can occur during a coma or vegetative state due to brain damage or diseases that cause a coma.
 
  • Decerebrate posturing is an abnormal posture of the arms, legs and trunk in which the arms are held outward and the legs are extended and held rigid. Both of these posturing responses occur when the neural pathways connecting the brain to the pyramidal tracts are disrupted, which can occur in the absence of death.


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 580

questions.text: A young teenager complains that she frequently drops things out of her hands, especially in the morning and before exams. Her cousin sister has been given an epilepsy diagnosis, but there is no history of loss of consciousness. The results of the EEG examination pointed to epileptic spikes. What is the ruling?
questions.solution:
• Most likely, due to the fact that Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy tends to appear in early adolescence, with reports of a family history of epilepsy, most likely in the morning after awakening and may be caused by sleep deprivation, the diagnosis would be Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3098,3102

questions.text: Meningitis in children is most commonly caused by:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Enterovirus 
Important causative organisms related to Meningitis in children:
  • Pyogenic Meningitis – Streptococcus pneumoniae; < 2 months age – E.coli
  • Tuberculosis
  • Viral meningitis/ Aseptic meningitis -Enterovirus(worldwide); Japanese Encephalitis(India )
Thus, among the given options, Enterovirus is the most common organism of Meningoencephalitis in children.




Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine Edition 21st Page No 1107

questions.text: A child born by normal vaginal delivery, had brief attacks of contraction of neck and trunk. There are jerky movements of hands as well. The episode is followed by crying. EEG showed hypsarrhythmia. Best drug to manage such a case:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with EEG findings of hypsarrythmia is suggestive of West Syndrome.
The drug of choice for West syndrome is ACTH. 

Note- Drug of choice for West Syndrome when associated with tuberous sclerosis is Vigabatrin. 


EEG features of seizure disorders-

1. Lennox Gastaut syndrome- 1.5-2 Hz spike and polyspike bursts

2. Absence Seizures- 3 Hz spike and dome pattern

3. Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy- 4-5 Hz spike

4. West Syndrome-Hypsarrythmia- high voltage waves with chaotic background ( Tall Himalayan Waves ) 



Reference: Essential Pediatrics by O.P Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 555, 556.

questions.text: ACTH is the drug of choice for which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
ACTH is considered the drug of choice for West Syndrome. 
The triad of infantile spasms, hypsarrhythmia, and developmental regression together is termed as West Syndrome.





Reference: Nelson Textbook Of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page no 3098,3103,3104 .

choices.text: Febrile seizures can have post ictal neurological deficit
Simple febrile seizures occur in children between six months to 5 years of age.
Anticonvulsants prophylaxis is usually not indicated in simple febrile seizures
Simple febrile seizures do not last for more than 15 minutes

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding febrile seizures?
questions.solution:
Option (1) is a False statement.

Febrile seizures are seizures that
  1. Occur in children between the age of 6 months and 5 years
  2. Occur at a temperature of 38°C (100.4°F) or higher
  3. Are not due to any CNS infection or any metabolic imbalance
  4. Occur without a history of prior afebrile seizures
  5. Occur with no post-ictal neurological deficit.
Hence, option (1) is a false statement.

Other options

Option (2) - True - febrile seizures are seizure which occur post fever as a trigger in children between 6months - 5 years. 

Option (3) - True - simple febrile seizure do not require anti-convulsant prophylaxis in most cases. Intermittent prophylaxis with clobazam is indicated in few cases if (a) febrile seizures are too frequent (>3 episodes in 6 months/>4 episodes in 12 months),(b) if there is excessive parental anxiety or (c) if the first episode occurred in a child less than 12 month. 

Option(4) - True - simple febrile seizures last for less than 15 minutes, are GTCS in nature and do not reoccur with 24 hr of first seizure. 

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th Edition, Page No 3092-3094.

questions.text: What would be the MRI finding in a child with spastic diplegia?
questions.solution:
• Spastic diplegia is commonly seen in premature infants with a history of birth asphyxia.
  • It is second most common type of cerebral palsy in india after spastic quadriplegia.
  • Brain MRI shows scarring and shrinkage in the periventricular white matter with compensatory enlargement of the cerebral ventricles, called periventricular leukomalacia.
  • Multicystic encephalomalacia is the MRI finding seen in children with spastic quadriplegia.
Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page No 3169.

questions.text: Which of the following is a new drug approved by the FDA for the treatment of Rett syndrome?
questions.solution:
Trofinetide is a newly FDA-approved drug for treating Rett syndrome. While the exact mechanism of its therapeutic effects in patients with Rett syndrome remains unclear, trofinetide is a synthetic analog of the amino-terminal tripeptide of insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1). It is designed to address the core symptoms of Rett syndrome by potentially reducing neuroinflammation and supporting synaptic function through the protein fragment glypromate (GPE).

IGF-1 is produced by both major brain cell types—neurons and glia—and is essential for normal brain development and the brain‘s response to injury and disease. Trofinetide has been found to inhibit the production of inflammatory cytokines, reduce the overactivation of microglia and astrocytes, and increase the availability of IGF-1 for binding to IGF-1 receptors.

Indicated specifically for the treatment of Rett syndrome, trofinetide‘s adverse effects can include diarrhea, vomiting, fever, seizures, anxiety, decreased appetite, fatigue, and nasopharyngitis.

 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 292-293 .

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presented with sudden onset of high-grade fever, seizures, and loss of consciousness. On examination, the child had anaemia, hypoglycemia, and no neurological deficits. What is the probable diagnosis
questions.solution:
In this scenario, a patient presents with the hallmark signs of cerebral malaria, which is a severe complication of Plasmodium falciparum infection.
Known for causing significant morbidity, severe complicated malaria manifests in various ways, including jaundice, severe anemia, respiratory distress, bleeding, cardiovascular collapse, renal failure, and most notably, cerebral malaria.

Cerebral malaria occurs when P. falciparum parasitemia affects the brain, leading to altered consciousness. The patient might experience seizures, hypoglycemia, and even show neurological findings such as hemiplegia, abnormal deep tendon reflexes, or a positive Babinski sign. In some cases, retinal hemorrhages are also observed.

The treatment for all patients presenting with severe malaria is swift and precise: intravenous or intramuscular artesunate is administered for at least 24 hours to manage the infection.

Interestingly, the symptoms of meningitis might be confused with cerebral malaria due to the shared presence of fever and neurological involvement. However, meningitis often features signs of meningeal irritation, such as the Kernig sign—pain felt when extending the leg after flexing the hip—and the Brudzinski sign, where passive flexion of the neck leads to involuntary bending of the knees and hips.

In both cases, early recognition and prompt treatment are key to improving outcomes.

questions.text: 10-month-old boy who is a known case of cerebral palsy, was brought to the OPD for a routine check-up. The child had a past history of weakness in both upper and lower limbs which improved with time. On examination, residual weakness is present more in the lower limbs and trunk as compared to the upper limbs. What is this condition called?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with cerebral palsy, who has residual weakness in his lower limbs as compared to his upper limbs is highly suggestive of spastic diplegia.
Spastic diplegia is more commonly seen in premature infants with a history of birth asphyxia due to damage to immature white matter. It is 2nd most common type of cerebral palsy in India after spastic quadriplegia. Both the lower limbs are involved. During development, characteristic commando crawling is seen. Brain MRI shows scarring and shrinkage in the periventricular white matter with compensatory enlargement of the cerebral ventricles. IQ of these children is usually normal and has a good prognosis. Ref- Nelson textbook of pediatrics 21st edition Page 342

questions.text: An infant was brought to the OPD with complaints of poor feeding and irritability. On examination, neck rigidity was present. Her sister has been on antitubercular therapy for 2 months. What are the CSF analysis findings expected in this child?
questions.solution:
• The child presents with signs of meningitis and has a household contact on antitubercular therapy, suggesting tubercular meningitis (TBM).

  • Typical CSF findings in TBM:

    • Cell type: Predominantly lymphocytes

    • Sugar: Low (hypoglycorrhachia)

    • Protein: High (hyperproteinorrachia)

  • Other features may include elevated opening pressure and a gradual onset of symptoms.

Other options:

  • Neutrophils, low sugar, high protein: Seen in bacterial meningitis, not TBM.

  • Neutrophils, high sugar, low protein: Not consistent with meningitis.

  • Lymphocytosis, high sugar, low protein: Not consistent; TBM lowers sugar and raises protein.


Reference
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition - Page no:Page no. 1100, 1102, 1103, 1104, 1106, 1108, 1109, 1110, 1267, 1366

questions.text: Which of the following is the first-line drug used to control seizures in a child presenting with febrile seizures?
questions.solution:
Feature Simple Febrile Seizure Complex (Atypical) Febrile Seizure
Duration < 15 minutes > 15 minutes
Recurrence in 24 hours No Yes
Focal features Generalized (tonic-clonic) Focal signs (e.g. affecting one limb/side)
Postictal state Quick recovery, no neurological deficit May have prolonged postictal drowsiness or deficit
Age group 6 months to 5 years 6 months to 5 years
Underlying CNS abnormality Absent May be present or suspected
Risk of epilepsy later Slightly increased (1-2%) Higher (5–10% or more)
Need for neuroimaging/EEG Not required Often indicated
Hospitalization Usually not required May be required

  • A seizure occurring in a child aged 6 months to 5 years associated with fever, but without evidence of CNS infection or prior afebrile seizures.

  • Most are generalized tonic-clonic and last less than 15 minutes (simple febrile seizures).

    Management of a febrile seizure

    If the child is actively seizing:

The first-line drug for acute seizure control in a febrile child is a benzodiazepine.

First-line drugs:

Drug Route Use
Midazolam Buccal, intranasal, IM First-line if IV access not available
Lorazepam IV Preferred if IV access available
Diazepam IV, rectal Alternative if midazolam not available
 
Option Role in febrile seizure management
1. Midazolam First-line drug for acute seizure control in febrile seizures (esp. intranasal/buccal)
2. Phenytoin Used for status epilepticus, not first-line in febrile seizures
3. Sodium valproate Not first-line for acute control; used in seizure disorders, not febrile seizures
4. Phenobarbitone Older drug, sedating; not first-line; may be used in neonatal seizures, not febrile seizures

Summary: 

  • Midazolam (buccal/intranasal) is safe, fast-acting, and easy to administer without IV access.

  • Therefore, it is the first-line drug for acute control of febrile seizures.


Reference:Nelson textbook of pediatrics 21st edition Page no 3092-3094

questions.text:
At the age of 10 months, a male infant with coarse facial characteristics, macroglossia, and thick lips comes with profuse nasal discharge.
At birth, the infant was entirely healthy. Upon inspection, it was discovered that his liver and spleen were enlarged. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• A male child with coarse facial features, macroglossia, thick lips presents with copious mucous discharge from nose at 10 months of age.
  • The child was absolutely normal at birth. On examination he was found to have an enlarged liver and spleen. Diagnosis is Hurler's syndrome.

  •  

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 812

questions.text:
A 7-month-old baby who had previously vomited and struggled to grow was examined. With the help of intravenous glucose, the patient recovered and emerged from a coma in less than 24 hours. He returned a month later with the same complaints. Following an examination, he is found to have elevated blood ammonia and no ketones.
He also exhibits high urine levels of uracil, alanine, and glutamine. What enzyme deficiency does this patient most probably have?
questions.solution:
• Ornithine transcarbamoylase.
  • The recurrent symptoms with raised ammonia levels point towards the diagnosis of a Urea cycle defect
  • The most common urea cycle defect is due to deficiency of the enzyme Ornithine transcarbamoylase.
  • OTC deficiency is an X-linked recessive disorder, primarily affecting males, though females can be affected in varying degrees due to lyonization (random X-inactivation).
  • Pathophysiology: The deficiency of the OTC enzyme impairs the conversion of carbamoyl phosphate and ornithine into citrulline, leading to the accumulation of ammonia in the blood.
  • Hyperammonemia: Accumulation of ammonia can lead to symptoms such as:
    • Vomiting
    • Lethargy
    • Seizures
    • Coma
    • Neurological impairment
  • Symptoms in newborns: Often present within the first few days of life with severe symptoms.
  • Late-onset: Some individuals may have a later onset of symptoms, often triggered by illness, stress, or high protein intake.


Reference:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK537257/

questions.text: A little child was treated with aspirin for a viral infection. The child was taken to the emergency room three days later with altered sensorium and icterus. What biochemical flaw is causing this?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical scenario described above - viral infection treated with aspirin followed by hepatic dysfunction- Reye's syndrome is the most appropriate diagnosis. It occurs in case of administration of aspirin in children with viral infection. Hence, aspirin should be avoided in a child with fever. Reye's syndrome causes widespread mitochondrial dysfunction particularly defective beta-oxidation of fatty acids that takes place in mitochondria.
 


 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2126,3178,739

questions.text:
After moderate exertion, a 10-year-old kid develops hypoglycemia quickly.
A blood test reveals elevated amounts of ketone bodies, lactic acid, and triglycerides. The liver and kidneys were found to be enlarged during the assessment.The histopathology of the liver reveals excessive glycogen accumulation.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Von-Gierke's disease is strongly suggested by a history of hypoglycemia following moderate exertion, elevated levels of ketone bodies, lactic acid, and triglycerides on blood testing, enlarged liver and kidneys, and excess glycogen deposits in the liver.
  • Von Gierke's disease is a glycogen storage disorder which occurs due to deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase.
  • Glycogen is normally broken down into glucose to give you more energy when you need it. This process is impaired in this disease. 
     
 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 1146,778,779

questions.text: A toddler who bit his fingers, had delayed motor development, and was mentally retarded was brought in. His birth was normal. Then, at the age of 25, he passes away from renal failure after developing cerebral palsy arthritis. What enzyme deficit is most likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
• Self-mutilation behaviour is frequently observed in Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, which is brought on by a lack of HGPRT.
  • Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome : HPRT deficiency is a rare X-linked impairment of purine metabolism.



 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 819

questions.text: All of the following conditions are eligible for enzyme replacement therapy except?
questions.solution:
ERT(Enzyme Replacement therapy) is not yet available for Sanfilippo disease (option 3) - hence, that is the answer.

Enzyme replacement therapy is available for the following diseases
 
  1. Gaucher's (Glucocerebrosidase)
  2. Pompe's (Lysosomal Acid Maltase)
  3. MPS I -Hurler disease (Alpha- Iduronidase)
  4. MPS II - Hunter disease (Iduronate Suplhatase)
  5. MPS IV-A - Morquio A (Galactosamine-6-sulfatase)
  6. Fabry's  (α-galactosidase A)
It is not yet available for San-filippo disease/Metachromatic leucodystrophy/Tay -Sachs/Neiman Pick/Krabbe's disease. 
 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 566,654

questions.text: A young child has been diagnosed with albinism. For what reason should he be assessed?
questions.solution:
• Any albinic child should be evaluated for eye consultation as Generalised albinism can further be divided into ocular or oculo-cutaneous.
  • Eye manifestations of albinism include foveal hypoplasia with reduced visual acuity, refractive errors, nystagmus, alternating strabismus and a red reflex of the iris during examination.
  • Additionally, albinism affects the melanin present in the cochlea, making those with albinism more susceptible to ototoxic agents such as aminoglycoside antibiotics.

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3477,3478,3343

choices.text: Growth plate healing is seen on X-ray
Bone specific alkaline phosphate levels become normal

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with rickets is on calcium supplements and is also suffering from congenital Talipes equinovarus (CTEV). The child will be referred to a surgeon for the correction of the deformity when:
questions.solution:
• The medical management of rickets, comprising vitamin D and calcium supplements in appropriate doses, must be employed prior to considering surgery, as success consequently relies upon the healing potential of rickets.
