  • Corrective osteotomy in rickets should only be done once after radiological healing has taken place[option 2] (i.e growth plate healing is seen on X-ray), otherwise the osteotomy will not unite due to defective mineralization. 

Other options

  • Option 1 (Vitamin D levels normal): Not reliable because vitamin D can normalize biochemically before growth plates fully heal.
  • Option 3 (Bone-specific ALP normal): ALP is a marker of osteoblastic activity but may remain elevated for some time, even after healing has started. It is not used as the deciding factor for surgery.
  • Option 4 (Serum calcium normal): Calcium often normalizes quickly with supplementation, but deformity correction is deferred until radiographic healing is evident.

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 112-116

questions.text: Which enzyme deficit is responsible for fish odour syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Monooxygenase 3 (FMO3)

Fish odour syndrome also known as primary trimethylaminuria occours due to the deficiency of Trimethylamine Oxidase (flavin monooxygenase 3 – FMO3).

The gene for FMO3 is located on chr 1q24.3.
 
  • Timethylamine is normally produced in intestine from the breakdown of dietary choline and trimethylamine oxide by bacteria.
  • Trimethylamine is absorbed and oxidised in the liver by trimethylamine oxidase to trimethylamine oxide which is odourless and excreated in urine.
  • Deficiency of this enzyme results in massive excretion of trimethylamine in urine which gives off a fish like body odour.
  • Treatment is done with oral activated charcoal, short courses of oral metronidazole, neomycin or lactulose cause temporary reduction in body odour
  • Restriction of fish, eggs, liver and other sources of choline in the diet is also helpful.


Reference:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3848652/

choices.text: Low serum ceruloplasmin and low urinary copper
Low serum ceruloplasmin and high urinary copper
High serum ceruloplasmin and low urinary copper
High Serum ceruloplasmin and high urinary copper

questions.text: Which is the accurate statement about Wilson's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Low serum ceruloplasmin and high urinary copper 
 
  • Wilson’s disease occours due to mutation in ATP 7b gene on chromosome 13q
  • Copper metabolism is impaired
  • Copper is absorbed from small intestine by DMT1
  • Inside the epithelial cells binds to metallothionien which sequesters copper. Enough metallothienin is present in children of less than 3 years and so Wilson disease is seen between 3-20 years of age.
  • Liver cells also carry the CMT1 protein, and metallothionein and ATOX1 bind it inside the cell, but here, ATP7B links copper to ceruloplasmin and releases it into the bloodstream, as well as removing excess copper by secreting it into bile.
  • In Wilson’s, Copper accumulates in the liver tissue; ceruloplasmin is still secreted, but in a form that lacks copper (termed apo-ceruloplasmin) and is rapidly degraded in the bloodstream. Thus ceruloplasmin levels are low.
  • This accumulation of copper in the liver causes oxidative damage by fentons chemistry which leads to chronic hepatitis, fibrosis and cirrhosis.
  • The liver also releases copper into the bloodstream that is not bound to ceruloplasmin. This free copper precipitates throughout the body, but particularly in the kidneys, eyes, and brain.
  • Clinical features
  1. Brain – copper deposits in the basal ganglia, globes pallidus and putamen leading to neuropsychiatric symptoms like bradykinesia, Parkinsonism, tremors, ataxia and dystonia.
  2. Eyes –  Kayser–Fleischer rings (KF rings) may be visible in the cornea of the eyes, the occur due to copper deposition in the descemet membrane.
  3. Kidneys – renal tubular acidosis
  4. Heart – cardiomyopathy and cardiac arrhythmias
  • Serum copper is low, which may seem paradoxical given that Wilson's disease is a disease of copper excess. However, 95% of plasma copper is carried by ceruloplasmin, which is often low in Wilson's disease. Urine copper is elevated in Wilson's disease.


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 322

questions.text: A patient complains of persistent knee pain and remains dissatisfied despite regular checkups. Additionally, their urine turns black when standing for sometime.. Which enzyme is likely deficient in this case?
questions.solution:
• Alkaptonuria is an inherited metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme homogentisic acid oxidase.
  • This deficiency prevents the proper metabolism of the amino acid tyrosine. This can cause an accumulation of substances known as homogentisic acid which can build up in tissues and cause damage.
  • Symptoms usually become apparent after the age of two and are usually limited to ochronosis (a darkening and hardening of connective tissue such as cartilage and ligaments) and arthritis.
 

Signs and symptoms of alkaptonuria include: 

-Darkening of the urine shortly after urination 

-Dark discoloration of cartilage and ligaments

-Joint pain 

-Reduced flexibility of the spine

-Grey or blue discoloration of the white of the eye

 
  • Diagnosis of alkaptonuria is usually done with a urine sample that is tested for an accumulation of homogentisic acid which is characteristic of the disorder.
  • Other tests may be used to confirm the diagnosis. These may include genetic testing to determine the presence of certain gene mutations, and enzyme testing to measure the activity of homogentisic acid oxidase.


 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 700,701

questions.text: What metabolic abnormality is seen in a newborn with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Hypochloremic Hyponatremic Metabolic Alkalosis.
 
  • The hypertrophic pyloric muscle causes gastric outlet obstruction which leads to recurrent vomiting. Hydrochloric acid(HCl) of stomach is vomited out, body becomes deficient in H+ ions resulting in Metabolic Alkalosis
  • Cl- ions are also lost leading to hypochloremia
  • To compensate for the metabolic alkalosis, kidney eliminates sodium bicarbonate ions in urine, which leads to decrease Na+ in the body stimulating RAAS.
  • Aldosterone acts on collecting duct and stimulates reabsorption of Na+ and in return secretion of K+ and H+ resulting in hypokalemia and paradoxical aciduria.
CHPS presents as projectile non-bilious vomiting 2-3 weeks after birth after feeding. Visible peristalsis from left to right followed by a lump in the epigastrium.

Investigation of choice for CHPS – USG

Diagnostic criteria
  1. Thickness >4mm
  2. Length of pylorus >16mm


Management: Ramstedts pyloromyotomy

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 274

questions.text: Deformed bones were present in a 4-year-old kid who also has a history of recurrent infections and belongs to a low SE status. Calcium levels were normal, but his PTH levels were high. There was low phosphate. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A child with a history of recurring infections/ poor SE status with normal Ca,low phosphate and high PTH suggests a nutritional deficiency of vitamin D (option 4) leading to rickets and hence, the deformed bones. 
In nutritional rickets, low Vit D3 leads to decreased Ca2+/PO4- absorption and leads to low phosphate(due to decreased phosphate absorption) and lowered Calcium levels initially which in turn stimulates the release of PTH and leads to high PTH (High PTH can make Ca2+ levels normal for a while). 

Other options
  • Vit D-dependent rickets will have similar biochemical parameters but also a history of resistance to Vit D supplementation. 
  • X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets will have low Phosphate but normal PTH. It will also have history of oligodontia/dental abscess which is not given in the question stem. 

The question stem with recurrent infection and low SE status points towards Nutritional deficiency rather than Vitamin D dependent Rickets/X linked Hypophosphatemic rickets



 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 112-114

choices.text: When vitamin D levels turn to normal
When growth plate healing is seen radio-graphically
When bone specific alkaline phosphatase is normal

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with rickets is on calcium supplements and has a foot deformity. When should a decision to undergo corrective surgery be made?
questions.solution:
According to Campbell Orthopedics - "The operation should be deferred until there is X-ray and other evidence that the rachitic process is over and that the osseous structures are normal"

Hence, corrective surgery should be undertaken when the growth plate healing is seen radiographically (option 2) - that is the best evidence of healing in rickets.  Presence of growth plate healing shows that endochondral ossification has normalized and bone remodeling can sustain the surgical correction.


Other options
  • Option 1 (Vitamin D levels normal): Not reliable because vitamin D can normalize biochemically before growth plates fully heal.
  • Option 3 (Bone-specific ALP normal): ALP is a marker of osteoblastic activity but may remain elevated for some time, even after healing has started. It is not used as the deciding factor for surgery.
  • Option 4 (Serum calcium normal): Calcium often normalizes quickly with supplementation, but deformity correction is deferred until radiographic healing is evident.

Reference-Campell Orthopedics 14th edition/ Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 112-114

questions.text: A child with hypoglycemia is not able to utilise glucose from glycogenolysis or gluconeogenesis. Which of the following enzymes does the child lack?
questions.solution:
Glucose-6-phosphate is deficient in this child.
 
  • Glucose 6-phosphatase is a key enzyme in both glycogenolysis (the breakdown of glycogen into glucose) and gluconeogenesis (the production of glucose from non-carbohydrate sources). A deficiency in this enzyme impairs the liver’s ability to release free glucose into the bloodstream, leading to hypoglycemia.
  • This condition is seen in Glycogen Storage Disease Type I (von Gierke's disease), where both glycogen breakdown and gluconeogenesis are impaired, resulting in severe fasting hypoglycemia.
  • Other Glycogen storage disorders include:

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 654

questions.text: Which of the chelating agent listed  below can be used to treat cystinuria?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Penicillamine

Some points about Cystinuria
  • AR genetic defect
  • Defect in the transepithelial  transport of cystine and other dibasic amino acids in the kidney
  • Stones form due to increase excretion of cystine which is poorly soluble at normal Urine pH.
  • These stones are resistant to extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy so Percutaneous surgery or Ureteroscopy are preferred techniques of stone extraction.
  • Medical preventative treatment is by high volume diuresis and urine alkalinization by Sodium Bicarbonate and/or potassium citrate
  • When these methods fail to prevent recurrence or dissolving pre-existing stones, sulfhydryl agents like D-penicillamine or Tiopronin are used which form highly soluble disulfides.
  • Frequent clinical and USG follow up is done to encourage patient compliance and assess efficacy of treatment.

  • Mechanism of Action:

  • Chelation of Cystine:

    • Penicillamine works by forming a stable complex with cystine, which increases its solubility in urine. This reduces the concentration of free cystine in the urine, thereby decreasing the risk of cystine crystal formation and stone development in the kidneys and urinary tract.

  • Reduction in Stone Formation:

    • By chelating cystine, penicillamine helps prevent the aggregation of cystine crystals into stones. This is particularly beneficial for individuals with cystinuria who are prone to recurrent kidney stones.

  • Urinary Excretion:

    • The penicillamine-cystine complex is excreted in the urine, which helps to reduce the overall cystine load in the body.

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 498

questions.text: 'Sweaty Feet' odour of urine is due to which of the following inborn errors of metabolism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Glutaric acidemia 

TABLE ON INBORN ERRORS OF METABOLISM VS URINE ODOURS :-




 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 694 table 102.11

choices.text: Acute hemolysis can be precipitated by fava beans
X-linked recessive disorder that does not affect homozygous females

questions.text: Which of the following is false with regards to G6PD deficiency?
questions.solution:
• Correct Option is 4: X-linked recessive disorder that does not affect homozygous females 
  • Since G6PD deficiency is X linked recessive, the females are thus carriers
  • Therefore, if the female is heterozygote then they won't be affected ; but if the female is homozygote they will have the disease. 
  • G6PD deficiency is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern, primarily affecting males. Females can be carriers and may have mild symptoms depending on X-inactivation.
  • G6PD is an enzyme that protects red blood cells (RBCs) from oxidative damage. Its deficiency makes RBCs more susceptible to oxidative stress, leading to hemolysis.
  • Hemolytic episodes can be triggered by certain factors, such as infections, certain medications (e.g., sulfa drugs, antimalarials), or consumption of fava beans (favism).
 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 338,654,641

questions.text: A child presents with the findings shown in the image below. What is the true statement regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
• This malnourished child with a distended abdomen likely has kwashiorkor, a condition caused by protein malnutrition.

• Kwashiorkor is a form of severe acute malnutrition (SAM) that primarily affects infants and young children, usually between the ages of weaning and five years old. It results from an overall deficiency in both protein and calories, but with a more pronounced protein deficit.

• The lack of proteins such as albumin, which helps maintain oncotic pressure in the blood, leads to extensive pitting edema that typically begins in the legs and feet, later spreading to the hands, face, and eventually becoming generalized.

• Skin changes over the swollen limbs include dark, cracked, peeling patches with pale areas beneath, forming patches of hyper- and hypopigmentation known as flaky paint dermatosis or crazy paving. The skin is prone to infections.

• The child's hair may appear dull, brittle, and sparse, and it can be easily pulled out. In dark-haired children, the hair may turn pale or reddish, and alternating bands of lighter and normal-colored hair, referred to as the flag sign, can appear.

• Children with kwashiorkor are often miserable, apathetic, and refuse to eat. They also show marked muscle atrophy and significant growth retardation.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric department with severe pain in the hands and feet. On examination, corneal Opacities and telangiectatic skin lesions on the thighs were observed. On further investigation, he is found to be deficient in a-galactosidase A enzyme. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Fabry disease is an X-linked lysosomal storage disorder caused by deficiency of α-galactosidase A.

  • Accumulation of globotriaosylceramide (Gb3) leads to:

    • Severe pain in hands and feet (acroparesthesia)

    • Telangiectatic skin lesions (angiokeratomas), often on the thighs or buttocks

    • Corneal opacities (cornea verticillata)

  • Diagnosis is confirmed by enzyme assay for α-galactosidase A.

  • Early recognition is important for enzyme replacement therapy.

Other options:

  • Tay-Sachs disease: Hexosaminidase A deficiency; presents with neurodegeneration and cherry-red spot in macula, not telangiectasias.

  • Niemann-Pick disease: Sphingomyelinase deficiency; causes hepatosplenomegaly and neurological regression, no corneal opacities.

  • Gaucher disease: Glucocerebrosidase deficiency; presents with hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, thrombocytopenia, not corneal or telangiectatic lesions.


Reference
Nelson textbook of pediatrics 21st edition - Page no 771-774

questions.text: Which of the following can be determined using a dried blood drop from an infant?
questions.solution:
Dried blood drop of an infant can be used to know inborn errors of metabolism with the help of tandem mass spectrometry.

Blood samples from infants can be screened using tandem mass spectrometry for the presence and quantities of amino acids, fatty acids, and other metabolites. A number of hereditary illnesses, including phenylketonuria, ethylmalonic encephalopathy, and glutaric acidemia type 1, can be diagnosed by abnormalities in metabolite levels.


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 645

questions.text: Which of the following given terms refers to the ability to methylate and acetylate a gene without changing the gene's actual content?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Epigenetics

The term Epigenetics means 'Epi'- above and 'genetics'- genes. Epigenetics is defined as the heritable changes in genetic expression without a change in the underlying DNA sequence.
The primary mechanisms of Epigenetics include



Option 2 : Translocation -  translocation: a transfer of a chromosomal segment to a new position, especially on a nonhomologous chromosome.

Option 3 : Inversion - a segment of DNA in the context of a chromosome that is reversed in orientation relative to a reference karyotype or genome.

Option 4 : Transduction - Transduction is the process by which foreign DNA is introduced into a cell by a virus or viral vector.

In all the other options the structure of chromosomes is changed which causes genetic alterations.


 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 680,681

questions.text: Which disease shown is in the karyotype?
questions.solution:
• The karyotype in the picture shows a partial deletion of chromosome 5p.
  • The Cri-du-chat syndrome is caused by a partial deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5.
  • Children that are affected suffer congenital cardiac problems, a cat-like cry, microcephaly, and mental impairment.


 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3075

questions.text: Determine the pedigree's inheritance pattern.
questions.solution:
The given inheritance pattern is X-linked recessive.
 
  • Only Males are affected - females are carriers as seen in the above pedigree suggesting X-linked recessive inheritance. 
  • A few well-identified clinical disorders like Hemophilia/ Color Blindness have X-linked recessive inheritance.
  • The Y chromosome is not homologous to the X, hence mutant X chromosome genes do not have matching Y chromosome alleles.
  • The male is said to be hemizygous for X-linked mutant genes as a result, and as a result, the male manifests these illnesses. 
  • Females are hemizygous - hence - act as carriers, and do not manifest the disease. 
The following table summarises identification points for various modes of inheritance: 
 




Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 640

questions.text: A five-year-old female child has odd coarse facial traits, an oversized head, hepatosplenomegaly, corneal clouding, a protruding abdomen, breathing problems caused by obstructive sleep apnea, and thickened heart valves. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Peculiar facial features, enlarged head, hepatosplenomegaly, corneal clouding, protuberant abdomen, breathing difficulty with obstructive sleep apnea, and cardiac valve thickening are suggestive of Mucopolysaccharidoses. 
  • Since the child is a female - it cannot be Hunter's disease since Hunter is inherited in an X-linked recessive manner. 
  • The likely diagnosis is Hurler's syndrome and it is characterized by a deficiency of alpha-L-iduronidase enzyme. 




Other options

Option 2 - Hunter's is also a MPS with similar features (coarse facial features, enlarged head, hepatosplenomegaly, protuberant abdomen, cardiac valve thickening etc ) but since its X-linked recessive - its seen only in Boys, not girls. Hunter also does NOT have corneal clouding. 

Option 3 -  Fragile X disorder - The most common inherited cause of intellectual disability and has features which include Long face, large ears, macroorchidism in males with developmental delay. It does not have coarse facial features or cardiac valve thickening. 

Option 4 - Tay Sachs occurs due to Hexosaminidase A deficiency and has neurodegeneration, developmental regression, hyperacuisis, cherry-red spot on macula but no organomegaly. 





Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 811,812

choices.text: Turner syndrome with the webbed neck is more likely to develop CVS defects than non-webbed neck
Coarctation of the aorta is more likely in non-webbed neck

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Turner's syndrome is correct?
questions.solution:
• Turner Syndrome with a Webbed neck is 3 times more likely to develop CVS abnormalities than a non-webbed neck.
  • The most common CVS defect in Turner's syndrome is the Bicuspid aortic valve followed by the Coarctation of the Aorta.
  • Turner syndrome is typically characterized by features such as short stature, webbed neck, and other physical abnormalities, but intelligence is usually normal. There may be some learning difficulties, but overall cognitive ability is not significantly impaired. 
  • Hence among options 1 and 3, 1 is better answer than option 3.

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 637,638

questions.text: Which of the following syndromes is not caused by uniparental disomy?
questions.solution:
• Prader Willi Syndrome - Hypotonia, feeding difficulties, Intellectual disability, hyperphagia, and obesity. Paternal deletion of chromosome 15 or uniparental disomy of maternal chromosome 15.
  • Angelman Syndrome - "Happy Puppets" - ataxia, seizures, developmental delay, frequent laughter. Maternal deletion of chromosome 15 or uniparental disomy of paternal chromosome 15
  • Russel Silver Syndrome - Characterized by Skeletal asymmetry in limbs, Small triangular forehead prominence, small chin, and incurved fifth finger (clinodactyly). One of the causes is maternal uniparental disomy 7, seen in 10% of cases.
  • Bloom Syndrome is not caused due to uniparental disomy but due to DNA repair defect. So, answer is 4


 

Reference:Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 676

questions.text: Which of the following syndromes is not associated with uniparental disomy?
questions.solution:
• Uniparental disomy is not related to bloom syndrome. Bloom syndrome is due to DNA repair defect. 
  • When both of a pair of chromosomes in a person with a normal number of chromosomes have been inherited from just one parent, the condition is known as uniparental disomy.
  • Uniparental disomy is linked to Angelman syndrome, Prader-Willi syndrome, and Russell-Silver syndrome.
  • Uniparental disomy and a genomic imprinting (chromosome 15) abnormality are the causes of the Prader-Willi and Angelman syndromes.
 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 634
 Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 676

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy complains of increasing muscle weakness. On examination, his calves are bulky and show muscle tightening. His serum creatine kinase levels are increasing with age. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The signs are indicative of Dystrophin deficiency causing Duchenne's Muscular dystrophy. Its other features include -

1. Progressive muscle weakness and wasting, beginning in the lower limbs.
2. Difficulty in ambulation due to leg weakness and contractures.
3. Abnormal gait and foot deformities, including contractures of the Achilles tendon and plantar fascia, toe walking, and hyperextension at the knees.
4. Low endurance, leading to fatigue and exhaustion early in physical activities.
5. Respiratory muscle weakness, leading to impaired pulmonary function.
6. Respiratory infections due to weak respiratory muscles.
7. Difficulty with fine eye movements
8. Cognitive deficits
9. Cardiomyopathy and progressive heart failure


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 589,590

questions.text: What is the most common cause of Down's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Maternal Nondisjunction

Maternal meiotic Nondisjunction of Chr 21 is cause of Down’s syndrome in 95% of cases. Downs is the most common trisomy.

Option 3 – Robertsonian translocation and Option 4 – mosaicism are also  included in genetic basis of trisomy 21.

The characteristic features of Down’s syndrome are :
 
Symptom.  Seen in % of people

Low muscle tone 80%
Narrow roof of mouth 76%

Flexible ligaments 75
Proportionally large tongue 75
Abnormal outer ears 70
Flattened nose 68
Separation of first and second toes 68
Abnormal teeth 60
Slanted eyes 60
Shortened hands 60
Short neck 60
Obstructive sleep apnea 60
Bent fifth finger tip 57
Brushfield spots in the iris 56
Single transverse palmar crease 53
Protruding tongue 47
Congenital heart disease 40
Strabismus ≈35

questions.text: Cystic fibrosis is inherited in autosomal recessive manner. One daughter of a normal couple has this condition. A new baby is now being considered by them. What chances are there that the sibling has the illness?
questions.solution:

questions.text: In which of these inheritance patterns given below are males more commonly affected than females?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: X-linked recessive

Males are more commonly affected than females in diseases which have X-linked recessive inheritance.
 
  • In X-linked recessive inheritance, the gene responsible for the disorder is located on the X chromosome.
  • Since, males have one X chromosome and females have two X chromosomes, the presence of a single copy of the mutated gene on the X chromosome in males is sufficient to cause the disorder.
  • In contrast, females need to have two copies of the mutated gene (one on each X chromosome) to be affected.
  • Since males have only one X chromosome, they have a higher chance of inheriting and expressing X-linked recessive disorders.
  • Females, on the other hand, have a second X chromosome that can act as a "backup" and may carry a normal copy of the gene, reducing the likelihood of exhibiting the disorder.
Examples of X-Linked Recessive diseases are
 
  1. Hemophilia A
  2. Hemophilia B (Christmas disease)
  3. Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD)
  4. Becker muscular dystrophy (BMD)
  5. X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA)
  6. Fragile X syndrome
  7. Lesch-Nyhan syndrome
  8. Hunter syndrome (Mucopolysaccharidosis II)
 

Reference - Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 640

  • 2. ATM gene on chromosome 13: This is incorrect. The ATM gene is located on chromosome 11, not 13.

questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: AD
If we study the following pedigree.
  • All 3 successive generations are affected which suggests Dominant disease.
  • Both male and female offspring are affected suggesting Autosomal inheritance
  • Male to male transmission is also present thus it cannot be an X-linked disease.
An autosomal dominant disease presenting with an early diastolic murmur in a young individual is most likely to be Aortic regurgitation.

questions.text: The karyogram below demonstrates a chromosomal defect. Location of the chromosome where the mutation has occurred is
questions.solution:
• Chromosome 13 is normally acrocentric, but in the given image - the arrow is pointed at the centromere located at the center of the chromosome showing a metacentric translocation defect. Hence, option(2) is the correct answer, not option(1).
  • Classification of chromosomes Depending on the position of the centromere, chromosomes are classified as—
  1. Metacentric: Both p and q are of equal size (p = q).
  2. Submetacentric: The q arm is slightly longer than the p arm (p < q).
  3. Acrocentric: The p arm is very small compared to the q arm (p <<< q).
  4. Telocentric: The p arm is completely absent. This type does not exist in humans.

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 631

choices.text: Ultrasound showing streak ovaries and a small uterus
Ultrasound showing hepatomegaly and altered echo texture

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is brought by her mother to the OPD. She worries about being shorter than her peers. Upon examination, the patient has webbed neck, shield-like chest, and ptosis on the right side. What would you expect to discover after evaluation?
questions.solution:
Girls and women are affected by the hereditary condition known as Turner syndrome.
  • Turner syndrome is brought on by an entirely or partially absent X chromosome.
  • Short stature, irregular periods, and lack of breast development are among the signs of Turner syndrome.
  • The majority of patients, who are often female, have streak ovaries, which can cause primary amenorrhea or premature ovarian failure. Usually, the ovaries initially develop correctly, but the egg cells die too soon, and the majority of the ovarian tissue deteriorates before delivery.
  • The majority of girls need hormone therapy to reach menarche and develop secondary sexual characteristics.
  • Although the ovaries will have streaks, the uterus, fallopian tubes, and vagina will all develop normally.

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 637,638

questions.text: The picture of a patients karyotype is shown below. Which of the following features can be seen in this karyotype?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Gynaecomastia and long arms

The above karyotypic study is showing 2 X chromosomes and one Y chromosome. This 47 XXY karyotypic abnormality is known as Klinefelter syndrome.
 
  • It is the most common sex chromosome aneuploidy
  • It is the most common genetic cause of infertility in males
  • Clinical features –
  1. Tall
  2. Absence of facial and body hair
  3. Small penis and testis
  4. Crypto-orchidism
  5. Gynaecomastia
  6. Male breast cancer
  7. Low IQ
  8. Increased risk of extragonadal GCT
All the other options like short wended neck, polydactyly and flat occiput are seen in Down’s syndrome.



Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 638

questions.text: Which of the following abnormalities is not found in Down's syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Deletion of chromosome number 21 is not seen in Down's syndrome.
  • Most of Down's syndromes have trisomy 21, so their chromosome count is 47.
  • In some cases of Down syndrome, the extra chromosomal material derives from the presence of a robertsonian translocation of the long arm of chromosome 21 to another acrocentric chromosome (e.g., 22 or 14).
  • Approximately 1% of Down syndrome patients are mosaics. usually having a mixture of cells with 46 and 47 chromosomes.
 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 635

choices.text: No need to worry as there is no increased risk

questions.text: What advice will you provide to the couple to prevent a child from being born with Down syndrome when one of the parents has a balanced translocation between chromosomes 15 and 21?
questions.solution:
• Advice given to the couple to prevent a child being born with Down's syndrome is (1)prenatal diagnosis and advice abortion
  • If any of the two parents is a 'balanced translocation' carrier to another chromosome (usually 13, 14, 15, 22) then the recurrence risk is about 1 in 8.
  • In the question, balanced translocation is present in one of the parents who has a translocation between chromosome 15 and 21.
  • Prenatal diagnosis and abortion will prevent a child being born with Down's syndrome.

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 659-662

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about trisomy 13?
questions.solution:
Bilateral microphthalmia is seen in Trisomy 13.

Important Head and neck features of Trisomy 13(Patau syndrome):

  • Microphthalmia
  • Cleft lip and palate
  • Microcephaly

Note: While rocker bottom feet can be seen in Trisomy 13, however- microphthalmia/cleft lip and other head/neck abnormalities are more characteristic of Trisomy 13 while rocker bottom feet are more characteristic of Trisomy 18(Edward Syndrome). Hence, option (1) is a better answer than option (3)



 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 638

questions.text: The following is not observed in cystic fibrosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Obstruction of sweat gland ducts

CYSTIC FIBROSIS à ONE OF THE MOST IMPORTANT TOPICS FREQUENTLY TESTED IN EXAMS:-
  • Autosomal Recessive inheritance
  • Defect in CFTR gene on chromosome 7 (  F508 )
  • Most common lethal genetic disease.
  • PATHOPHYSIOLOGY :- 
  • Normally CFTR encodes ATP gated chloride channel which is responsible for secretion of chloride ions in lungs and gastro intestinal tracts, and reabsorption of chloride ions in sweat glands.
  •  F508 deletion decreases secretion of chloride and water à Increase in intracellular chloride ions results in compensatory increase in sodium and water reabsorption à Thus thick mucus gets secreted in lungs and gastrointestinal tract. Increased sodium reabsorption leads to development of negative transepithelial potential difference.
  • DIAGNOSIS :-
  • Increased chloride ion concentration is Pilocarpine induced sweat test—Diagnostic
  • Increased Immunoreactive Trypsinogen in Newborn screening test
  • CLINICAL FEATURES :-
  • Recurrent Pulmonary Infections ( commonly by Staph aureus – children ; Pseudomonas -- adult )
  • ABPA, Bronchiectasis , Chronic Bronchitis
  • Nasal polyps
  • Pancreatic Insufficiency, Malabsorption , Steatorrhea , deficiency of fat soluble vitamins
  • INFERTILITY – MALES à Due to ABSENCE OF VAS DEFERENS ; FEMALES --. THICK CERVICAL MUCUS [ VV IMP –FREQUENTLY TESTED ]
  • TREATMENT :-
  • Multifactorial
  • Chest physiotherapy
  • Aerosolized Dornase Alfa—inhalation route
  • Pancreatic Enzyme Replacement Therapy
  • Combination of LUMACAFTOR OR TEZACAFTOR ( corrects misfolded proteins ) with IVACAFTOR ( opens chloride channels )

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 392,393

questions.text: What is the term for differentiating the expression of a gene based on the parent of origin?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Genomic imprinting
 
  • MOSAICISM – Presence of genetically distinct cell lines in the same individual
(Example – McCune Albright syndrome )
  • ANTICIPATION – Increased severity or earlier onset of disease in succeeding generations ( Example – Trinucleotide Repeat disorders )
  • NONPENETRANCE- It means that not all individuals with the disease shows the disease due to incomplete or non penetrance.

GENOMIC IMPRINTING :-
  • In this one gene copy is silenced by methylation while the other copy is expressed based on parent of origin.
  • Examples :- PRADER WILLI SYNDROME , ANGELMAN SYNDROME
 


[TRICK –
PRADER WILLI SYNDROME – PAPA KA BETA- PATERNAL GENE DELETED -Spoiled brat—only eats thus obese
ANGELMAN SYNDROME – ANGEL- MEANS MOTHER- MATERNAL GENE DELETED ]



Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 634

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about Noonan syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Abnormal Karyotype

The karyotype in Noonan syndrome is typically normal, 46,XX in females and 46,XY in males. Noonan syndrome is not caused by a chromosomal abnormality but by mutations in specific genes involved in the RAS-MAPK signaling pathway, most commonly in the PTPN11 gene



A few points to remember about NOONAN SYNDROME:-
  • Autosomal Dominant condition
  • Found in boys or girls with normal karyotype
  • Clinical Features include :-

-Short stature
-Webbed neck
-Low posterior hairline
-Congenital Heart Defects – Pulmonary stenosis, HOCM, ASD
-Delayed puberty in girls
-Cryptorchidism in boys




 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 398

questions.text: What is a possible cause of the darkening of urine after standing?
questions.solution:
The correct Option is 1: Alkaptonuria

 

HOMOGENTISATE OXIDASE – This enzyme helps in the conversion of Homogentisic Acid to Maleylacetoacetic acid.
ALKAPTONURIA –
  • Congenial deficiency of the Homogentisate oxidase enzyme leads to the accumulation of pigment-forming homogentisic acid which accumulates in the tissues.
  • Autosomal Recessive condition
  • Benign condition
  • Bluish black coloration of connective tissue, ear cartilage, sclera, synovium deposits (Ochronosis )
  • Urine turns black on standing because of prolonged exposure to air
  • Also causes debilitating arthralgias as homogentisic acid is toxic to cartilages.
  • TREATMENT – Nitisinone; Supplementation of vitamin c

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 700,701

questions.text: Which of the following statements about phenylketonuria is false?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is option (3) Excess Melanin

Phenylketonuria is characterised by the absence of enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase. This results in increase in levels of phenyalanine (hence, option 2 is true) and decrease in levels of tyrosine (hence, option 1 is true) - the product of phenylalanine conversion. Lack of tyrosine causes lack of melanin since tyrosine is a precursor of melanin (not excess melanin as given in option 3). Hence, option 3 is the false statement. 
PKU is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. (hence, option 4 is correct)



PHENYLKETONURIA:
  • Deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase enzyme.
  • Increase in Phenylalanine which in turn leads to increase in passage of phenylalanine through urine
  • Autosomal recessive inheritance.
  • Lack of Phenylalanine to leads to low tyrosine and hence, low thyroxine/ low melanin(which would lead to hypopigmentation) and low dopamine. 
  • Excess of phenylalanine gets converted into phenyllactate/phenylpyruvate/acetate which are toxic to brain causing clinical features like microcephaly and intellectual disability. 
  • Urine has musty odour due to excretion and presence of phenylalanine and its metabolites (phenylacetate in particular) 
  • Treatment includes - Avoid artificial sweetener aspartate; Decreased phenylalanine and Increased tyrosine in diet. 
 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 695

From the given pedigree we can interpret that in every generation the disease is only getting transmitted from a diseased female to her offspring. The disease is not getting transmitted from a diseased male to his offspring. Therefore, this pedigree describes Mitochondrial inheritance.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Mousy odor is seen in urine of patients with phenyl ketonuria
Reason (R): Decrease in serum levels of tyrosine, dopamine and norepinephrine
questions.solution:
• The musty or mousy odor of urine in phenylketonuria (PKU) results from the buildup of phenylalanine metabolites, such as phenylpyruvate, phenylacetate, and phenyl lactate.
 
  • PKU can cause reduced levels of tyrosine, which is normally produced from phenylalanine. Tyrosine is a precursor for catecholamines like dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine, so low tyrosine levels may lead to a deficiency in these neurotransmitters. However, this is not the cause of the mousy odor in urine.
 
  • PKU arises from a deficiency in the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase (in classic PKU) or defects in enzymes involved in tetrahydrobiopterin production.
  • These enzyme deficiencies hinder the conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine, resulting in elevated phenylalanine levels and low tyrosine levels.
  • The excess phenylalanine is converted into phenyl ketones (such as phenylpyruvate and phenylacetate), which are then excreted in the urine.



Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page no 695-698.

Lippincott Illustrated Reviews: Biochemistry, 7th edition, Page no 779-786.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of partial aneuploidy?
questions.solution:
• Cri du chat syndrome is a genetic disorder that occurs when a part of chromosome 5 is missing. (Deletion of short arm of chromosome 5). This condition is also known as 5p - (5p minus) syndrome.
 
  • The name "cri du chat" comes from the French term for "cry of the cat," which describes the distinctive cry that infants with this condition may produce.
 
  • Partial aneuploidy refers to a condition where there is an abnormal number of chromosomes, but only a portion of a chromosome is affected.



Reference: Cerruti Mainardi, Paola. “Cri du Chat syndrome.” Orphanet journal of rare diseases vol. 1 33. 5 Sep. 2006, doi:10.1186/1750-1172-1-33. URL: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC1574300/

questions.text: Congenital absence of seminal vesicles and Vas deferens is seen in which condition?
questions.solution:
• Congenital absence of seminal vesicles and vas deferens is typically seen in Cystic fibrosis (option 1).
 
  • Cystic fibrosis (CF) is a genetic disorder that affects various organs, including the lungs, pancreas, liver, and reproductive system. It is caused by mutations in the CFTR (Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator) gene present on chromosome 7. The CFTR protein is responsible for chloride conductance across the epithelium and for the production of mucus, sweat, and digestive fluids.
 
  • In males with cystic fibrosis, one common manifestation is the absence or bilateral aplasia (underdevelopment) of the seminal vesicles and vas deferens. This condition is known as Congenital Bilateral Absence of the Vas Deferens (CBAVD).


Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page no 2298.

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2896, 3001.

questions.text: Which of the following is most commonly seen only in females?
questions.solution:
• Rett syndrome is the only condition given above that is most commonly seen in females.(X linked dominant disorder)
  • Rett syndrome is a neurodevelopmental disorder that is caused by a mutation in the MECP2 gene.
  • It is characterized by a period of normal development followed by a regression in skills, including loss of purposeful hand use, repetitive hand movements, gait abnormalities, and intellectual disability. Rett syndrome is almost exclusively seen in females, with an estimated incidence of 1 in 10,000-15,000 live births.

Asperger syndrome, atypical autism, and classical autism are all neurodevelopmental disorders that can affect both males and females. However, males are more likely to be diagnosed with these conditions than females.



Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 1124, 1164, 1167, 1261.

questions.text: All of the following are associated with Downs syndrome, Except?
questions.solution:
Caudal regression is seen in infants of diabetic mothers , specially seen with Overt Diabetes.
Most specific anomaly in Diabetic mother - Caudal regression .
Most Common Anomaly - Ventricular septal defects > NTD
Most specific Cardiac anomaly - TGA



Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21th Edition, Page. No- 660.

questions.text: Choose the correct statements regarding Cystic fibrosis?
questions.solution:
Cystic fibrosis is charecterised by increased chloride levels in sweat and reduced chloride levels in Pancreatic juice.
Sweat Chloride level of >60mmol/l is diagnostic of CF.

* Extra Edge: 
  • Sweat electrolytes following pilocarpine iontophoresis continue to comprise an essential diagnostic element, with levels of chloride markedly elevated in CF compared to non-CF individuals.
  • The sweat test result is highly specific and served as a mainstay of diagnosis for many decades prior to availability of CFTR genotyping. Notably, hyperviscosity of eccrine sweat is not a clinical feature of the disease. Sweat ducts function to reabsorb chloride from a primary sweat secretion produced by the glandular coil.
  • Malfunction of CFTR leads to diminished chloride uptake from the ductular lumen, and sweat emerges on the skin with elevated levels of chloride. For the unusual situation in which both CFTR genotype and sweat electrolytes are inconclusive, in vivo measurement of ion transport across the nasal airways can serve as a specific test for CF and is used by a number of referral centers.
  • For example, elevated (sodium-dependent) transepithelial charge separation across airway epithelial tissue and persistent failure of isoproterenol dependent chloride secretion (via CFTR) represent bioelectric findings specific for the disease. Measurements of CFTR activity in excised rectal mucosal biopsies can also be obtained.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2178.

questions.text: A woman visits the gynaecology OPD for a scheduled ANC check-up. A 1st-trimester scan reveals that her child has anencephaly. This occurs due to the inability of neural tube closure at what weeks of intrauterine life?
questions.solution:
Anencephaly results from the incomplete closure of the neural tube, a type of neural tube defect (NTD) that occurs when the neural tube fails to close spontaneously between the 3rd and 4th week of in utero development.

Key Points about Anencephaly:
Detection: Anencephaly is one of the earliest detectable congenital defects, identifiable as early as 10 to 11 weeks of gestation. Screening can be done through maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP) estimation.

Radiological Signs of Anencephaly:
Frog Eye Sign: Characterized by the absence of the cranial calvaria and prominent orbits, resembling a frog's face.

Shower Cap Sign: The absence of the cranium can lead to the protrusion of disorganized brain tissue, resembling a shower cap, which results in a characteristic triangular facial appearance.

Prevention:
Neural tube defects can be prevented with preconceptional supplementation of folic acid. A dose of 4 mg daily is recommended for women with a history of NTDs in subsequent pregnancies. For women with no prior history, 400 μg of folic acid should be taken starting preconceptionally and continued throughout pregnancy.

questions.text: A teenager is brought to the OPD with history of amenorrhea. On examination, she is short statured, has a webbed neck, low hairline at the back of the neck. Further examination revealed widely spaced nipples. Karyotyping in this patient would reveal which of the following?
questions.solution:
The clinical features described are classic for Turner syndrome:

  • Short stature

  • Webbed neck

  • Low posterior hairline

  • Widely spaced nipples (shield chest)

  • Primary amenorrhea

Genetics:

  • Turner syndrome is caused by complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome, most commonly 45,XO.

  • Patients typically have normal female external genitalia but gonadal dysgenesis (streak ovaries), leading to amenorrhea and infertility.

Other options:

  • 46 XX: Normal female karyotype.

  • 47 XXX: Triple X syndrome — usually tall stature, normal fertility.

  • 47 XXY: Klinefelter syndrome — male phenotype with small testes, gynecomastia, infertility.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was presented with a history of chronic cough and foul-smelling stools. His sibling had similar symptoms and passed away a few years ago. A sweat chloride test and CFTR gene studies were conducted. The CFTR gene codes for proteins involved in the transport of:
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described suggests cystic fibrosis, an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator (CFTR) gene located on chromosome 7q. The CFTR gene encodes proteins involved in chloride ion transport across epithelial cells. The most common mutation is the F508 deletion.

CFTR encodes ATP-gated chloride channels found in the apical membranes of epithelial cells. These channels regulate ion flow across the epithelial membranes of sweat glands, respiratory airways, pancreatic ducts, and more. A defect in this gene results in high salt concentrations in sweat and thick secretions in the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts. Children with cystic fibrosis are prone to episodes of salt depletion due to excessive salt loss in sweat, leading to hypochloremic alkalosis and increased serum bicarbonate levels.

### Clinical Manifestations and Complications of Cystic Fibrosis:
- **Sinusitis and Nasal Polyps**
- **Respiratory Complications:**
- Accumulation of thick, sticky pulmonary secretions with abnormal mucociliary clearance leads to obstruction of small and medium-sized airways, causing respiratory compromise.
- The condition can be complicated by bronchiectasis and allergic bronchopulmonaryaspergillosis (ABPA).
- **Gastrointestinal Complications:**
- Thick and sticky exocrine secretions block pancreatic ducts, impairing enzyme production and flow.
- Destruction of the exocrine pancreas, fibrotic scarring, cyst formation, and loss of acinar tissue lead to fat malabsorption, steatorrhea, and fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies.
- Obstruction of intrahepatic bile ducts and parenchymal fibrosis can lead to hepatic insufficiency and focal biliary cirrhosis.
- Adults may develop distal intestinal obstructive syndrome, while neonates can present with meconium ileus.
- **Reproductive Complications:**
- Males often have infertility due to the congenital absence of the vas deferens and obstructive azoospermia.
- Females may experience infertility due to abnormal reproductive tract secretions.

### Diagnostic Criteria:
Cystic fibrosis is diagnosed when both of the following criteria are met:
1. **Clinical Presentation:**
- Symptoms affecting at least one organ system (respiratory, gastrointestinal, or genitourinary)
- Positive newborn screening
- Presence of a sibling with cystic fibrosis

2. **Evidence of CFTR Dysfunction:**
- Two positive sweat chloride tests obtained on separate days
- Identification of two CFTR mutations via genetic testing
- An abnormal nasal potential difference measurement

### Management:
Cystic fibrosis management requires a multidisciplinary approach. Treatment options include:
- **Lumacaftor:** An FDA-approved drug that corrects protein misfolding associated with the F508del mutation.
- **Ivacaftor:** A medication that potentiates CFTR channel opening and enhances ion transport.
- **Lung Transplantation:** Considered in cases of end-stage pulmonary failure.


Reference : Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page no 2282,2283,2285-2288,2292-2295 .

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought for complaints of short stature. His height is comparable with his parent's height and his bone age corresponds to his chronological age. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the case of a child presenting with short stature, whose height aligns with that of the parents and where the bone age is equal to the chronological age, the most likely diagnosis is familial short stature.

This child's height is considered normal relative to the genetic potential established by the parents' heights. Additionally, the child exhibits appropriate body proportions, a normal growth velocity, and has a bone age that matches the chronological age. Puberty is anticipated at the appropriate time, and the final height will likely fall within the expected target range.
 

Key features of Familial Short Stature (FSS):

  • Height is below the 3rd percentile.

  • Normal bone age.

  • Normal growth velocity.

  • Family history of short stature.

  • Final adult height is short but within the target parental height range.


The relationship between bone age and chronological age can be summarized as follows:

Bone age = chronological age in familial short stature.
Bone age > chronological age in cases of precocious puberty.
Bone age < chronological age in other conditions, such as constitutional delay, undernutrition, genetic disorders, and various endocrine causes.

Other options: 

  1. Constitutional delay of growth and puberty (CDGP)
    → Bone age delayed; often seen in boys, normal growth velocity.

  2. Growth hormone deficiency
    → Bone age is delayed, growth velocity low.

  3. Undernutrition
    → Bone age delayed, child typically has other signs like low weight-for-height, low BMI.

choices.text: Midline facial defects such a cleft palate

questions.text: A child is born with micrognathia, low-set ears, rocker-bottom feet, and congenital heart diseases. He had a characteristic finding of clenched fist with overlapping fingers. What are the other features associated with this condition?
questions.solution: Edwards syndrome, also called trisomy 18 syndrome, is an autosomal chromosomal disorder due to an extra copy of chromosome 18. Edwards syndrome is one of the autosomal trisomy syndrome, second in frequency only to trisomy 21. Trisomy 18 or Edwards syndrome is characterized by mental retardation, micrognathia, low-set ears, rocker-bottom feet, and congenital heart diseases. The most characteristic finding is a clenched fist with overlapping fingers: the index finger overlies the third and fourth fingers, while the fifth finger overlaps the fourth. It is also associated with polyhydramnios and a single umbilical artery.Ref- Nelson textbook of Pediatrics 20th edition page 611,615

questions.text: A 10 year old child presented with hypotonia, obesity, hyperphagia, delayed puberty, dysmorphic facial features and cognitive impairment with temper outbursts. What could be the possible diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) is a contiguous gene syndrome due to abnormal DNA methylation within the Prader-Willi critical region (PWCR) at 15q11.2-q13. It is characterized by severe hypotonia, poor appetite, and feeding difficulties in early infancy, followed in early childhood by excessive eating and gradual development of morbid obesity (unless food intake is strictly controlled).
- Motor milestones and language development are delayed.
-All individuals have some degree of cognitive impairment. -Hypogonadism is present in both males and females and manifests as genital hypoplasia, incomplete pubertal development.
These patients also develop a distinctive behavioral phenotype characterized by temper tantrums, stubbornness, manipulative behavior, and obsessive-compulsive characteristics.
textbook of pediatrics 21'st edition • Page no: 2926-2927

choices.text: 5 mg/dL, and his serum albumin level was 2.5 gm/L.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old child was seen with frothy urine, oliguria, and edema. He hasn't previously received any complaints like this. His urine was examined and revealed 3+ proteinuria, no RBCs or WBCs, and no casts. His blood creatinine level was 0.5 mg/dL, and his serum albumin level was 2.5 gm/L.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• A 10-year old child presents with edema, oliguria and frothy urine with no past history of similar complaints. On examination, urine is positive for 3+ proteinuria, no RBCs/WBCs and no casts, with serum albumin 2.5 glL and serum creatinine 0.5 mg/ dL, the most likely diagnosis is minimal change disease.
  • Main features of Nephrotic syndrome- Massive proteinuria, Hypoalbuminemia, Edema and Hyperlipidemia.
  • Most common cause of Nephrotic syndrome in children- Minimal Change Disease.

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 472

questions.text: A child with nephrotic syndrome develops acute kidney injury (AKI) following an episode of diarrhoea. The serum creatinine is 4.5 mg/dL. Which of the following is least likely to explain the AKI in this setting?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4 - Steroid-induced diabetes
 
  • AKI in Nephrotic Syndrome is multifactorial in origin. It is most often secondary to hypovolemia, nephrotoxic medications, and infections.
  • In the above case, diarrhoeal disease leading to water depletion/hypovolemia (option 2) is the likely cause of AKI. 
  • Excess Furosemide (option 1) leads to diuresis and is usually given to Nephrotic syndrome patients for edema control but since it leads to diuresis and water loss (hypovolemia) - it can also lead to the development of AKI. 
  • Renal vein thrombosis (option 3)- can occur in patients with nephrotic syndrome due to the loss of antithrombin III (ATIII) in the urine, which in turn leads to an increase in hyper-coagulability and can also be an important cause of AKI in a child with Nephrotic Syndrome. 
  • Steroid-induced diabetes is the least likely reason for the development of AKI in Nephrotic Syndrome since Diabetes leads to "Chronic" nephropathy, and very rarely would cause "Acute kidney injury". Development of Diabetes in a child with Nephrotic syndrome secondary to steroid intake too would take time and would NOT be an acute event

Reference - Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2769-2771,2742

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child presents with a painless lump on the right side of the abdomen detected incidentally on bathing by parents. Ultrasound revealed it to be a solid mass. On examination, his right arm and leg were found to be longer. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
• The right arm and leg were found to be longer in the child pointing towards hemihypertrophy. 
  • Hemihypertrophy is a known syndromic association (seen in Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome) and Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is associated with an increased risk of having Wilms Tumor. 
  • Wilms tumor is also known as Nephroblastoma - hence the correct answer is option (2).
  • Wilms tumor is the most common renal malignancy in children, usually presenting between ages 2 to 5 years. It often manifests as a painless abdominal mass and may be discovered incidentally or during a routine examination - similar to the given clinical scenario in the question. 


 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2681-2684

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate in the neonatal ICU develops seizures. Which of the following would be the next best investigation for the child?
questions.solution:
• Cranial ultrasonography is particularly practical in case of premature neonates in order to assess various features including ventricular size, presence of fluid-filled lesions, and indications of either haemorrhagic or ischaemic damage, in addition to charting how conditions may evolve.
  • Transcranial USG can be done in neonates due to presence of fontanelles. 
  • It is advantageous in this respect as it can be conducted at the bedside, less time consuming and no hazard of radiation exposure. 



Reference: AIIMS NICU Protocols 2 nd Edition page no 78

questions.text: 7-year-old child with steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome has developed corticosteroid toxicity and posterior subcapsular cataracts and uncontrolled hypertension. Which of the following is the best alternative for the treatment of the patient?
questions.solution:
• In patients with Frequent Relapsing Nephrotic Syndrome - Levamisole is the preferred steroid-sparing agent while MMF is the preferred agent in Steroid dependent Nephrotic syndrome
  • However, a 12-week course of Cyclophosphamide is preferred over Levamisole/MMF in patients with evidence of severe steroid toxicity (like the example given in question - cataracts and uncontrolled hypertension) or having compliance issues. Hence in the above question, option(2) is a better answer as compared to option (3).

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 476-477

choices.text: Reassure the parents and follow up after 6 months

questions.text: A 4 year old boy complains of wetting the bed. The youngster is calm during the day, and the issue only arises at night. The child's growth and development were typical. The urine specific gravity was normal. What should you do next?
questions.solution:
• Bed-wetting is considered normal till 5 years of age.
  • In a child with only night time bed wetting, when Urinalysis (to rule out infections) and Urine Osmolality (to rule out diabetes) are normal, only regular follow-up is required.
  • An anatomic abnormality requiring USG-KUB is unlikely. The decision on whether to start treatment should be guided by the degree of concern and motivation on the part of the child rather than the parents.

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 499,500

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl with no symptoms is discovered to have persistent hypertension. There is no noteworthy past, and a urine test results in normal results. Which among the following is most likely to be the cause?
questions.solution:
Option 2 is the correct option.
  • Renal parenchymal disease, is the most likely cause of persistent hypertension in a 7-year-old girl with no symptoms and normal urine test results.
  • Renal parenchymal disease refers to damage to the functional tissue of the kidneys, which can lead to hypertension. This type of kidney disease can be caused by a number of factors, including congenital abnormalities, infections, and autoimmune disorders.
  • Essential hypertension (option 1) is rare in children(unlike adults) and is usually diagnosed only after other causes of hypertension have been ruled out.
  • Polycystic kidney disease (option 3) is a genetic disorder that causes the growth of numerous cysts in the kidneys, leading to kidney failure. However, this condition is rare in young children.
  • Coarctation of the aorta (option 4) is a narrowing of the aorta, which can cause high blood pressure in the arms and head and low blood pressure in the legs. However, this condition typically presents with other symptoms such as leg cramps, cold feet, and weak or absent pulses, which are not mentioned in the question stem.

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2492

questions.text: A child is experiencing sporadic episodes of left flank pain. Ultrasonography shows a normal ureter and a dilated renal pelvis with cortical thinning. A 19% difference in kidney function was found. Among the following, which type of management is best:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2:  Pyeloplasty 

The presentation of normal ureter and a dilated renal pelvis is suggestive of PUJ obstruction. Anderson Hynes pyeloplasty is the treatment of choice for it.

Nephrectomy is done if the function of the obstructed kidney is less than 10%.






 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 501

questions.text: A young girl enters the room dribbling urine continuously. She does, however, urinate normally. According to her parents, she had never been completely dry since birth. What diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
• Case of ectopic ureter as the patient has continuous dribbling of urine.
  • IVU can be used for investigation
  • Re-implantation of the ectopic ureter is the definitive treatment.
 

Reference:Nelson textbook of pediatrics 21st edition Page no 2796, 2797, 2805-2807

questions.text: A patient comes in with headache and nausea. Upon evaluation, it was discovered that his blood pressure was 180/110 and that his K+ level was 2mEq/l. His ABG results indicated that he had metabolic alkalosis. Which syndrome might be the cause of this ailment?
questions.solution:
• The give history shows development of metabolic alkalosis, hypokalemia and hypertension which are suggestive of Liddle Syndrome (option 2).
  • It is due to the overactivity of epithelial Na+ Channel in the collecting tubule (due to gain of function mutations).
  • It is Autosomal Dominant in nature .
  • Due to gain of function mutations in ENa+C(sodium channel) - There is increased/excessive absorption of Na+ and H2O into circulation causing hypertension. To maintain the electro-neutrality in the tubule lumen due to excessive sodium absorption - there is excretion of K+ and and H+ into tubule(which then come in urine) resulting in hypokalaemia & metabolic alkalosis.

Other options
  • Gitelman and Bartter syndrome both have hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis but do not have high Blood pressure. Instead they have low blood pressure and present with failure to thrive. 
  • Gordon syndrome is pseudohypoaldosteronism- there is excessive activation of Na/Cl symporter in DCT leading to Excessive sodium absorption along with hypertension. This leads to less sodium being available for exchange with K+/H+ in collecting ducts leading to their retention and hence- hyperkalemia/metabolic acidosis. 
 



Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2970

questions.text: In chronic kidney disease, what is the acid-base abnormality?
questions.solution:
CKD causes Metabolic acidosis (option 2) by the following mechanisms - 

1. Decreased Excretion of Hydrogen Ions:
The kidneys are responsible for excreting excess H ions into the urine. In CKD, there is a reduction in the number of functioning nephrons, which decreases the kidney's capacity to excrete these ions. As a result, H accumulates in the bloodstream, leading to acidosis.

2. Impaired Bicarbonate Reabsorption:
Normally, the kidneys reabsorb bicarbonate from the urine. In CKD, the reabsorption capacity is impaired, leading to a decrease in serum bicarbonate levels. This results in a reduced buffering capacity for H ions in the blood.

3. Loss of Ammonium Excretion:
The kidneys also produce ammonium (NH) as a means of excreting H ions. In CKD, the ability to synthesize and excrete ammonia is diminished, leading to less H excretion and further acid retention.
 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 83

questions.text:
A 2-day-old child presents with a ballotable abdominal mass not crossing midline and h/o hematuria. Which among the following investigations should be carried out?
i. CT Abdomen
ii. CT Chest
iii. FNAC
iv. VMA assessment
questions.solution:
• Wilms tumor is the most likely diagnosis based on the child's examination and history(Ballotable mass + hematuria). Wilms tumor is the most common primary malignant renal tumor. 
  • Abdominal imaging studies such as CT of the abdomen are used to pinpoint the mass' intrarenal origin and distinguish it from abdominal masses such as neuroblastomas and adrenal masses. 
  • CT Chest is done to evaluate for metastatic lesions. (Lungs are the most common site of metastasis)
  • While typically imaging suffices for making a diagnosis - FNAC can be considered if the diagnosis is unclear. However, a biopsy is avoided as it upstages the disease. 
  • Urinary VMA is used for diagnosis of suspected Neuroblastoma - will not be sent in the case of suspected Wilms tumor as the mass is ballotable/not crossing the midline and CT Abdomen will further confirm the renal origin of the mass. (VMA is not sent in case of every abdominal mass - only if Neuroblastoma is suspected on imaging - it is sent)


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 609,610

questions.text: The following is not part of the classical triad of the hemolytic uremic syndrome:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Neurological symptoms 

Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome is a type of Thrombotic Microangiopathy commonly affecting children.
While neurological symptoms can occur in some cases of HUS, they are not a defining feature of the syndrome itself.
  • The most common cause is Shiga toxin producing E coli infection ( O157: H7)
  •  TRIAD of
  1. Thrombocytopenia
  2. Microangiopathic haemolytic anaemia
  3. Acute kidney injury
  •  CLINICAL FEATURES include the above Triad & bloody diarrhea
  • INVESTIGATION :- Normal PT & APTT – helps to differentiate from DIC
  • TREATMENT:- Supportive care

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 487,488

choices.text: Most common cause of Nephrotic Syndrome in children

questions.text: Which of the following statements about minimal change disease is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Remission is urine protein: creatinine ration>2
 
  • It is the most common cause of Nephrotic syndrome in children
  • Also known as Lipoid Nephrosis
  • CAUSES:- ( 4I)
-Idiopathic
-Infection
-Immunisation
-Immune stimulus
  • It has excellent response to steroids ( Prednisolone 60 mg/day )
  • Good prognosis
  • LIGHT MICROSCOPY- Normal glomerulus
  • IMMUNOFLUORESCENCE – Absent
  • ELECTRON MICROSCOPY -Effacement of podocytes
  • REMISSION –
-Complete remission :- Reduction in proteinuria to <300 mg/day, stable serum creatinine, and serum albumin >3.5 g/dL.
-Partial remission –  Reduction in proteinuria of >50 percent, with absolute values between 300 mg and 3.5 g/day.


 

Reference:Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10 edition Page 898

questions.text: When does the kidney reach adult GFR?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2:  1-2 year

The GFR of a newborn gradually increases after birth and attains the adult vale of GFR at the age of 1-2 years.
GFR again progressively starts decreasing after the age of 40 yrs.


 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2715

choices.text: Light microscopy shows effacement of foot processes

questions.text: A 10 years old male child presented initially with periorbital edema and anasarca, later on. A clinical diagnosis of minimal change disease was made. Which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
The true statement among the following options is option 3- Steroid Responsive. 

Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children.


Other options:
 
  • Option 1- Minimal change disease is characterized by selective proteinuria with loss of albumin, transferrin and ferritin.  
  • Option 2- Commonly seen in children. 
  • Option 4- Light microscopy of minimal change disease is normal. Effacement of foot processes is a finding on electron microscopy. 


Reference: Essential Pediatrics by O.P Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 472.

questions.text: A 9 years old child presented to the Pediatrics OPD with the complaints of colicky abdominal pain and melena. On examination, palpable purpura was noted over buttocks and legs. Such a case should be treated by:
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Henoch Schonlein's purpura.
  • Glucocorticoids are used in the treatment of HSP. 

It classically involves the following systems-

1. Skin- Palpable purpura-lower extremities, buttocks.

2. Joints- Arthralgia and arthritis affecting large joints of lower limb.

3. GIT- Abdominal pain, vomiting, intussusception. 



Reference: Essential Pediatrics by O.P Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 628, 629.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy weighing 15 kg and 100 cm tall with blood urea 100mg/dl and serum creatinine 1 mg/dl is admitted in the Pediatric Nephrology ward. Calculate the eGFR of the patient. 
1. 33ml/min/ 1.73 m2
2. 80 ml/min/1.73 m2
3. 40 ml/min/1.73 m2 
4. 65ml/min/1.73m2
questions.solution:
In children, the most frequently used creatinine-based eGFR equation is the revised bedside Schwartz: 
0.413 × Height (cm) / Serum Cr (mg/dL).

Using the given values:

Height = 100 cm Serum creatinine = 1 mg/dl k = 0.413

eGFR = 0.41 × (100 cm) / (1 mg/dl) = 41 ml/min/1.73 m2 



Reference: Nelson Textbook Of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page no 2715,2716 .

questions.text: A worried mother brings her 18-month-old son to the outpatient department with complaints of repeated urinary tract infections. During diagnostic work-up, pelvic USG shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario, along with the ultrasound showing the key-hole sign, indicates posterior urethral valves (PUV), characterized by dilation of the bladder and proximal urethra.

Posterior urethral valves are membranes with a small slit located just distal to the verumontanum, functioning as flap valves that obstruct antegrade urinary flow.

PUV is the most common congenital cause of bladder outlet obstruction in males and is classified into three types according to Young's classification.

Diagnosis is often made antenatally via ultrasound, which reveals bilateral hydronephrosis above a distended bladder. If undiagnosed prenatally, neonates typically present with recurrent urinary infections, uremia, or renal failure.

The investigation of choice for PUV is micturating cystourethrography (MCUG).

Initial management involves catheterization to relieve obstruction and preserve renal function, while definitive treatment consists of urethroscopic destruction of the valves, with lifelong supportive care required.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented with a history of ederna of the face which later progressed to generalised edema. Urine showed massive proteinuria and light microscopy was normall Electron microscopy showed effacement of podocyte foot processes. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This case of nephrotic syndrome exhibits effacement of the podocyte foot processes, which is characteristic of minimal change disease (MCD).

Minimal change disease is the most prevalent cause of nephrotic syndrome, typically occurring in children aged 2-6 years. The clinical presentation includes nephrotic syndrome features such as heavy proteinuria, edema, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidemia. Patients may be asymptomatic or present with peripheral edema.

A renal biopsy is not necessary for confirmation; treatment can be started if the child presents with the classic clinical signs of nephrotic syndrome. Light microscopy shows normal glomeruli, while electron microscopy reveals effacement of the podocyte foot processes.

Patients with MCD typically respond very well to steroid therapy with prednisone or prednisolone.

The standard treatment regimen consists of a daily dose of 60 mg/m²/day for 6 weeks, followed by a single dose of 40 mg/m² on alternate days for the next 6 weeks.
 

Other options:

  • Membranous glomerulonephritis: Light microscopy shows diffuse thickening of GBM; EM shows subepithelial deposits (“spike and dome”).

  • Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS): Light microscopy shows focal sclerosis; often resistant to steroids.

  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN): Presents with hematuria, hypertension, RBC casts; LM shows hypercellular glomeruli; EM shows subepithelial “humps.”

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presented with dark-colored urine as shown below, oliguria, hypertension, and facial puffiness for 3 days. The urine test is positive for albumin. He had a history of throat infection 2 weeks back. On microscopic examination, enlarged, pale glomeruli and epithelial humps are seen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The case features classic signs of Post-Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis (PSGN):

Key Clues:

  • Dark-colored (tea/cola) urine → Hematuria

  • Oliguria, hypertension, facial puffiness → Nephritic syndrome features

  • History of throat infection 2 weeks back → Latent period typical of PSGN

  • Urine: Albumin + RBCs

  • Biopsy finding: "Epithelial humps" → Subepithelial immune complex deposits, pathognomonic for PSGN


Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is an immune complex–mediated glomerular disease that follows infection with nephritogenic strains of Group A β-hemolytic Streptococcus. Antigen–antibody complexes deposit in the glomeruli, activating complement and causing inflammation.

Timing

  • Pharyngitis: PSGN develops 1–2 weeks after.

  • Skin infections (impetigo): Onset is usually 3–6 weeks post-infection.

    Clinical Features

  • Gross hematuria: Tea- or cola-colored urine

  • Periorbital edema, especially in the morning

  • Hypertension

  • Oliguria or decreased urine output

  • Possible mild to moderate renal impairment

    Investigations

  • Low serum C3 (returns to normal in 6–8 weeks)

  • Elevated ASO titer (or anti-DNase B for skin infections)

  • Urinalysis: RBCs, RBC casts, and mild proteinuria

  • Renal biopsy (if done):

    • Light microscopy: Hypercellular glomeruli

    • Immunofluorescence: "Starry sky" granular deposits of IgG & C3

    • Electron microscopy: Subepithelial "hump-like" deposits

      Management

  • Supportive care

  • Control of fluid overload and hypertension

  • Diuretics may be needed

  • Antibiotics only if active infection persists

  • No role for steroids unless rapidly progressive features develop


Reference:Nelson textbook of pediatrics 21st edition Page no 2723-2724

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy has non-blanching rashes on the legs and buttocks as seen in the picture. He also complains of joint pains, abdominal pain, vomiting, and blood in the stool. Lab investigations revealed normal platelet count and urine analysis shows haematuria +++ and proteinuria +. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Non-blanching purpura localized to buttocks and lower limbs.

  • Joint pain (arthralgia/arthritis) – common in HSP.

  • Gastrointestinal symptoms – abdominal pain, vomiting, blood in stool (GI bleeding is common).

  • Hematuria +++ and Proteinuria + – indicates renal involvement, a classic feature of HSP.

  • Normal platelet count – rules out ITP.

  • Age group: 3–10 years is the common age range for HSP.

    Pathophysiology:

  • HSP is an IgA-mediated small vessel vasculitis, often post-infectious.

  • It affects skin, joints, GI tract, and kidneys.

    Why not the other options?

  1. Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN):

    • Involves medium-sized arteries, not small vessels.

    • More systemic (HTN, neuropathy, renal infarcts).

    • Rash is not typically palpable purpura.

  2. Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE):

    • Would show systemic symptoms, ANA positivity, cytopenias.

    • Rash is usually malar, not palpable purpura.

  3. Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP):

    • Causes petechiae/purpura but with low platelet count, not normal.

    • No joint pain, GI bleed, or hematuria.



Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 258
